<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Automated Decomposition of Model-based Learning Problems +L+ </title>

<author> Brian C. Williams and Bill Millar +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Recom Technologies, Caelum Research +L+

NASA Ames Research Center, </affiliation> <address> MS 269-2 +L+

Moffett Field, CA 94305 USA +L+ </address>

<email> E-mail: williams, millar@ptolemy.arc.nasa.gov +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

A new generation of sensor rich, massively distributed +L+

autonomous systems is being developed that has +L+

the potential for unprecedented performance, such +L+

as smart buildings, reconfigurable factories, adaptive +L+

traffic systems and remote earth ecosystem monitoring. To achieve high performance these massive systems will need to accurately model themselves and +L+

their environment from sensor information. Accomplishing this on a grand scale requires automating the +L+

art of large-scale modeling. This paper presents a +L+

formalization of decompositional, model-based learning +L+

(DML), a method developed by observing a modeler's +L+

expertise at decomposing large scale model estimation +L+

tasks. The method exploits a striking analogy between +L+

learning and consistency-based diagnosis. Moriarty, +L+

an implementation of DML, has been applied to thermal modeling of a smart building, demonstrating a +L+

significant improvement in learning rate. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Generation of task-specific segmentation +L+

procedures as a model selection task +L+ </title>

<author> Ralf Herbrich and Tobias Scheffer +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Technische Universitat Berlin, +L+

Artificial Intelligence Research Group, </affiliation> <address> Sekr. FR 5-8, +L+

Franklinstr. 28/29. D-10587 Berlin, Germany +L+ </address>

<email> email: ralfh|scheffer@cs.tu-berlin.de +L+ </email>

<date> December 1, 1997 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

In image segmentation problems, there is usually a vast amount of filter +L+

operations available, a subset of which has to be selected and instantiated +L+

in order to obtain a satisfactory segmentation procedure for a particular domain. In supervised segmentation, a mapping from features, such as filter +L+

outputs for individual pixels, to classes is induced automatically. However, +L+

since the sample size required for supervised learning grows exponentially +L+

in the number of features it is not feasible to learn a segmentation procedure +L+

from a large amount of possible filters. But we argue that automatic model +L+

selection methods are able to select a region model in terms of some filters. +L+

We propose a wrapper algorithm that performs this task. We present results +L+

on artificial textured images (Brodatz) and report on our experiences with +L+

x-ray images. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: model based image segmentation, automatic model selection, +L+

learning pixel classifier, texture segmentation +L+ </keyword>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A Neural Net for Determining Structural +L+

Similarity of Recursive Programs +L+ </title>

<author> Kristina Schadler, Ute Schmid, Hendrik Lubben, Bernd +L+

Machenschalk +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Research Group "Methods of Artificial Intelligence" +L+

Institute for Applied Computer Science, Technische Universitat +L+

Berlin +L+ </affiliation>

<address> email: schaedle,schmid,compuman,herold@cs.tu-berlin.de +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract. In this work it will be shown, how the comparison of recursive program schemata (RPS) can be reduced to an only slightly modified +L+

type of the search for maximal isomorphic subgraphs by interpreting the +L+

RPS as directed, cyclic, labelled graphs. The quality of the mapping of +L+

two RPS can be used as a quantitative measure for similarity of RPS +L+

among each other. The simultaneously calculated graph morphism can +L+

serve as a basis for the detection of analogies between the RPS. A special +L+

neural net, developed for the solution of general graph-matching problems, realizes the search for a sensible and as comprising as possible +L+

mapping between two RPS. It is shown, which special properties of RPS +L+

have to be accounted for in the modeling and how these can be incorporated into the algorithms when using a special neural approach for the +L+

solution. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1. Structural similarities in case-based reason </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<pubnum> ICOPS 97 +L+

ICOPS 97 +L+ </pubnum>

<title> Nonlinear Poisson Solve for Boltzmann Electrons +L+ </title>

<author> K. L. Cartwright , J. P. Verboncoeur , and C. K.Birdsall  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Electronics Research Laboratory +L+

University of California, </affiliation> <address> Berkeley, CA 94720 +L+ </address>

<date> October 29, 1997 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Kinetic simulation of plasmas in which equilibrium occurs over ion timescales poses +L+

a computational challenge due to the disparate timescales of the electron plasma frequency (~ 10 9 ), the ion plasma frequency (~ 10 7 ), ion transit frequency (~ 10 6 ), and +L+

the ionization frequency (~ 10 7 ). Hybrid electrostatic PIC algorithms are presented +L+

in which the electrons reach thermodynamic equilibrium with the ions each time step. +L+

There are two different approximations for the electrons. First, the nonlinear Boltzmann relationship for the electrons can be applied to the bulk of a plasma. Second, +L+

there is a truncated Maxwellian which is used in sheaths; this approximation truncates +L+

the electron distribution at the wall potential. The error associated with neglecting +L+

this second approximation in the sheath is small. The collision cross section, (E), can +L+

be a tabulated or fitted function; the method is implemented with He cross sections. +L+

These approximations neglect effects faster than ion time-scales, decreasing the computer time used by over an order of magnitude; however, they increase the complexity +L+

of the boundary conditions and the simulation is no longer self-consistent. Theoretical +L+

ramifications of these approximations are examined, and results are compared with full +L+ </abstract>

<note> Supported by ONR-AASERT N100014-94-1-1033 +L+

Supported by the Air Force Office of Scientific Research-MURI under grant F49620-95-1-0253 +L+

Supported by the Air Force Office of Scientific Research-under grant FDF49620-96-1-0154 +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Refraction and Reflection of Ion Acoustic Solitons by Space Charge Sheath +L+ </title>

<author> K. L. Cartwright and C. K. Birdsall +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Electronics Research Laboratory +L+

University of California, </affiliation> <address> Berkeley, CA 94720-1774 +L+ </address>

<note> Acknowledgments: This research is supported by ONR grant number N00014-90-J-1198 and ONR-AASERT 23057. +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Experiments have shown[1],[2] that ion acoustic solitons tunnel through the space charge sheath +L+

in front of a grid without time delay. They are absorbed resonantly when the spatial width of the +L+

wave is close to the characteristic gradient scale length of the sheath. The reflection and transmission +L+

coefficients found in these experiments have compared well with theory in the long wavelength limit[3]. +L+

However, to achieve this comparison, two parameters were added that were not in the original theory. +L+

These parameters allow for the absorption of wave energy by the space charge sheath. The goal of our +L+

numerical simulations, designed to reproduce the experimental results, is to uncover the mechanism of +L+

this energy loss and large speed of propagation through the sheath. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Photo Ionization-Steady State </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> Survey Paper +L+ </note>

<title> Update-in-place Analysis for Sets +L+ </title>

<author> Chung Yung +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department +L+

Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences +L+

New York University +L+ </affiliation>

<email> yung@cs.nyu.edu +L+ </email>

<date> December 15, 1997 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This survey paper describes the current approaches on the update-in-place analysis +L+

for sets. Pure functional languages do not allow mutations, destructive updates, or selective updates so that straightforward implementations of functional language compilers +L+

may induce large amounts of copying to preserve program semantics. The unnecessary +L+

copying of data can increase both the execution time and the memory requirements of +L+

an application. Introducing sets to functional languages as a primitive data constructor posts a new problem of update-in-place analysis in functional languages. Moreover, most of the compiler optimization techniques depend on the side-effects and the +L+

update-in-place analysis serves as the premise of applying such optimization techniques. +L+

Among other compiler optimization techniques, finite differencing captures common yet +L+

distinctive program constructions of costly repeated calculations and transforms them +L+

into more efficient incremental program constructions. This dissertation is an attempt +L+

to explore the update-in-place analysis for sets in functional languages in order to apply finite differencing to compiling pure functional languages. In this survey paper, +L+

we will describe the approaches of update-in-place analysis and the finite differencing +L+

techniques. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Motivation and Introduction </intro>

for the degree of Master of Engineering. +L+ </note>

<NEW_HEADER>

<note> EUROPEAN ORGANISATION FOR NUCLEAR RESEARCH +L+

CERN-PPE/96-xxx +L+ </note>

<date> 25 January 1996 +L+ </date>

<title> Search for Chargino and Neutralino +L+

Production Using the OPAL Detector +L+

at +L+

s = 130 136 GeV at LEP +L+

The OPAL Collaboration +L+ </title>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

A search for charginos and neutralinos, predicted by supersymmetric theories, has been +L+

performed using a data sample of 2.6 pb 1 at a centre-of-mass energy of p s =130 GeV and +L+

2.6 pb 1 at 136 GeV collected with the OPAL detector at LEP during November 1995. No +L+

candidate events were observed. The 95% C.L. lower limit on the lightest chargino mass +L+

in the Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model is 65.4 GeV if the universal scalar mass +L+

m 0 is greater than 1 TeV, and 58.7 GeV for the smallest m 0 compatible with slepton and +L+

sneutrino mass limits obtained at centre-of-mass energies near the Z peak. These limits +L+

were obtained under the conditions that the lightest chargino is heavier than the lightest +L+

neutralino by more than 10 GeV and tan fi is larger than 1.5. The results of a model +L+

independent search for charginos and neutralinos are also given. +L+ </abstract>

<note> Submitted to Physics Letters +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> System Administration: Monitoring, Diagnosing, and Repairing +L+ </title>

<author> Eric Anderson +L+ </author>

<abstract> We first describe the general goals of system administration explaining the +L+

relationship to monitoring, diagnosing, and repairing (MDR). Then, we describe the +L+

functional and environmental concerns for a MDR system, and use these concerns to +L+

explain how previous approaches have failed to fully address the problem. Next, we +L+

describe the major pieces of our approach, and identify the research questions +L+

associated with each piece. Finally we present a method for testing the system when +L+

it is created. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Path integral approach to no-Coriolis +L+

approximation in heavy-ion collisions +L+ </title>

<author> K. Hagino, 1 N. Takigawa, 1 , A.B. Balantekin 2 , and J.R. Bennett 3 +L+ </author>

<affiliation> 1 Department of Physics, Tohoku University, </affiliation> <address> 980-77 Sendai, Japan +L+ </address>

<affiliation> 2 Physics Department, University of Wisconsin, </affiliation> +L+

<address> Madison, Wisconsin 53706, USA +L+ </address>

<affiliation> 3 Department of Physics and Astronomy, +L+

University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, </affiliation> <address> Chapel Hill, NC 27599-3255 +L+ </address>

<date> June 26, 1995 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We use the two time influence functional method of the path integral approach in +L+

order to reduce the dimension of the coupled-channels equations for heavy-ion reactions +L+

based on the no-Coriolis approximation. Our method is superior to other methods in that +L+

it easily enables us to study the cases where the initial spin of the colliding particle is not +L+

zero. It can also be easily applied to the cases where there is a spin-orbit force, and where +L+

the internal degrees of freedom are not necessarily collective coordinates. It also clarifies +L+

the underlying assumption of the approximation. +L+ </abstract>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> ACM SIGPLAN Workshop on Languages, Compilers and Tools for Real-Time Systems, La Jolla, California, June 1995. +L+ </note>

<title> RTsynchronizer: Language Support for +L+

 Real-Time Specifications in Distributed Systems +L+  </title>

<author> Shangping Ren and Gul A. Agha +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 1304 W. Springfield Avenue +L+ </address>

<affiliation> University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Urbana, IL 61801, USA +L+ </address>

<email> Email: f ren j agha g@cs.uiuc.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We argue that the specification of an object's functional behavior and the timing constraints imposed +L+

on it may be separated. Specifically, we describe +L+

RTsynchronizer, a high-level programming language +L+

construct for specifying real-time constraints between +L+

objects in a distributed concurrent system. During program execution, RTsynchronizers affect the +L+

scheduling of distributed objects to enforce real-time +L+

relations between events. Objects in our system are +L+

defined in terms of the actor model extended with +L+

timing assumptions. Separation of the functional +L+

behaviors of actors and the timing constraints on +L+

patterns of actor invocation provides at least three +L+

important advantages. First, it simplifies code development by separating design concerns. Second, +L+

multiple timing constraints can be independently +L+

specified and composed. And finally, a specification +L+

of timing constraints can be reused even if the +L+

representation of the functional behavior of actors has +L+

changed, and conversely. +L+

A number of examples are given to illustrate the +L+

use of RTsynchronizers. These examples illustrate +L+

how real-time constraints for periodic events, simultaneous events, exception handling, and producer-consumer may be specified. +L+ </abstract>

<note> The research described has been made possible by support from the Office of Naval Research (ONR contract numbers N00014-90-J-1899 and N00014-93-1-0273), by an Incentives for Excellence Award from the Digital Equipment Corporation Faculty Program, and by joint support from the Defense +L+

Advanced Research Projects Agency and the National Science +L+

Foundation (NSF CCR 90-07195). The authors would like to +L+

thank Mark Astley, Brian Nielsen, Masahiko Saitoh and Daniel +L+

Sturman for helpful discussions concerning the manuscript. +L+ </note>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A Visualization Model for Concurrent Systems +L+ </title>

<author> Mark Astley and Gul A. Agha  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Open Systems Laboratory +L+

Department of Computer Science +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 1304 W. Springfield Avenue +L+ </address>

<affiliation> University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Urbana, IL 61801, USA +L+ </address>

<phone> Phone: (217) 244-3087 +L+

Fax: (217) 333-3501 +L+ </phone>

<email> Email: fastley j aghag@cs.uiuc.edu +L+ </email>

<keyword> Keywords: Actors, Distributed Systems, Program Visualization +L+ </keyword>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Concurrent systems maintain a distributed state and thus require coordination and synchronization between +L+

components to ensure consistency. To provide a coherent design approach to concurrent systems, recent work +L+

has employed an object-based methodology which emphasizes interactions through well-defined interfaces. The +L+

Actor model has provided formal reasoning about distributed object systems. Nonetheless, due to the complex +L+

interactions among components and the high volume of observable information produced, understanding and +L+

reasoning about concurrent algorithms in terms of simple interactions is a difficult task. Coordination patterns, +L+

which abstract over simple interactions, are not biased by low-level event orderings and are the appropriate +L+

mechanism for reasoning about concurrent algorithms. We outline a methodology for visualizing coordination +L+

patterns in concurrent algorithms which emphasizes observable interactions and causal connections between +L+

objects. We introduce visualizers as a linguistic mechanism for mapping coordination patterns to visualization. +L+

Visualizers are specified separately from algorithm code and thus respect code integrity. Moreover, visualizers +L+

may be implemented strictly in terms of object interfaces and thus preserve object encapsulation. +L+ </abstract>

<note> Author for contact. +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> IEEE JOURNAL ON SELECTED AREAS IN COMMUNICATIONS, VOL. 13, NO. 7, SEPTEMBER 1995 1 +L+ </note>

<title> Billing Users and Pricing for TCP +L+ </title>

<author> Richard J. Edell, Nick McKeown and Pravin P. Varaiya +L+ </author>

<abstract> Abstract| This paper presents a system for billing users +L+

for their TCP traffic. This is achieved by postponing the +L+

establishment of connections while the user is contacted, +L+

verifying in a secure way that they are prepared to pay. By +L+

presenting the user with cost and price information, the system can be used for cost recovery and to encourage efficient +L+

use of network resources. The system requires no changes to +L+

existing protocols or applications and can be used to recover +L+

costs between cooperating sites. Statistics collected from a +L+

four day trace of traffic between the University of Califor-nia, Berkeley and the rest of the Internet demonstrate that +L+

such a billing system is practical and introduces acceptable +L+

latency. An implementation based on the BayBridge prototype router is described. Our study also indicates that +L+

pricing schemes may be used to control network congestion +L+

either by rescheduling time-insensitive traffic to a less expensive time of the day, or by smoothing packet transfers to +L+

reduce traffic peaks. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords| Internet economics, network tracing, usage-accounting +L+ </keyword>

<intro> I. Introduction </intro>

<note> Appears in Proceedings of the 4 +L+

th +L+

International Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining, +L+

AAAI Press, 1998, 359-363. +L+ </note>

<title> Learning to Predict Rare Events in Event Sequences +L+ </title>

<author> Gary M. Weiss +L+

and Haym Hirsh +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

Rutgers University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> New Brunswick, NJ 08903 +L+ </address>

<email> gmweiss@att.com, hirsh@cs.rutgers.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract  +L+

Learning to predict rare events from sequences of events +L+

with categorical features is an important, real-world, +L+

problem that existing statistical and machine learning +L+

methods are not well suited to solve. This paper describes +L+

timeweaver, a genetic algorithm based machine learning +L+

system that predicts rare events by identifying predictive +L+

temporal and sequential patterns. Timeweaver is applied to +L+

the task of predicting telecommunication equipment failures +L+

from 110,000 alarm messages and is shown to outperform +L+

existing learning methods. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> Introduction </intro>

<title> A Comparative Study of Three Paradigms for Object +L+

Recognition Bayesian Statistics, Neural Networks and +L+

Expert Systems.  +L+ </title>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Object recognition, which involves the classification of objects into one of many a priori known object types, and determining object characteristics such as pose, is a difficult +L+

problem. A wide range of approaches have been proposed and applied to this problem with +L+

limited success. This paper presents a brief comparative study of methods from three different paradigms for object recognition: Bayesian, Neural Network and Expert Systems. +L+ </abstract>

<title> Evaluation and Ordering of Rules Extracted from Feedforward +L+

Networks  +L+ </title>

<author> Ismail Taha and Joydeep Ghosh +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Laboratory of Artificial Neural Systems +L+

University of Texas +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Austin, TX. 78712-1084 +L+ </address>

<email> fismail,ghoshg@pine.ece.utexas.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Rules extracted from trained feedforward networks +L+

can be used for explanation, validation, and cross-referencing of network output decisions. This paper +L+

introduces a rule evaluation and ordering mechanism +L+

that orders rules extracted from feedforward networks +L+

based on three performance measures. Detailed experiments using three rule extraction techniques as applied +L+

to the Wisconsin breast cancer database, illustrate the +L+

power of the proposed methods. Moreover, a method +L+

of integrating the output decisions of both the extracted +L+

rule-based system and the corresponding trained network is proposed. The integrated system provides further improvements. +L+ </abstract>

<title> Digital Communication Over Rayleigh +L+

Fading Channels +L+ </title>

<author> T. M. Parks +L+ </author>

<date> 15 December 1992 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The properties of Rayleigh fading channels are derived and their +L+

effects on various QAM signal constellations are explored. A simplified +L+

channel model for an urban radio environment is justified in order +L+

to simplify the analysis of error performance for the constellations. +L+

Finally, arguments are made for extending the results to more general +L+

channel models. +L+ </abstract>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Switching through Singularities +L+ </title>

<author> C. J. Tomlin and S. S. Sastry +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences +L+

University of California, </affiliation> <address> Berkeley CA 94720 +L+ </address>

<email> fclairet, sastryg@eecs.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Asymptotic tracking is studied for systems in which the relative degree is not well defined, +L+

meaning that the control law derived from exact input-output linearization has singularities in +L+

the state space. We propose a tracking control law which switches between approximate tracking +L+

[1] close to the singularities, and exact tracking away from the singularities, and we study the +L+

applicability of this law based on the behavior of the system's zero dynamics at the switching +L+

boundary. As in [1], the ball and beam example is used to motivate the study. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: Switching, nonlinear control, zero dynamics, exact and asymptotic tracking, +L+

nonminimum phase. +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Simulation as a Tool for Hybrid System Design +L+ </title>

<author> John Lygeros, Datta Godbole & Shankar Sastry +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Intelligent Machines and Robotics Laboratory +L+

Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences +L+

University of California, </affiliation> <address> Berkeley, CA 94720 +L+ </address>

<email> lygeros,godbole,sastry@eecs.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

A case study of the use of simulation as a tool +L+

for design and validation of hybrid systems is presented. We use the Intelligent Vehicle Highway Systems (IVHS) architecture of [1], a system that involves +L+

both continuous state and discrete event controllers as +L+

our example of a hierarchical hybrid system. We point +L+

out that even though analytical methods do not exist +L+

for verification of hybrid control system, a simulation +L+

tool can be useful to (in)validate that the the hybrid +L+

system operates properly. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Construction of Fuzzy Linguistic Model +L+ </title>

<author> Tak-Kuen John Koo +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Robotics and Intelligent Machines Laboratory +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 211-85 Cory Hall, </address> <affiliation> Department of EECS +L+ </affiliation>

<affiliation> University of California at Berkeley +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Berkeley, CA94720 +L+ </address>

<email> koo@robotics.eecs.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Using linguistic variables to describe the behavior of a +L+

hybrid system, which consists of a discrete event system and a continuous system, could make the design +L+

of the controller and verification of the system perform +L+

on an unified framework. In this paper, we show the +L+

construction of a fuzzy linguistic model from a given +L+

mathematical model of a physical system. By considering the state-space realization of the model, the system +L+

construction problem can be transformed into a function approximation problem. We propose to use projection theorem in obtaining an optimal fuzzy system +L+

which is the best approximation of a given nonlinear +L+

function in L 2 (U ) space. We show that the existence +L+

and uniqueness of the optimal solution is assured when +L+

the Fuzzy Basis Functions(FBFs) are linearly independent. We demonstrate that the dependence of the basis +L+

functions can be examined by checking the condition of +L+

the Gram determinant associated to the FBFs. Finally, +L+

a method is proposed in converting the optimal coefficients into fuzzy sets to obtain a fuzzy linguistic model. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Hybrid Control in Air Traffic Management Systems +L+ </title>

<author> S. Sastry, G. Meyer , C. Tomlin, J. Lygeros, D. Godbole and G. Pappas +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences, +L+

University of California, </affiliation> <address> Berkeley, CA 94720 +L+ </address>

<address> MS 210-3, </address> <affiliation> NASA Ames Research Center, </affiliation> <address> Moffett Field CA 94035 +L+ </address>

<email> fsastry, gmeyer, clairet, lygeros, godbole, gpappas@eecs.berkeley.edug +L+ </email>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

In a new collaborative project involving the University of California, Berkeley, NASA Ames Research +L+

Center, and Honeywell Systems Research Center, we +L+

have begun the study of hierarchical, hybrid control +L+

systems in the framework of air traffic management +L+

systems (ATMS). The need for a new ATMS arises +L+

from the overcrowding of large urban airports and +L+

the need to more efficiently land and take off larger +L+

numbers of aircraft, without building new runways. +L+

Technological advances that make a more advanced +L+

air traffic control system a reality include the availability of relatively inexpensive and fast real time +L+

computers (both on board the aircraft and in the control tower) and global positioning systems. The usefulness of these technological advances is currently +L+

limited by today's air traffic control system, which +L+

involves the use of "freeways" in the Terminal Radar +L+

Approach Control (TRACON) region around urban +L+

airports. These freeways are set approach patterns +L+

to runways which do not allow for the possibility of +L+

so-called "free flight" by an aircraft to its destination. +L+

Limiting the aircraft trajectories in this manner results in the addition of both planned and unplanned +L+

delays to air travel. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: hybrid systems, air traffic management, +L+

flight control. +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1. Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A Fault Tolerant Control Architecture +L+

for Automated Highway Systems  +L+ </title>

<author> John Lygeros, Datta N. Godbole, Mireille Broucke +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences +L+

University of California, Berkeley +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Berkeley, CA 94720 +L+ </address>

<email> lygeros, godbole, mire@robotics.eecs.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We propose a hierarchical control architecture for dealing with faults and adverse environmental conditions on an Automated Highway System (AHS). Our design extends +L+

a previous control architecture that works under normal conditions of operation. The +L+

faults that are considered in our design are classified according to the capabilities remaining on the vehicle or roadside after the fault has occurred. Information about these +L+

capabilities is used by supervisors in each of the layers of the architecture to select appropriate control strategies. We outline the extended control strategies that are needed +L+

by these supervisors and, in certain cases, give examples of their detailed operation. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords +L+

Automated Highway System Design, Fault Tolerant Control, Safety +L+ </keyword>

<note> Research supported by the California PATH program, Institute of Transportation Studies, University of +L+

California, Berkeley, under MOU-135 +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Motion Recovery From Image Sequences: Discrete Viewpoint vs. +L+

Differential Viewpoint  +L+ </title>

<author> Yi Ma Jana Kosecka Shankar Sastry x +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Electronics Research Laboratory +L+

University of California at Berkeley +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Berkeley, CA 94720-1774 +L+ </address>

<email> fmayi, janka, sastryg@robotics.eecs.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<date> November 3, 1997 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The aim of this paper is to explore intrinsic geometric methods of recovering the three +L+

dimensional motion of a moving camera from a sequence of images. Generic similarities between +L+

the discrete approach and the differential approach are revealed through a parallel development +L+

of their analogous motion estimation theories. +L+

We begin with a brief review of the (discrete) essential matrix approach, showing how to +L+

recover the 3D displacement from image correspondences. The space of normalized essential +L+

matrices is characterized geometrically: the unit tangent bundle of the rotation group is a +L+

double covering of the space of normalized essential matrices. This characterization naturally +L+

explains the geometry of the possible number of 3D displacements which can be obtained from +L+

the essential matrix. +L+

Second, a differential version of the essential matrix constraint previously explored by [19, 20] +L+

is introduced. We then present the precise characterization of the space of differential essential +L+

matrices, which gives rise to a novel eigenvector-decomposition-based 3D velocity estimation +L+

algorithm from the optical flow measurements. This algorithm gives a unique solution to the +L+

motion estimation problem and serves as a differential counterpart of the SVD-based 3D displacement estimation algorithm from the discrete case. +L+

Finally, simulation results are presented evaluating the performance of our algorithm in terms +L+

of bias and sensitivity of the estimates with respect to the noise in optical flow measurements. +L+

The presented unifying theory of the motion estimation using discrete and differential version of the Longuet-Higgins (essential) constraint can be extended to the case of uncalibrated +L+

cameras. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: optical flow, epipolar constraint, motion estimation. +L+ </keyword>

<note> Research is supported by ARO under the MURI grant DAAH04-96-1-0341, "An Integrated Approach to Intelligent +L+

Systems". +L+ </note>

<address> Address: 211-109 Cory Hall, EECS, UC Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720-1772, USA. </address> <phone> Tel: (USA) 510-643-2383. +L+ </phone>

<address> Address: 211- 98 Cory Hall, EECS, UC Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720-1772, USA. </address> <phone> Tel: (USA) 510-643-5806. +L+ </phone>

<address> x Address: 269M Cory Hall, EECS, UC Berkeley, Berkeley, CA 94720-1772, USA. </address> <phone> Tel: (USA) 510-642-1857. +L+ </phone>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> SmartATMS : A SIMULATOR FOR AIR TRAFFIC MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS +L+ </title>

<author> Tak-Kuen John Koo +L+

Yi Ma +L+

George J. Pappas +L+

Claire Tomlin +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Robotics and Intelligent Machines Laboratory +L+

Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences +L+

University of California at Berkeley +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Berkeley, CA 94720 +L+ </address>

<email> koo,mayi,gpappas,clairet@eecs.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

Air Traffic Management Systems (ATMS) of the future will feature Free Flight, in which aircraft choose +L+

their own routes, altitude, and speed, and automated conflict resolution methods in which aircraft +L+

will coordinate to resolve conflicts. The resulting distributed control architecture is a hybrid system, with +L+

mixed discrete event and continuous time dynamics. +L+

SmartATMS is an object oriented modeling and simulation facility which accounts for these hybrid issues +L+

and will serve as a uniform modeling framework for +L+

the design and evaluation of various ATMS concepts. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 INTRODUCTION </intro>

<note> Appears in KDD-97 +L+ </note>

<title> MineSet: An Integrated System for Data Mining +L+ </title>

<author> Cliff Brunk James Kelly Ron Kohavi +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Data Mining and Visualization +L+

Silicon Graphics, Inc. +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 2011 N. Shoreline Blvd +L+

Mountain View, CA 94043-1389 +L+ </address>

<email> fbrunk,jkelly,ronnykg@engr.sgi.com +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

MineSet TM , Silicon Graphics' interactive system for +L+

data mining, integrates three powerful technologies: +L+

database access, analytical data mining, and data visualization. It supports the knowledge discovery process from data access and preparation through iterative analysis and visualization to deployment. Mine-Set is based on a client-server architecture that scales +L+

to large databases. The database access component +L+

provides a rich set of operators that can be used to +L+

preprocess and transform the stored data into forms +L+

appropriate for visualization and analytical mining. +L+

The 3D visualization capabilities allow direct data visualization for exploratory analysis, including tools +L+

for displaying high-dimensional data containing geographical and hierarchical information. The analytical mining algorithms help identify potentially interesting models of the data, which can be viewed using +L+

visualization tools specialized for the learned models. +L+

Third party vendors can interface to the MineSet tools +L+

for model deployment and for integration with other +L+

packages. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> Introduction </intro>

<title> Tioga: Providing Data Management Support for +L+

Scientific Visualization Applications  +L+ </title>

<author> Michael Stonebraker, Jolly Chen, Nobuko Nathan, Caroline Paxson, Jiang Wu +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Division, EECS Department +L+

University of California +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Berkeley, CA 94720 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We present a user interface paradigm for +L+

database management systems that is motivated +L+

by scientific visualization applications. Our +L+

graphical user interface includes a "boxes and arrows" notation for database access and a flight +L+

simulator model of movement through information space. We also provide means to specify a +L+

hierarchy of abstracts of data of different types +L+

and resolutions, so that a "zoom" capability can +L+

be supported. The underlying DBMS support for +L+

this system is described and includes the compilation of query plans into megaplans, new algorithms for data buffering, and provisions for +L+

a guaranteed rate of data delivery. The current state of the Tioga implementation is also described. +L+ </abstract>

Engineers, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA), Epoch Systems, Inc., Hewlett-Packard +L+

and TRW Space and Electronics. +L+ </note>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

In this paper we present a prototype system for +L+

shown in the context of its use by two geographically distributed scientific groups with demanding data storage and processing requirements. +L+

store. We claim that the design principles +L+

embodied in BigSur provide sufficient exibility +L+

to achieve the difficult scientific and technical +L+

objectives of Mission to Planet Earth. +L+ </abstract>

<title> The Use of Description Logics in KBSE systems +L+

Survey Paper +L+ </title>

<author> Premkumar T. Devanbu & Mark A. Jones +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Artificial Intelligence Principles Research Department +L+

AT&T Bell Laboratories +L+ </affiliation>

<email> fprem,jonesg@research.att.com +L+ </email>

<address> Murray Hill, NJ 07063 +L+ </address>

<date> February 9, 1994 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The increasing size and complexity of many software +L+

systems demand a greater emphasis on capturing and +L+

maintaining knowledge at many different levels within +L+

the software development process. This knowledge includes descriptions of the hardware and software components and their behavior, external and internal design specifications, and support for system testing. +L+

The knowledge-based software engineering (KBSE) research paradigm is concerned with systems that use +L+

formally represented knowledge, with associated inference procedures, to support the various subactivi-ties of software development. As they grow in scale, +L+

KBSE systems must balance expressivity and inferential power with the real demands of knowledge base +L+

construction, maintenance, performance and comprehensibility. Description Logics (DL's) possess several +L+

features a terminological orientation, a formal semantics and efficient reasoning procedures which offer an effective tradeoff of these factors. We discuss +L+

three KBSE systems in which DL's capture some of +L+

the requisite knowledge needed to support design, coding and testing activities. We close with a discussion +L+

of the benefits of DL's and ways to address some of +L+

their limitations. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

<title> Dealing With Disaster: +L+

Surviving Misbehaved Kernel Extensions +L+ </title>

<author> Margo I. Seltzer, Yasuhiro Endo, Christopher Small, Keith A. Smith +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Harvard University +L+ </affiliation>

<note> 5th Midwest Artificial Intelligence and Cognitive Science Conference +L+ </note>

<title> Identifying Language from Raw Speech  +L+

An Application of Recurrent Neural Networks +L+ </title>

<author> Weilan Wu, Stan C. Kwasny, Barry L. Kalman, E. Maynard Engebretson +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

Washington Unversity +L+ </affiliation>

<address> St. Louis, MO 63130 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

People can differentiate spoken languages +L+

without understanding them, and, in some +L+

sense, this differentiation can only be done +L+

without understanding the language. When +L+

we consider a multi-lingual person trying to +L+

understand an utterance spoken in one of the +L+

languages with which they are familiar, they +L+

will first decide which language this utterance +L+

belongs to, before trying to interpret it. +L+

The language identification task is one +L+

example of high-level feature abstraction from +L+

raw speech. Speech samples are classified +L+

into categories according to what language +L+

was spoken. We conjecture that this classification can be performed reliably and in real +L+

time. To be successful, such a system should +L+

be speaker-independent as well as context-independent. A large amount of training is +L+

required to achieve a satisfactory level of performance. +L+

We present a continuation of previous +L+

work (Kwasny et al., 1992) which introduces +L+

two important improvements to the system: +L+

(1) replacement of the non-recurrent, feed-forward network with a recurrent one, which +L+

is smaller, but still classifies correctly; (2) +L+

development of a frontend processor on a +L+

Nextfi workstation to facilitate sample +L+

recording and data acquisition. This is important for large-scale data acquisition, training, +L+

and testing of the network. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Efficient Restoration of Multicolor Images with +L+

Independent Noise +L+ </title>

<author> Yuri Boykov Olga Veksler Ramin Zabih  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Cornell University, </affiliation> <address> USA +L+ </address>

<keyword> Keywords: Bayesian image restoration; Markov random fields; max flow-min cut +L+ </keyword>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We consider the problem of maximum a posteriori (MAP) restoration of multicolor images +L+

where each pixel has been degraded by independent arbitrary noise. We assume that the +L+

prior distribution is given by a Markov random field with only pairwise site interactions. +L+

Two classes of site interactions are considered: two-valued site interactions, which form a +L+

generalized Potts model; and linear site interactions. We give efficient algorithms based on +L+

graph cuts for both classes. The MAP estimate for a generalized Potts model can be computed by solving a multiway minimum cut problem on a graph. While this graph problem is +L+

computationally intractable, there are fast algorithms for computing provably good approximations. The MAP estimate with linear site interactions can be computed exactly by solving +L+

a minimum cut problem on a graph. This can be performed in nearly linear time. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

<title> The Abstract Class Pattern +L+ </title>

<affiliation> Knowledge Systems Corp. +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 4001 Weston Pkwy, Cary, NC 27513-2303 +L+ </address>

<title> ABSTRACT CLASS Class Behavioral +L+ </title>

<abstract> Intent +L+

polymorphism of those classes. +L+

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Semantic Query Caching for Heterogeneous Databases +L+ </title>

<author> Parke Godfrey +L+ </author>

<affiliation> U.S. Army Research Laboratory +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 2800 Powder Mill Road +L+

Adelphi, Maryland 20783-1197 +L+

U.S.A. +L+ </address>

<email> godfrey@arl.mil +L+ </email>

<author> Jarek Gryz +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

York University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Toronto, Ontario M3J 1P3 +L+

Canada +L+ </address>

<email> jarek@cs.yorku.ca +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Query caching can play a vital role in heterogeneous, multi-database environments. Answers to a query that are available in cache +L+

at the local client can be returned to the user +L+

quickly, while the rest of the query is evaluated. The use of caches can optimize query +L+

evaluation. By caching certain sensitive data +L+

locally, caches can be used to answer the parts +L+

of queries that involve the sensitive data, so it +L+

need not be shipped across the network. Most +L+

prior cache schemes have been tuple-based or +L+

page-based. It is unclear, however, how these +L+

might be adapted for multi-databases. We explore a more flexible semantic query caching +L+

(SQC) approach. In SQC, caches are the answer sets of previous queries, labeled by the +L+

query expressions that produced them. We +L+

promote developing the technology, based on +L+

logic, to manipulate semantic caches, to determine when and how caches can be used to answer subsequent queries, and to optimize via +L+

cache use. +L+ </abstract>

<note> The copyright of this paper belongs to the papers authors. Permission to copy without fee all or part of this material is granted +L+

provided that the copies are not made or distributed for direct +L+

commercial advantage. +L+

Proceedings of the 4th KRDB Workshop +L+

Athens, Greece, 30-August-1997 +L+

(F. Baader, M.A. Jeusfeld, W. Nutt, eds.) +L+ </note>

<web> http://sunsite.informatik.rwth-aachen.de/Publications/CEUR-WS/Vol-8/ +L+ </web>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Revisiting the Paxos algorithm +L+ </title>

<author> Roberto De Prisco ? , Butler Lampson, Nancy Lynch +L+ </author>

<affiliation> MIT Laboratory for Computer Science +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 545 Technology Square NE43, Cambridge, MA 02139, USA. +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract. This paper develops a new I/O automaton model called the +L+

Clock General Timed Automaton (Clock GTA) model. The Clock GTA +L+

is based on the General Timed Automaton (GTA) of Lynch and Vaan- +L+

drager. The Clock GTA provides a systematic way of describing timing- +L+

based systems in which there is a notion of "normal" timing behavior, +L+

but that do not necessarily always exhibit this "normal" behavior. It can +L+

be used for practical time performance analysis based on the stabilization +L+

of the physical system. +L+

We use the Clock GTA automaton to model, verify and analyze the +L+

paxos algorithm. The paxos algorithm is an efficient and highly fault- +L+

tolerant algorithm, devised by Lamport, for reaching consensus in a distributed system. Although it appears to be practical, it is not widely +L+

known or understood. This paper contains a new presentation of the +L+

paxos algorithm, based on a formal decomposition into several interacting components. It also contains a correctness proof and a time performance and fault-tolerance analysis. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: I/O automata models, formal verification, distributed con +L+

sensus, partially synchronous systems, fault-tolerance +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Finding Maximum Flows in Undirected Graphs Seems Easier than +L+

Bipartite Matching +L </title>+

<author> David R. Karger and Matthew S. Levine  +L+ </author>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Consider an n-vertex, m-edge, undirected graph with maximum flow value v. We give a method to find augmenting +L+

paths in such a graph in amortized sub-linear (O(n +L+

p +L+

v)) time +L+

per path. This lets us improve the time bound of the classic augmenting path algorithm to O(m + nv 3=2 ) on simple +L+

graphs. The addition of a blocking flow subroutine gives a +L+

simple, deterministic O(nm 2=3 v 1=6 )-time algorithm. We also +L+

use our technique to improve known randomized algorithms, +L+

giving O(m+nv 5=4 )-time and O(m+n 11=9 v)-time algorithms +L+

for capacitated undirected graphs. For simple graphs, in +L+

which v n, the last bound is O(n 2:2 ), improving on the best +L+

previous bound of O(n 2:5 ), which is also the best known time +L+

bound for bipartite matching. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Bounds on the Time to Detect Failures +L+

Using Bounded-capacity Message Links +L+ </title>

<author> Stephen Ponzio  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> MIT Laboratory for Computer Science +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We consider a system of distributed processors that +L+

communicate by passing messages and that have inexact information about time. Specifically, a processor knows that a single message is delayed by at most +L+

time d and the time between any two of its consecutive steps is at least c 1 and at most c 2 ; it has no +L+

other way of estimating elapsed time. This simple +L+

model is very close to traditional models used in distributed computing theory, and has been studied by +L+

Attiya and Lynch [2, 1] among others. We extend +L+

the model by making a realistic assumption about +L+

how the delay of messages is affected by the rate at +L+

which they are sent. We define a model of message +L+

links with bounded capacity, which are guaranteed to +L+

deliver messages at only a given rate. If a processor sends messages at a greater rate, they may incur +L+

greater delay. +L+

We quantify the effect of this bounded capacity on +L+

the time necessary to detect processor failures. We +L+

consider a system of two processors connected by a +L+

bi-directional message link of (integral) capacity . +L+

First we give two very simple protocols that guarantee any stopping failure will be detected within +L+

time 2Cd + d and C 2 d= + Cd + d respectively, +L+

where C = c 2 =c 1 . The main result is an almost-matching lower bound of 2Cd+d= or C 2 d=+Cd+d, +L+

whichever is less. If the link is uni-directional, our result specializes to give a matching upper and lower +L+

bound of C 2 d= + Cd + d. +L+ </abstract>

<note> Supported by an NSF Graduate Fellowship +L+ </note>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Electronic Lottery Tickets as Micropayments +L+ </title>

<author> Ronald L. Rivest +L+ </author>

<affiliation> MIT Lab for Computer Science +L+

(RSA / Security Dynamics) +L+ </affiliation>

<email> rivest@theory.lcs.mit.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract. We present a new micropayment scheme based on the use of +L+

"electronic lottery tickets." This scheme is exceptionally efficient since +L+

the bank handles only winning tickets, instead of handling each micro +L+

payment. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> The Design and Implementation of SOLAR, +L+

a Portable Library for Scalable Out-of-Core Linear Algebra Computations +L+ </title>

<author> Sivan Toledo Fred G. Gustavson +L+ </author>

<affiliation> IBM T.J. Watson Research Center +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

SOLAR is a portable high-performance library for out-of-core dense +L+

matrix computations. It combines portability with high performance +L+

by using existing high-performance in-core subroutine libraries and +L+

by using an optimized matrix input-output library. SOLAR works on +L+

parallel computers, workstations, and personal computers. It supports +L+

in-core computations on both shared-memory and distributed-memory +L+

machines, and its matrix input-output library supports both conventional I/O interfaces and parallel I/O interfaces. This paper discusses +L+

the overall design of SOLAR, its interfaces, and the design of several +L+

important subroutines. Experimental results show that SOLAR can +L+

factor on a single workstation an out-of-core positive-definite symmetric matrix at a rate exceeding 215 Mflops, and an out-of-core general +L+

matrix at a rate exceeding 195 Mflops. Less than 16% of the running +L+

time is spent on I/O in these computations. These results indicate +L+

that SOLAR's portability does not compromise its performance. We +L+

expect that the combination of portability, modularity, and the use of +L+

a high-level I/O interface will make the library an important platform +L+

for research on out-of-core algorithms and on parallel I/O. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Compiler Technology for Portable Checkpoints +L+ </title>

<author> Volker Strumpen  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Laboratory for Computer Science +L+

Massachusetts Institute of Technology +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Cambridge, MA 02139 +L+ </address>

<email> strumpen@theory.lcs.mit.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We have implemented a prototype compiler called porch that transforms C programs into C programs supporting portable checkpoints. Portable checkpoints capture the state of a computation in +L+

a machine-independent format that allows the transfer of computations across binary incompatible machines. We introduce source-to-source compilation techniques for generating code to save and +L+

recover from such portable checkpoints automatically. These techniques instrument a program with code that maps the state of a computation into a machine-independent representation and vice versa. +L+

In particular, the following problems are addressed: (1) providing +L+

stack environment portability, (2) enabling conversion of complex +L+

data types, and (3) rendering pointers portable. Experimental results show that the overhead of checkpointing is reasonably small, +L+

even if data representation conversion is required for portability. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Regression shrinkage and selection via the lasso +L+ </title>

<author> Robert Tibshirani  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Statistics +L+

and +L+

Division of Biostatistics +L+

Stanford University +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We propose a new method for estimation in linear models. The "lasso" +L+

minimizes the residual sum of squares subject to the sum of the absolute +L+

value of the coefficients being less than a constant. Because of the nature +L+

of this constraint it tends to produce some coefficients that are exactly zero +L+

and hence gives interpretable models. Our simulation studies suggest that +L+

the lasso enjoys some of the favourable properties of both subset selection +L+

and ridge regression. It produces interpretable models like subset selection +L+

and exhibits the stability of ridge regression. There is also an interesting +L+

relationship with recent work in adaptive function estimation by Donoho +L+

and Johnstone. The lasso idea is quite general and can be applied in a +L+

variety of statistical models: extensions to generalized regression models +L+

and tree-based models are briefly described. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: regression, subset selection, shrinkage, quadratic programming. +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Task Driven Perceptual Organization for Extraction of Rooftop +L+

Polygons  +L+ </title>

<author> Christopher Jaynes Frank Stolle Robert Collins +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department +L+

University of Massachusetts +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Amherst, MA 01003 +L+ </address>

<email> Email: @cs.umass.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

A new method for extracting planar polygonal rooftops in monocular aerial imagery is proposed. Through bottom-up and top-down construction of perceptual groups, polygons in a +L+

single aerial image can be robustly extracted. +L+

Orthogonal corners and lines are extracted and +L+

hierarchically related using perceptual grouping techniques. Top-down feature verification is +L+

used so that features, and links between the features, are verified with local information in the +L+

image and weighed in a graph structure according to the underlying support for each feature. +L+

Cycles in the graph correspond to possible +L+

building rooftop hypotheses. Virtual features +L+

are hypothesized for the perceptual completion +L+

of partial rooftops. Extraction of the "best" +L+

grouping of features into a building rooftop hypothesis is posed as a graph search problem. +L+

The maximally weighted, independent set of cycles in the graph is extracted as the final set of +L+

roof boundaries. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1. Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<pubnum> M.I.T Media Laboratory Perceptual Computing Section Technical Report No. 368 +L+ </pubnum>

<note> Appears in: Fourth European Conference on Computer Vision, Cambridge, UK, April 1996. +L+ </note>

<title> Generalized Image Matching: +L+

Statistical Learning of Physically-Based Deformations +L+ </title>

<author> Chahab Nastar, Baback Moghaddam and Alex Pentland +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Perceptual Computing Section, The Media Laboratory, +L+

Massachusetts Institute of Technology +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 20 Ames Street, Cambridge MA 02139, U.S.A. +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We describe a novel approach for image matching +L+

based on deformable intensity surfaces. In this +L+

approach, the intensity surface of the image +L+

is modeled as a deformable 3D mesh in the +L+

(x; ; I(x; )) space. Each surface point has 3 +L+

degrees of freedom, thus capturing fine surface +L+

changes. A set of representative deformations +L+

within a class of objects (e.g. faces) are statistically learned through a Principal Components Analysis, thus providing a priori knowledge +L+

about object-specific deformations. We demonstrate the power of the approach by examples +L+

such as image matching and interpolation of +L+

missing data. Moreover this approach dramatically reduces the computational cost of solving +L+

the governing equation for the physically based +L+

system by approximately three orders of magni +L+

tude. +L+
 </abstract>
<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Determining 3-D Hand Motion +L+ </title>

<author> James Davis Mubarak Shah +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Media Lab Computer Vision Lab +L+

Massachusetts Institute of Technology University of Central Florida +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Cambridge, MA 02139 Orlando, FL 32826 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper presents a glove-free method for tracking +L+

hand movements using a set of 3-D models. In this +L+

approach, the hand is represented by five cylindrical +L+

models which are fit to the third phalangeal segments +L+

of the fingers. Six 3-D motion parameters for each +L+

model are calculated that correspond to the movement +L+

of the fingertips in the image plane. Trajectories of +L+

the moving models are then established to show the 3-D nature of hand motion. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Optimal Algorithms for Substrate Testing +L+

in Multi-Chip Modules  +L+ </title>

<author> Andrew B. Kahng, Gabriel Robins and Elizabeth A. Walkup  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science, UCLA, </affiliation> <address> Los Angeles, CA 90024-1596 </address> +L+

<affiliation> y Department of Computer Science, </affiliation> <address> University of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA, 22903-2442 +L+ </address>

<affiliation> z Department of Computer Science, </affiliation> <address> University of Washington, Seattle, WA 98195 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Multi-chip module (MCM) packaging techniques present several new technical challenges, notably substrate testing. We formulate MCM substrate testing as a problem of connectivity verification in trees via k-probes, and present a linear-time algorithm which computes a minimum +L+

set of probes achieving complete open fault coverage. Since actual substrate testing also involves +L+

scheduling probe operations, we formulate efficient probe scheduling as a special type of metric +L+

traveling salesman optimization and give a provably-good heuristic. Empirical results using both +L+

random and industry benchmarks demonstrate reductions in testing costs of up to 21% over previous methods. We conclude with generalizations to alternate probe technologies and several open +L+

problems. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Key words: MCMs, testing, graph algorithms, fault detection, circuit probing, TSP. +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Efficient Gate Delay Modeling for Large Interconnect Loads +L+ </title>

<author> Andrew B. Kahng and Sudhakar Muddu +L+ </author>

<affiliation> UCLA Computer Science Department, </affiliation> <address> Los Angeles, CA 90095-1596 USA +L+ </address>

<email> abk@cs.ucla.edu, sudhakar@cs.ucla.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

With fast switching speeds and large interconnect trees (MCMs), the +L+

resistance and inductance of interconnect has a dominant impact on +L+

logic gate delay. In this paper, we propose a new P model for distributed RC and RLC interconnects to estimate the driving point admittance at the output of a CMOS gate. Using this model we are able to +L+

compute the gate delay efficiently, within 25% of SPICE-computed delays. Our parameters depend only on total interconnect tree resistance +L+

and capacitance at the output of the gate. Previous effective load capacitance methods [7, 9], applicable only for distributed RC interconnects, are based on P model parameters obtained via a recursive admittance moment computation. Our model should be useful for iterative +L+

optimization of performance-driven routing or for estimation of gate +L+

delay and rise times in high-level synthesis. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: gate delay, reduced-order models, driving point admittance, +L+

effective capacitance, interconnect modeling +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Gate Load Delay Computation Using Analytical Models +L+ </title>

<author> Andrew B. Kahng Sudhakar Muddu +L+ </author>

<affiliation> UCLA Computer Science Department Silicon Graphics, Inc. +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Los Angeles, CA 90095-1596 USA Mountain View, CA 94039 USA +L+ </address>

<email> abk@cs.ucla.edu muddu@mti.sgi.com +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

With submicron technologies, gate delays are dominated by gate +L+

load delays rather than intrinsic gate delays. While the common approach for computing gate load delay (or total gate delay) is through +L+

delay tables (or k-factor equations), there are important methodology problems associated with the delay table approach. In this paper, we propose a gate driver model with a Thevenin equivalent circuit consisting of a ramp voltage source whose slew time is obtained +L+

from the gate slew tables, and a driver resistance in series with the +L+

gate load. We then develop analytical gate delay formulas using this +L+

Thevenin driver model and modeling the load with various gate load +L+

models under both rising and falling ramp input. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Robust IP Watermarking Methodologies for Physical Design +L+ </title>

<author> Andrew B. Kahng, Stefanus Mantik, Igor L. Markov, Miodrag Potkonjak, +L+

Paul Tucker , Huijuan Wang and Gregory Wolfe +L+ </author>

<affiliation> UCLA Computer Science Dept., </affiliation> <address> Los Angeles, CA 90095-1596 +L+ </address>

<affiliation> UCSD Computer Science & Engineering Dept., </affiliation> <address> La Jolla, CA 92093-0114 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Increasingly popular reuse-based design paradigms create a pressing need for authorship enforcement techniques that protect the intellectual property rights of designers. We develop the first intellectual property protection protocols for embedding design watermarks at the physical design level. We demonstrate that these protocols are transparent with respect to existing industrial tools and +L+

design flows, and that they can embed watermarks into real-world +L+

industrial designs with very low implementation overhead (as measured by such standard metrics as wirelength, layout area, number +L+

of vias, routing congestion and CPU time). On several industrial +L+

test cases, we obtain extremely strong, tamper-resistant proofs of +L+

authorship for placement and routing solutions. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Concurrency and Recovery in Generalized Search Trees +L+ </title>

<author> Marcel Kornacker  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> U. C. Berkeley +L+ </affiliation>

<web>  http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/ +L+ 

marcel +L+ </web>

<email> marcel@cs.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<author> C. Mohan +L+ </author>

<affiliation> IBM Research Division +L+ </affiliation>

<web>  http://www.almaden.ibm.com/ +L+ 

cs/people/mohan +L+ </web>

<email> mohan@almaden.ibm.com +L+ </email>

<author> Joseph M. Hellerstein +L+ </author>

<affiliation> U. C. Berkeley +L+ </affiliation>

<web>  http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/ +L+ 

jmh +L+ </web>

<email> jmh@cs.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper presents general algorithms for concurrency control in +L+

tree-based access methods as well as a recovery protocol and a +L+

mechanism for ensuring repeatable read. The algorithms are developed in the context of the Generalized Search Tree (GiST) data +L+

structure, an index structure supporting an extensible set of queries +L+

and data types. Although developed in a GiST context, the algorithms are generally applicable to many tree-based access methods. +L+

The concurrency control protocol is based on an extension of the +L+

link technique originally developed for B-trees, and completely +L+

avoids holding node locks during I/Os. Repeatable read isolation is +L+

achieved with a novel combination of predicate locks and two-phase +L+

locking of data records. To our knowledge, this is the first time that +L+

isolation issues have been addressed outside the context of B-trees. +L+

A discussion of the fundamental structural differences between B-trees and more general tree structures like GiSTs explains why the +L+

algorithms developed here deviate from their B-tree counterparts. +L+

An implementation of GiSTs emulating B-trees in DB2/Common +L+

Server is underway. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Quick Simulation of ATM Buffers with +L+

On-off Multiclass Markov Fluid Sources 1 +L+ </title>

<author> G. Kesidis +L+ </author>

<affiliation> E & CE Dept, University of Waterloo, </affiliation> <address> Waterloo, Ontario, N2L 3G1, Canada. +L+ </address>

<author> J. Walrand +L+ </author>

<affiliation> EECS Dept, University of California, </affiliation> <address> Berkeley, CA94720. +L+ </address>

<note> ACM TOMACS, Vol. 3, No. 3, pp. 269-276, July, 1993. +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The problem we address is how to quickly estimate by simulation the loss in a +L+

buffer with multiclass on-off Markov fluid sources. We generate the Markov fluids +L+

with the altered rate matrices given in [11], instead of the originals, to speed up +L+

the simulation. Likelihood ratios are used to recover an estimate of the loss for the +L+

original traffic parameters. +L+ </abstract>

<title> Inferring Reduced Ordered Decision Graphs of Minimal Description +L+

Length +L+ </title>

<author> Arlindo L. Oliveira  +L+

Alberto Sangiovanni-Vincentelli +L+ </author>

<note> Kluwer Academic Publishers, Boston. Manufactured in The Netherlands. </note> +L+

<title> A Method for Automatic Design Error Location and +L+

Correction in Combinational Logic Circuits  +L+ </title>

<author> AYMAN M. WAHBA AND DOMINIQUE BORRIONE +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Modelisation et Preuves de Circuits, TIMA Laboratory, </affiliation> <address> BP 53X, 38041 Grenoble Cedex FRANCE +L+ </address>

<email> Ayman.Wahba@imag.fr, Dominique.Borrione@imag.fr +L+ </email>

<note> Received ??. Revised ??. +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract. We present a new diagnostic algorithm, based on backward-propagation, for localising design +L+

errors in combinational logic circuits. Three hypotheses are considered, that cover all single gate replacement and insertion errors. Diagnosis-oriented test patterns are generated in order to rapidly reduce the +L+

suspected area where the error lies. The originality of our method is the use of patterns which do not +L+

detect the error, in addition to detecting patterns. A theorem shows that, in favourable cases, only two +L+

patterns suffice to get a correction. We have implemented the test generation and diagnosis algorithms. +L+

Results obtained on benchmarks show that the error is always found, after the application of a small +L+

number of test patterns, with an execution time proportional to the circuit size. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: design correctness, design debugging, design error diagnosis +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1. Introduction </intro>

<title> Using Don't Cares in Logic Minimization for +L+

LUT-Based FPGAs +L+ </title>

<author>  Philip Chong  13327872 +L+ </author>

<date> May 25, 1997 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Don't care information has proven to be useful in logic minimization. +L+

Here, the use of don't care information in network collapsing for mapping +L+

to LUT-based FPGAs is explored. Results are shown which indicate that +L+

this approach does not result in appreciable improvements in network size. +L+ </abstract>
