<NEW_HEADER>

<title> An Assume-Guarantee Rule For Checking Simulation +L+ </title>

<author> T.A. Henzinger S. Qadeer S.K. Rajamani S. Ta~sran +L+ </author>

<affiliation> EECS Department, University of California at Berkeley, </affiliation> <address> CA 94720 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The simulation preorder on state transition systems is widely accepted as a +L+

useful notion of refinement, both in its own right and as an efficiently checkable sufficient condition for trace containment. For composite systems, due to +L+

the exponential explosion of the state space, there is a need for decomposing a +L+

simulation check of the form P s Q into simpler simulation checks on the components of P and Q. We present an assume-guarantee rule that enables such a +L+

decomposition. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first assume-guarantee +L+

rule that applies to a refinement relation different from trace containment. Our +L+

rule is circular, and its soundness proof requires induction on trace-trees. The +L+

proof is constructive: given simulation relations that witness the simulation +L+

preorder between components, we provide a procedure for constructing a witness relation for P s Q. We also extend our assume-guarantee rule to account +L+

for fairness assumptions on transition systems. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> Submitted to ACM SIGCOMM '98 +L+ </note>

<title> Modeling TCP Throughput: A Simple Model and its Empirical Validation  +L+ </title>

<author> Jitendra Padhye Victor Firoiu Don Towsley Jim Kurose +L+ </author>

<email> jitu@cs.umass.edu vfiroiu@cs.umass.edu towsley@cs.umass.edu kurose@cs.umass.edu +L+ </email>

<phone> 1-413-545-2447 1-413-545-3179 1-413-545-0207 1-413-545-1585 +L+ </phone>

<affiliation>  Department of Computer Science +L+ 

University of Massachusetts +L+ </affiliation>

<address> LGRC, Box 34610 +L+

Amherst, MA 01003-4610 USA +L+ </address>

<date> May 29, 1998 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

In this paper we develop a simple analytic characterization of the steady state throughput, as a function of loss rate and round trip time for a bulk transfer TCP flow, i.e., a flow with an unlimited amount +L+

of data to send. Unlike the models in [6, 7, 10], our model captures not only the behavior of TCP's fast +L+

retransmit mechanism (which is also considered in [6, 7, 10]) but also the effect of TCP's timeout mechanism on throughput. Our measurements suggest that this latter behavior is important from a modeling +L+

perspective, as almost all of our TCP traces contained more timeout events than fast retransmit events. +L+

Our measurements demonstrate that our model is able to more accurately predict TCP throughput and is +L+

accurate over a wider range of loss rates. +L+

This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under grants NCR-95-08274, NCR-95-23807 +L+

and CDA-95-02639. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this material are those of the authors +L+

and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation. +L+ </abstract>

<note> Corresponding Author +L+ </note>

<web> http://www.cs.umass.edu/~vfiroiu/ +L+ </web>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Exotica/FMQM: A Persistent +L+

Message-Based Architecture for +L+

Distributed Workflow Management +L+ </title>

<author> G. Alonso, C. Mohan, R. Gunthor +L+ </author>

<affiliation> IBM Almaden Research Center +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 650 Harry Road, San Jose, CA 95120, USA. +L+ </address>

<email> E-mail: fgustavoa,rgunther,mohang@almaden.ibm.com +L+ </email>

<author> D. Agrawal, A. El Abbadi +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department, UC Santa Barbara, +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Santa Barbara, CA 93106, USA. +L+ </address>

<email> E-mail: fagrawal,amrg@cs.ucsb.edu +L+ </email>

<author> M. Kamath +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department, UM at Amherst, +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Amherst, MA 01003, USA. +L+ </address>

<email> E-mail: kamath@cs.umass.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

In the past few years there has been an increasing interest in workflow applications as a +L+

way of supporting complex business processes in modern corporations. Given the nature +L+

of the environment and the technology involved, workflow applications are inherently +L+

distributed and pose many interesting challenges to the system designer. In most cases, a +L+

client/server architecture is used in which knowledge about the processes being executed is +L+

centralized in one node to facilitate monitoring, auditing, and to simplify synchronization. +L+

In this paper, we explore a novel distributed architecture, Exotica/FMQM, for workflow +L+

systems in which the need for such a centralized database is eliminated. Instead, we use +L+

persistent messages as the means to store the information relevant to the execution of a +L+

business process. Our approach is to completely distribute the execution of a process so +L+

individual nodes are independent. The advantages of this approach are increased resilience +L+

to failures and greater scalability and flexibility of the system configuration. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords +L+

Workflow Management Systems, Distributed Systems, reliability, scalability. +L+ </keyword>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Use of Architecture-Altering Operations to Dynamically +L+

Adapt a Three-Way Analog Source Identification Circuit to +L+

Accommodate a New Source +L+ </title>

<author> John R. Koza +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Dept. +L+

Stanford University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Stanford, California 94305-9020 +L+ </address>

<email> koza@cs.stanford.edu +L+ </email>

<web> http://www-cs +L+

faculty.stanford.edu/~koza/ +L+ </web>

<author> Forrest H Bennett III +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Visiting Scholar +L+

Computer Science Dept. +L+

Stanford University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Stanford, California 94305 +L+ </address>

<email> forrest@evolute.com +L+ </email>

<author> Jason Lohn +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Visiting Scholar +L+

Computer Science Dept. +L+

Stanford University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Stanford, California 94305 +L+ </address>

<email> jlohn7@leland.stanford.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Frank Dunlap +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dunlap Consulting +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Palo Alto, California +L+ </address>

<author> Martin A. Keane +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Martin Keane Inc. +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 5733 West Grover +L+

Chicago, Illinois 60630 +L+ </address>

<email> makeane@ix.netcom.com +L+ </email>

<author> David Andre +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Division +L+

University of California +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Berkeley, California +L+ </address>

<email> dandre@cs.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

The problem of source +L+

identification involves correctly +L+

classifying an incoming signal into +L+

a category that identifies the +L+

signal's source. +L+

The problem is difficult because +L+

information is not provided +L+

distinguishing characteristics and +L+

because successive signals from the +L+

same source differ. The source +L+

identification problem can be made +L+

more difficult by dynamically +L+

changing the repertoire of sources +L+

while the problem is being solved. +L+

We used genetic programming to +L+

evolve both the topology and the +L+

sizing (numerical values) for each +L+

component of an analog electrical +L+

circuit that can correctly classify an +L+

incoming analog electrical signal +L+

into three categories. Then, the +L+

repertoire of sources was +L+

dynamically changed by adding a +L+

new source during the run. The +L+

paper describe show the +L+

enabled genetic programming to +L+

adapt, during the run, to the +L+

changed environment. Specifically, +L+

a three-way source identification +L+

circuit was evolved and then +L+

adapted into a four-way classifier, +L+

during the run, thereby successfully +L+

handling the additional new source. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1. Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Planar-Adaptive Routing: Low-cost Adaptive Networks for +L+

Multiprocessors +L+ </title>

<author> Andrew A. Chien and Jae H. Kim +L+ </author>

<email> achien@cs.uiuc.edu kim@cs.uiuc.edu +L+ </email>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 1304 W. Springfield Avenue +L+

Urbana, IL 61801 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Network throughput can be increased by allowing mul-tipath, adaptive routing. Adaptive routing allows more +L+

freedom in the paths taken by messages, spreading load +L+

over physical channels more evenly. The flexibility of +L+

adaptive routing introduces new possibilities of deadlock. Previous deadlock avoidance schemes in k-ary n-cubes require an exponential number of virtual channels +L+

[17]. We describe a family of deadlock-free routing algorithms, called planar-adaptive routing algorithms which +L+

require only a constant number of virtual channels, independent of network size and dimension. Planar-adaptive +L+

routing algorithms reduce the complexity of deadlock +L+

prevention by reducing the number of choices at each +L+

routing step. In the fault-free case, planar-adaptive +L+

networks are guaranteed to be deadlock-free. In the +L+

presence of network faults, the planar-adaptive router +L+

can be extended with misrouting to produce a working network which remains provably deadlock free and +L+

is provably livelock free. In addition, planar adaptive +L+

networks can simultaneously support both in-order and +L+

adaptive, out-of-order packet delivery. +L+

Planar-adaptive routing is of practical significance. It +L+

provides the simplest known support for deadlock-free +L+

adaptive routing in k-ary n-cubes of more than two +L+

dimensions (with k &gt; 2). Restricting adaptivity reduces the hardware complexity, improving router speed +L+

or allowing additional performance-enhancing network +L+

features. The structure of planar-adaptive routers is +L+

amenable to efficient implementation. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: Multicomputers, Routing Networks, Adaptive Routing, Deadlock Avoidance, Transmission-Order +L+

Preservation, Fault Tolerance +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Learning to Retrieve Information +L+ </title>

<author> Brian Bartell +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Encylopdia Britannica and +L+

Institute for Neural Computation +L+

Computer Science & Engineering +L+

University of California, San Diego +L+ </affiliation>

<address> La Jolla, California 92093 +L+ </address>

<author> Garrison W. Cottrell  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Institute for Neural Computation +L+

Computer Science & Engineering +L+

University of California, San Diego +L+ </affiliation>

<address> La Jolla, California 92093 +L+ </address>

<author> Rik Belew +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Institute for Neural Computation +L+

Computer Science & Engineering +L+

University of California, San Diego +L+ </affiliation>

<address> La Jolla, California 92093 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Information retrieval differs significantly from function approximation in that the goal is for the system to achieve the same ranking +L+

function of documents relative to queries as the user: the outputs of +L+

the system relative to one another must be in the proper order. We +L+

hypothesize that a particular rank-order statistic, Guttman's point +L+

alienation, is the proper objective function for such a system, and +L+

demonstrate its efficacy by using it to find the optimal combination +L+

of retrieval experts. In application to a commercial retrieval system, +L+

the combination performs 47% better than any single expert. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Segregating Planners and Their Environments +L+ </title>

<author> Scott D. Anderson +L+

Paul R. Cohen +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Experimental Knowledge Systems Laboratory +L+

Computer Science Department, LGRC +L+

University of Massachusetts +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Amherst MA 01003-4610 +L+ </address>

<email> fanderson,coheng@cs.umass.edu +L+ </email>

<note> To be published in the proceedings of the +L+

Spring Symposium on Integrated Planning Applications +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

By implementing agents and environments using a domain-independent, extensible simulation substrate, described in this +L+

paper, agents will have clean interfaces to +L+

their environments. These makes it easier +L+

for agents to be plugged into other environments that have been similarly defined. If +L+

agents can interact with multiple environments, their behaviors and the associated +L+

experimental results will be more general +L+

and interesting. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Higher Bandwidth X +L+ </title>

<note> (Extended Abstract) +L+

Submitted to ACM MULTIMEDIA '94 +L+ </note>

<author> John Danskin  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Princeton University +L+

Computer Science Department +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Princeton NJ, 08540 +L+ </address>

<email> jmd@cs.princeton.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Network bandwidth has always been a key issue for multimedia protocols. Many potential users of networked multimedia protocols will continue to have low bandwidth network +L+

connections for some time: copper wire ISDN, infra-red, cellular modems, etc.. Compression provides potential relief for users of slow networks by increasing effective bandwidth. +L+

HBX introduces a new technique, based on arithmetic coding and statistical modeling, for +L+

compressing structured data. Applied to the X networked graphics protocol, this technique +L+

yields 4.5:1 compression across a representative set of traces, performing twice as well as the +L+

popular LZW-based Xremote compression protocol. HBX's coding techniques are generally +L+

applicable to the graphics and imaging subset of multimedia protocols. Future work will +L+

determine whether HBX's coding techniques can be applied to audio and video streams as +L+

well. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Fast Volume Rendering Using a Shear-Warp Factorization +L+

of the Viewing Transformation +L+ </title>

<author> Philippe Lacroute +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Systems Laboratory +L+

Stanford University +L+ </affiliation>

<author> Marc Levoy +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department +L+

Stanford University +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Several existing volume rendering algorithms operate by factoring the viewing transformation into a 3D shear parallel to the data +L+

slices, a projection to form an intermediate but distorted image, +L+

and a 2D warp to form an undistorted final image. We extend +L+

this class of algorithms in three ways. First, we describe a new +L+

object-order rendering algorithm based on the factorization that is +L+

significantly faster than published algorithms with minimal loss +L+

of image quality. Shear-warp factorizations have the property that +L+

rows of voxels in the volume are aligned with rows of pixels in the +L+

intermediate image. We use this fact to construct a scanline-based +L+

algorithm that traverses the volume and the intermediate image in +L+

synchrony, taking advantage of the spatial coherence present in +L+

both. We use spatial data structures based on run-length encoding +L+

for both the volume and the intermediate image. Our implementation running on an SGI Indigo workstation renders a 256 3 voxel +L+

medical data set in one second. Our second extension is a shear-warp factorization for perspective viewing transformations, and +L+

we show how our rendering algorithm can support this extension. +L+

Third, we introduce a data structure for encoding spatial coherence +L+

in unclassified volumes (i.e. scalar fields with no precomputed +L+

opacity). When combined with our shear-warp rendering algorithm this data structure allows us to classify and render a 256 3 +L+

voxel volume in three seconds. The method extends to support +L+

mixed volumes and geometry and is parallelizable. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> CR Categories: I.3.7 [Computer Graphics]: Three-Dimensional +L+

Graphics and Realism; I.3.3 [Computer Graphics]: Picture/Image +L+

Generation|Display Algorithms. +L+

Additional Keywords: Volume rendering, Coherence, Scientific +L+

visualization, Medical imaging. +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<author> David Laur and Pat Hanrahan +L+ </author>

<affiliation>  Princeton University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Princeton, NJ 08544, USA +L+ </address> 

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper presents a progressive refinement algorithm for +L+

volume rendering which uses a pyramidal volume representation. Besides storing average values, the pyramid stores +L+

estimated error, so an oct-tree can be fit to the pyramid +L+

given a user-supplied precision. This oct-tree is then drawn +L+

using a set of splats, or footprints, each scaled to match the +L+

size of the projection of a cell. The splats themselves are approximated with RGBA Gouraud-shaded polygons, so that +L+

they can be drawn efficiently on modern graphics workstations. The result is a real-time rendering algorithm suitable +L+

for interactive applications. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> CR Categories and Subject Descriptors: I.3.7 [Computer Graphics]: Three-Dimensional Graphics and Realism. +L+

Key Words: volume rendering, coherence, progressive refinement, interactive techniques. +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Compression Performance of the Xremote Protocol +L+ </title>

<author> John Danskin Pat Hanrahan +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science, Princeton University +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The Xremote protocol is a compressed transformation of the X Window System protocol, +L+

designed to efficiently implement X connections across relatively slow serial lines. Using an +L+

Xremote simulator and 11 traces of X sessions, we found that Xremote's overall compression +L+

ratio is 2.4:1. This figure varies widely depending on the trace. A study of compression +L+

ratio as a function of message type shows text based messages commonly achieving 3:1 +L+

compression, while geometric messages usually achieve only 1.6:1 compression. By examining bandwidth requirements and compression performance as a function of time, we see +L+

that Xremote performs adequately for some applications which are text based or which use +L+

small geometric datasets, except at application startup where more bandwidth is required. +L+

Further work is required to adequately support the initialization stage of X applications and +L+

medium to large geometric databases. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Robust Meshes from Multiple Range Maps +L+ </title>

<author> Kari Pulli Tom Duchamp Hugues Hoppe  +L+

John McDonald Linda Shapiro Werner Stuetzle  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> University of Washington, </affiliation> <address> Seattle, WA +L+ </address>

<affiliation> Microsoft Research, </affiliation> <address> Redmond, WA +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper presents a method for modeling the surface +L+

of an object from a sequence of range maps. Our method +L+

is based on a volumetric approach that produces a compact +L+

surface without boundary. It provides robustness through +L+

the use of interval analysis techniques and computational +L+

efficiency through hierarchical processing using octrees. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1. Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Constraint Satisfaction Problem as a Causal Theory +L+ </title>

<author> Robert Rodosek +L+ </author>

<affiliation> University of Munich, Department of Computer Science +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Theresienstrae 39, 80333 Munich, Germany +L+ </address>

<email> rodosek@informatik.uni-muenchen.de +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The aim of this paper is to identify and to characterize the features that render one class +L+

of the Constraint Satisfaction Problem (CSP) computationally more efficient. Our approach +L+

is to search for a causal structure not only in the topology of the subsets of variables upon +L+

which the constraints are specified, but also in the nature of the constraints. Basically, there +L+

should exist an ordering of variables in the system such that an assignment of the variables +L+

can be reached without backtracking. First, an approach of a causal structure is formulated, +L+

and second, an efficient procedure is provided (i) for deciding if such an ordering of variables +L+

exists and, (ii) for identifying such an ordering whenever possible. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Dis-equality Constraints in Linear/Integer +L+

Programming +L+ </title>

<author> Mozafar T. Hajian +L+ </author>

<affiliation> IC-Parc, William Penny Laboratory, Imperial College, </affiliation><address>  London, SW7 2AZ. +L+ </address>

<email> mh10@doc.ic.ac.uk +L+ </email>

<date> June 21, 1996 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We have proposed an extension to the definition of general integer linear programs (ILP) to accept dis-equality constraints explicitly. A new class of logical +L+

variables is introduced to transform the extended ILP in general form to standard +L+

form. Branch and Bound algorithm is modified to solve this new class of ILP. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: Mathematical Modelling, Linear/Integer Programming, Algorithms, +L+

Branch and Bound, Dis-equality Constraints. +L+ </keyword>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> THE AUTOMATED HIGHWAY SYSTEM: A TRANSPORTATION +L+

TECHNOLOGY FOR THE 21ST CENTURY +L+ </title>

<author> M. Broucke and P. Varaiya 1 +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science +L+

University of California, </affiliation> <address> Berkeley CA 94720 +L+ </address>

<email> mire, varaiya@eclair.eecs.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract. The current vehicle-highway system has reached a plateau in its ability +L+

to meet the demand for moving goods and people. We sketch an architecture for +L+

an automated highway system or AHS. The architecture can be realized by several +L+

designs that differ in terms of performance and sophistication. We describe one design +L+

that could triple capacity and reduce travel time; guarantee collision-free operation +L+

in the absence of malfunctions; limit performance degradation in the case of faults; +L+

and reduce emissions by half. We summarize evidence suggesting that the design can +L+

be implemented. We indicate how the design can be adapted to different urban and +L+

rural scenarios and how a standard land use model can show the impact of AHS on +L+

urban density. We conclude with a critique of AHS. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords. Automated vehicles, hierarchical control +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1. INTRODUCTION </intro>

<title> A Parallel Implementation of an MPEG1 Encoder: +L+

Faster Than Real-Time! +L+ </title>

<author> Ke Shen , Lawrence A. Rowe and Edward J. Delp  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Vision and Image Processing Laboratory +L+

School of Electrical Engineering +L+

Purdue University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> West Lafayette, Indiana +L+ </address>

<affiliation> Computer Science Division +L+

Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science +L+

University of California +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Berkeley, California +L+ </address>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

In this paper we present an implementation of an MPEG1 encoder on the Intel Touchstone Delta and Intel +L+

Paragon parallel computers. We describe the unique aspects of mapping the algorithm onto the parallel +L+

machines and present several versions of the algorithms. We will show that I/O contention can be a bottleneck +L+

relative to performance. We will also describe how the Touchstone Delta and Paragon can be used to compress +L+

video sequences faster than real-time. +L+ </abstract>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Kin Recognition, Similarity, and Group Behavior +L+ </title>

<author> Maja J Mataric +L+ </author>

<affiliation> MIT Artificial Intelligence Laboratory +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 545 Technology Square #721 +L+

Cambridge, MA 02139 +L+ </address>

<phone> phone: (617) 253-8839 +L+ </phone>

<phone> fax: (617) 253-0039 +L+ </phone>

<email> maja@ai.mit.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper presents an approach to describing +L+

group behavior using simple local interactions +L+

among individuals. We propose that for a given +L+

domain a set of basic interactions can be defined +L+

which describes a large variety of group behaviors. +L+

The methodology we present allows for simplified +L+

qualitative analysis of group behavior through the +L+

use of shared goals, kin recognition, and minimal +L+

communication. We also demonstrate how these +L+

basic interactions can be simply combined into +L+

more complex compound group behaviors. +L+

To validate our approach we implemented an array of basic group behaviors in the domain of spatial interactions among homogeneous agents. We +L+

describe some of the experimental results from two +L+

distinct domains: a software environment, and a +L+

collection of 20 mobile robots. We also describe +L+

a compound behavior involving a combination of +L+

the basic interactions. Finally, we compare the +L+

performance of homogeneous groups to those of +L+

dominance hierarchies on the same set of basic behaviors. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Structuring Graphical Paradigms in TkGofer +L+ </title>

<author> Koen Claessen +L+ </author>

<affiliation> OGI and Utrecht University +L+ </affiliation>

<email> koen@cse.ogi.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Ton Vullinghs +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Universitat Ulm +L+ </affiliation>

<email> ton@informatik.uni-ulm.de +L+ </email>

<author> Erik Meijer +L+ </author>

<affiliation> OGI and Utrecht University +L+ </affiliation>

<email> erik@cse.ogi.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

In this paper we describe the implementation of several +L+

graphical programming paradigms (Model View Controller, +L+

Fudgets, and Functional Animations) using the GUI library +L+

TkGofer. This library relies on a combination of monads +L+

and multiple-parameter type classes to provide an abstract, +L+

type safe interface to Tcl/Tk. We show how choosing the +L+

right abstractions makes the given implementations surprisingly concise and easy to understand. +L+ </abstract>

<title> REWRITING METHODS +L+

FOR WORD PROBLEMS  +L+ </title>

<author> NACHUM DERSHOWITZ +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 1304 West Springfield Ave., Urbana, IL 61801-2987, U.S.A. +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper outlines various recent approaches to solving word problems. +L+

Term orderings are used to define a terminating rewrite relation. When confluent, that relation defines unique normal forms that can be used to decide word +L+

problems. Some results obtained by these methods are summarized. +L+ </abstract>

<title> Disk Packings and Planar Separators +L+ </title>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We demonstrate that the geometric separator algorithm of Miller, Teng, Thurston, and Vavasis finds a +L+

3=4-separator of size 1:84 +L+

p +L+

n for every n node planar +L+

graph. Our bound is derived from an analysis of disk +L+

packings on the sphere. +L+ </abstract>

<title> THE PRACTICAL VALUE OF N-GRAMS IN +L+

GENERATION +L+ </title>

University of Southern California +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Marina del Rey, CA 90292 +L+ </address>

<email> ilangkil@isi.edu and knight@isi.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We examine the practical synergy between symbolic and statistical language processing in a generator +L+

called Nitrogen. The analysis provides insight into the kinds of linguistic decisions that bigram frequency +L+

statistics can make, and how it improves scalability. We also discuss the limits of bigram statistical +L+

knowledge. We focus on specific examples of Nitrogen's output. +L+ </abstract>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Building Interpreters by Composing Monads +L+ </title>

<author> Guy L. Steele Jr. +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Thinking Machines Corporation +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 245 First Street +L+

Cambridge, Massachusetts 02142 +L+ </address>

<phone> (617) 234-2860 +L+ </phone>

<email> gls@think.com +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract: We exhibit a set of functions coded in +L+

Haskell that can be used as building blocks to construct +L+

a variety of interpreters for Lisp-like languages. The +L+

building blocks are joined merely through functional +L+

composition. Each building block contributes code to +L+

support a specific feature, such as numbers, continuations, functions calls, or nondeterminism. The result of +L+

composing some number of building blocks is a parser, +L+

an interpreter, and a printer that support exactly the +L+

expression forms and data types needed for the combined set of features, and no more. +L+

The data structures are organized as pseudomonads, +L+

a generalization of monads that allows composition. +L+

Functional composition of the building blocks implies +L+

type composition of the relevant pseudomonads. +L+

Our intent was that the Haskell type resolution system ought to be able to deduce the approprate data +L+

types automatically. Unfortunately there is a deficiency +L+

in current Haskell implementations related to recursive +L+

data types: circularity must be reflected statically in the +L+

type definitions. +L+

We circumvent this restriction by applying a purpose-built program simplifier that performs partial evaluation +L+

and a certain amount of program algebra. We construct +L+

a wide variety of interpreters in the style of Wadler by +L+

starting with the building blocks and a page of boiler-plate code, writing three lines of code (one to specify the +L+

building blocks and two to (redundantly) specify type +L+

compositions), and then applying the simplifier. The +L+

resulting code is acceptable Haskell code. +L+

We have tested a dozen different interpreters with +L+

various combinations of features. In this paper we discuss the overall code structuring strategy, exhibit several building blocks, briefly describe the partial evaluator, and present a number of automatically generated +L+

interpreters. +L+ </abstract>

<note> This is a preprint of a paper that is to appear +L+

in the Proceedings of the Twenty-first Annual ACM +L+

SIGPLAN-SIGACT Symposium on Principles of Programming Languages, January 1994. +L+ </note>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> RESTORATION OF LOSSY COMPRESSED NOISY IMAGES +L+ </title>

<author> Osama K. Al-Shaykh 1 Russell M. Mersereau 2 +L+ </author>

<affiliation> School of Electrical and Computer Engineering +L+

Georgia Institute of Technology +L+ </affiliation>

<email> 1 osamakl@eedsp.gatech.edu +L+ </email>

<email> 2 rmm@eedsp.gatech.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

A restoration algorithm for estimating lossy compressed +L+

images that are corrupted by data-dependent Poisson noise +L+

is presented. The algorithm is based on modeling the image +L+

as a Markov random field (MRF) that penalizes the blocking artifact. The effectiveness of the proposed algorithm is +L+

illustrated using synthetic and real images. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1. INTRODUCTION </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Theory and Design of Multidimensional QMF Sub-Band Filters From +L+

1-D Filters Using Transforms +L+ </title>

<author> I.A. Shah A.A.C. Kalker +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Philips Research Laboratories, +L+ </affiliation>

<address> P.O. Box 80.000, 5600 JA Eindhoven, The Netherlands +L+ </address>

<email> Net: kalker@prl.philips.nl, shah@prl.philips.nl +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The paper presents the general theory of designing +L+

multidimensional Quadrature Mirror Filters (QMF), +L+

for use in sub-band coding (SBC) systems, using the +L+

McClellan transform [1]. It was recently shown that +L+

McClellan transform could be used to generate 2-D +L+

diamond shape QMF filters [2]. In this paper we will +L+

formalize the proofs of the diamond shape case, and +L+

generalize it to other shapes, sampling rasters and +L+

dimensions. Examples are given of two dimensional +L+

diamond shape filters and three dimensional tetrad +L+

filters designed using the technique. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Optimal Multiple Description Transform +L+

Coding of Gaussian Vectors +L+ </title>

<author> Vivek K Goyal +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Elec. Eng. & Comp. Sci. +L+

University of California, Berkeley +L+ </affiliation>

<email> v.goyal@ieee.org +L+ </email>

<author> Jelena Kovacevic +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Bell Laboratories +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Murray Hill, NJ +L+ </address>

<email> jelena@bell-labs.com +L+ </email>

<note> Proc. IEEE Data Compression Conference 1998, pp. 388-397. c fl1998 IEEE +L+

Includes minor corrections. +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Multiple description coding (MDC) is source coding for multiple channels +L+

such that a decoder which receives an arbitrary subset of the channels may produce a useful reconstruction. Orchard et al. [1] proposed a transform coding +L+

method for MDC of pairs of independent Gaussian random variables. This paper provides a general framework which extends multiple description transform +L+

coding (MDTC) to any number of variables and expands the set of transforms +L+

which are considered. Analysis of the general case is provided, which can be +L+

used to numerically design optimal MDTC systems. The case of two variables +L+

sent over two channels is analytically optimized in the most general setting +L+

where channel failures need not have equal probability or be independent. It +L+

is shown that when channel failures are equally probable and independent, the +L+

transforms used in [1] are in the optimal set, but many other choices are possible. A cascade structure is presented which facilitates low-complexity design, +L+

coding, and decoding for a system with a large number of variables. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> 16 IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON INFORMATION THEORY, VOL. 44, NO. 1, JANUARY 1998 +L+ </note>

<title> Quantized Overcomplete Expansions in R +L+

N +L+

Analysis, Synthesis, and Algorithms +L+ </title>

<author> Vivek K Goyal, Student Member, IEEE, Martin Vetterli, Fellow, IEEE, +L+

and Nguyen T. Thao, Member, IEEE +L+ </author>

<abstract> Abstract|Coefficient quantization has peculiar qualitative +L+

effects on representations of vectors in R N with respect to +L+

overcomplete sets of vectors. These effects are investigated +L+

in two settings: frame expansions (representations obtained +L+

by forming inner products with each element of the set) +L+

and matching pursuit expansions (approximations obtained +L+

by greedily forming linear combinations). In both cases, +L+

based on the concept of consistency, it is shown that traditional linear reconstruction methods are suboptimal, and +L+

better consistent reconstruction algorithms are given. The +L+

proposed consistent reconstruction algorithms were in each +L+

case implemented, and experimental results are included. +L+

For frame expansions, results are proven to bound distortion as a function of frame redundancy r and quantization +L+

step size for linear, consistent, and optimal reconstruction +L+

methods. Taken together, these suggest that optimal reconstruction methods will yield O(1=r 2 ) MSE, and that consistency is sufficient to insure this asymptotic behavior. A +L+

result on the asymptotic tightness of random frames is also +L+

proven. +L+

Applicability of quantized matching pursuit to lossy vector compression is explored. Experiments demonstrate the +L+

likelihood that a linear reconstruction is inconsistent, the +L+

MSE reduction obtained with a nonlinear (consistent) reconstruction algorithm, and generally competitive performance +L+

at low bit rates. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords| quantization, source coding, frames, matching +L+

pursuit, consistent reconstruction, optimal reconstruction, +L+

overcomplete representations, MSE bounds +L+ </keyword>

<intro> I. Introduction </intro>

<author> Erica Melis 1 and Alan Bundy 2 +L+ </author>

some possible cross-fertilization of planning and proof planning. +L+ </abstract>

<title> The Role of Learning in Autonomous Robots +L+ </title>

<author> Rodney A. Brooks </author> <affiliation> MIT Artificial Intelligence Laboratory </affiliation> <address> 545 Technology Square Cambridge, MA 02139 </address> <email> brooks@ai.mit.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Applications of learning to autonomous +L+

agents (simulated or real) have often been +L+

restricted to learning a mapping from perceived state of the world to the next action +L+

to take. Often this is couched in terms of +L+

learning from no previous knowledge. This +L+

general case for real autonomous robots is +L+

very difficult. In any case, when building a +L+

real robot there is usually a lot of a priori +L+

knowledge (e.g., from the engineering that +L+

went into its design) which doesn't need to +L+

be learned. We describe the behavior-based +L+

approach to autonomous robots, and then examine four classes of learning problems associated with such robots. +L+ </abstract>

<title> Predicting Lifetimes in Dynamically +L+

Allocated Memory +L+ </title>

<author> David A. Cohn +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Adaptive Systems Group +L+

Harlequin, Inc. +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Menlo Park, CA 94025 +L+ </address>

<email> cohn@harlequin.com +L+ </email>

<address> Boulder, CO 80309 +L+ </address>

<email> baveja@cs.colorado.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Predictions of lifetimes of dynamically allocated objects can be used +L+

to improve time and space efficiency of dynamic memory management in computer programs. Barrett and Zorn [1993] used a simple +L+

lifetime predictor and demonstrated this improvement on a variety +L+

of computer programs. In this paper, we use decision trees to do +L+

lifetime prediction on the same programs and show significantly +L+

better prediction. Our method also has the advantage that during +L+

training we can use a large number of features and let the decision +L+

tree automatically choose the relevant subset. +L+ </abstract>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A Perturbation Scheme for Spherical Arrangements +L+

with Application to Molecular Modeling  +L+ </title>

<author> Dan Halperin  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Tel Aviv University +L+ </affiliation>

<author> Christian R. Shelton  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Massachusetts Institute of Technology +L+ </affiliation>

<date> July 31, 1997 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We describe a software package for computing and manipulating the subdivision of a sphere +L+

by a collection of (not necessarily great) circles and for computing the boundary surface of the +L+

union of spheres. We present problems that arise in the implementation of the software and the +L+

solutions that we have found for them. At the core of the paper is a novel perturbation scheme to +L+

overcome degeneracies and precision problems in computing spherical arrangements while using +L+

floating point arithmetic. The scheme is relatively simple, it balances between the efficiency +L+

of computation and the magnitude of the perturbation, and it performs well in practice. We +L+

report and discuss experimental results. Our package is a major component in a larger package +L+

aimed to support geometric queries on molecular models; it is currently employed by chemists +L+

working in `rational drug design.' The spherical subdivisions are used to construct a geometric +L+

model of a molecule where each sphere represents an atom. We also give an overview of the +L+

molecular modeling package and detail additional features and implementation issues. +L+ </abstract>

<note> This work has been supported in part by a grant from Pfizer Central Research. Dan Halperin has also been +L+

supported by an Alon Fellowship, by ESPRIT IV LTR Project No. 21957 (CGAL), and by the Hermann Minkowski +L+ </note>

<affiliation> - Minerva Center for Geometry at Tel Aviv University. +L+ </affiliation>

halperin@math.tau.ac.il. +L+ </email>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Observations on Cognitive Judgments +L+ </title>

<author> David McAllester +L+ </author>

<email> dam@ai.mit.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

It is obvious to anyone familiar with the rules of the game of chess +L+

that a king on an empty board can reach every square. It is true, but +L+

not obvious, that a knight can reach every square. Why is the first +L+

fact obvious but the second fact not? This paper presents an analytic +L+

theory of a class of obviousness judgments of this type. Whether or +L+

not the specifics of this analysis are correct, it seems that the study of +L+

obviousness judgments can be used to construct integrated theories of +L+

linguistics, knowledge representation, and inference. +L+ </abstract>

<note> This report describes research done at the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory of the Massachusetts +L+

Institute of Technology. Support for the work described in this paper was provided in part by +L+

Misubishi Electric Research Laboratories, Inc. Support for the laboratory's artificial intelligence +L+

research is provided in part by the Advanced Research Projects Agency of the Department of +L+

Defense under Office of Naval Research contract N00014-85-K-0124. +L+

This paper appeared in AAAI-91. A postscript electronic source for this paper can be found in +L+

ftp.ai.mit.edu:/pub/dam/aaai91a.ps. A bibtex reference can be found in ftp.ai.mit.edu:/pub/dam/dam.bib. +L+ </note>

<title> Taxonomic Syntax for First Order Inference +L+ </title>

<author> DAVID MCALLESTER and ROBERT GIVAN +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge Massachusetts +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract: We identify a new polynomial time decidable fragment of first order +L+

logic and present a general method for using polynomial time inference procedures +L+

in knowledge representation systems. Our results indicate that a non-standard +L+

"taxonomic" syntax is essential in constructing natural and powerful polynomial +L+

time inference procedures. The central role of taxonomic syntax in our polynomial time inference procedures provides technical support for the often expressed +L+

intuition that knowledge is better represented in terms of taxonomic relationships +L+

than classical first order formulas. To use our procedures in a knowledge representation system we define a "Socratic proof system" which is complete for first +L+

order inference and which can be used as a semi-automated interface to a first +L+

order knowledge base. +L+ </abstract>

proving; I.2.3 [Artificial Intelligence]: Deduction and Theorem Proving | deduction +L+

General Terms: Deduction, Algorithms +L+

Additional Keywords and Phrases: Proof Theory, Machine Inference, Theorem Proving, Automated Reasoning, Polynomial Time Algorithms, Inference +L+

Rules, Proof Systems, Mechanical Verification. +L+ </keyword>

<NEW_HEADER>

<affiliation> MASSACHUSETTS INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY +L+

ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE LABORATORY +L+ </affiliation>

<pubnum> A.I. Memo No. 1591 </pubnum> <date> November, 1996 +L+ </date>

<title> Complex Feature Recognition: A +L+

Bayesian Approach for Learning to +L+

Recognize Objects +L+ </title>

<author> Paul A. Viola +L+ </author>

<note> This publication can be retrieved by anonymous ftp to publications.ai.mit.edu. +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We have developed a new Bayesian framework for visual object +L+

recognition which is based on the insight that images of objects can be +L+

modeled as a conjunction of local features. This framework can be used +L+

to both derive an object recognition algorithm and an algorithm for +L+

learning the features themselves. The overall approach, called complex +L+

feature recognition or CFR, is unique for several reasons: it is broadly +L+

applicable to a wide range of object types, it makes constructing object +L+

models easy, it is capable of identifying either the class or the identity +L+

of an object, and it is computationally efficient requiring time proportional to the size of the image. +L+

Instead of a single simple feature such as an edge, CFR uses a large +L+

set of complex features that are learned from experience with model +L+

objects. The response of a single complex feature contains much more +L+

class information than does a single edge. This significantly reduces the +L+

number of possible correspondences between the model and the image. +L+

In addition, CFR takes advantage of a type of image processing called +L+

oriented energy. Oriented energy is used to efficiently pre-process the +L+

image to eliminate some of the difficulties associated with changes in +L+

lighting and pose. +L+ </abstract>

<note> Copyright c Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 1996 +L+

This report describes research done at the Artificial Intelligence Laboratory of the Massachusetts +L+

Institute of Technology. Support for this research was provided in part by the Advanced Research +L+

Projects Agency of the Department of Defense under Office of Naval Research contract N00014-96-1-0311. +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Anatomical origin and computational role of diversity +L+

in the response properties of cortical neurons  +L+ </title>

<author> Kalanit Grill Spectory Shimon Edelmany Rafael Malachz +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Departments of Applied Mathematics and Computer Science and Neurobiology +L+ </affiliation>

<affiliation> The Weizmann Institute of Science +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Rehovot 76100, Israel +L+ </address>

<email> fkalanit,edelmang@wisdom.weizmann.ac.il bnmalach@weizmann.weizmann.ac.il +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The maximization of diversity of neuronal response properties has been recently suggested +L+

as an organizing principle for the formation of such prominent features of the functional +L+

architecture of the brain as the cortical columns and the associated patchy projection patterns +L+

(Malach, 1994). We report a computational study of two aspects of this hypothesis. First, we +L+

show that maximal diversity is attained when the ratio of dendritic and axonal arbor sizes is +L+

equal to one, as it has been found in many cortical areas and across species (Lund et al., 1993; +L+

Malach, 1994). Second, we show that maximization of diversity leads to better performance in +L+

two case studies: in systems of receptive fields implementing steerable/shiftable filters, and in +L+

matching spatially distributed signals, a problem that arises in visual tasks such as stereopsis, +L+

motion processing, and recognition. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Toward an Analysis of Forward Pruning +L+ </title>

<author> Stephen J. J. Smith +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department +L+

University of Maryland +L+ </affiliation>

<address> College Park, MD 20740 +L+ </address>

<email> sjsmith@cs.umd.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Dana S. Nau +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Institute for Advanced Computer Studies, +L+

Computer Science Department, +L+

and Institute for Systems Research +L+

University of Maryland +L+ </affiliation>

<address> College Park, MD 20740 +L+ </address>

<email> nau@cs.umd.edu +L+ </email>

<date> June 30, 1993 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Several early game-playing computer programs used forward pruning (i.e., the practice of +L+

deliberately ignoring nodes that are believed unlikely to affect a game tree's minimax value), +L+

but this technique did not seem to result in good decision-making. The poor performance of +L+

forward pruning presents a major puzzle for AI research on game playing, because some version +L+

of forward pruning seems to be "what people do," and the best chess-playing programs still do +L+

not play as well as the best humans. +L+

As a step toward deeper understanding of how forward pruning affects quality of play, in +L+

this paper we set up a model of forward pruning on two abstract classes of binary game trees, +L+

and we use this model to investigate how forward pruning affects the accuracy of the minimax +L+

values returned. The primary result of our study is that forward pruning does better when there +L+

is a high correlation among the minimax values of sibling nodes in a game tree. +L+

This result suggests that forward pruning may possibly be a useful decision-making technique +L+

in certain kinds of games. In particular, we believe that bridge may be such a game. +L+ </abstract>

<note> Address correspondence to </note> <author> Dana S. Nau, </author> <affiliation> Computer Science Dept., University of Maryland, +L+ </affiliation>

<address> College Park, MD 20742. +L+ </address>

<note> This work supported in part by an AT&T Ph.D. scholarship to Stephen J. J. Smith, Maryland Industrial Part +L+

nerships (MIPS) grant 501.15, Great Game Products, and NSF grants IRI-8907890 and NSFD CDR-88003012. +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Parametric Models are Versatile: +L+

The Case of Model Based Optimization +L+ </title>

<author> P. Fua +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Artificial Intelligence Center +L+

SRI International +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 333 Ravenswood Avenue +L+

Menlo Park, California 94025 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Model-Based Optimization (MBO) is a paradigm in which an objective function is used to express +L+

both geometric and photometric constraints on features of interest. A parametric model of a feature +L+

(such as a road, a building, or coastline) is extracted from one or more images by adjusting the model's +L+

state variables until a minimum value of the objective function is obtained. The optimization procedure +L+

yields a description that simultaneously satisfies (or nearly satisfies) all constraints, and, as a result, is +L+

likely to be a good model of the feature. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A Data-Flow Graphical User Interface for Querying a Scientific +L+

Database  +L+ </title>

<author> Bosco S. Tjan, Leonard Breslow, Sait Dogru, Vijay Rajan, +L+

Keith Rieck, James R. Slagle, and Marius O. Poliac +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department +L+

University of Minnesota, </affiliation> <address> Minneapolis MN 55455 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We describe the design principles and functionality +L+

of a visual query language called SeeQL that represents data retrieval and analysis operations as a data-flow graph. A query is viewed as a sequence of relational algebra and other data transformation operations applied to database tables. The language is well-suited for large-scale scientific database applications, +L+

where data analysis is a major component and the typical queries or data retrieval patterns are unrestricted. +L+

The language provides a flexible yet easy-to-use environment for database access and data analysis for +L+

non-programmer research scientists. We have implemented this language in a system being used in a long-term data-intensive highway pavement research project +L+

(MnRoad) conducted by the Minnesota Department of +L+

Transportation. +L+ </abstract>

<title> Cooperative Bayesian and Case-Based Reasoning +L+

for Solving Multiagent Planning Tasks  +L+ </title>

<author> David W. Aha & Li Wu Chang +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Navy Center for Applied Research in AI +L+

Naval Research Laboratory, </affiliation> <address> Code 5510 +L+

Washington, DC 20375 +L+ </address>

<email> faha; liwug@aic.nrl.navy.mil +L+ </email>

<phone> (202) 767-2884 / FAX: 767-3172 +L+ </phone>

<date> January 25, 1996 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We describe an integrated problem solving architecture named INBANCA in +L+

which Bayesian networks and case-based reasoning (CBR) work cooperatively on +L+

multiagent planning tasks. This includes two-team dynamic tasks, and this paper +L+

concentrates on simulated soccer as an example. Bayesian networks are used to characterize action selection whereas a case-based approach is used to determine how to +L+

implement actions. This paper has two contributions. First, we survey integrations +L+

of case-based and Bayesian approaches from the perspective of a popular CBR task +L+

decomposition framework, thus explaining what types of integrations have been attempted. This allows us to explain the unique aspects of our proposed integration. +L+

Second, we demonstrate how Bayesian nets can be used to provide environmental +L+

context, and thus feature selection information, for the case-based reasoner. +L+ </abstract>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> THE LOAD, CAPACITY AND AVAILABILITY OF QUORUM +L+

SYSTEMS  +L+ </title>

<author> MONI NAOR AND AVISHAI WOOL  +L+ </author>

<abstract> Abstract. +L+

A quorum system is a collection of sets (quorums) every two of which intersect. Quorum systems +L+

have been used for many applications in the area of distributed systems, including mutual exclusion, +L+

data replication and dissemination of information +L+

Given a strategy to pick quorums, the load L(S) is the minimal access probability of the busiest +L+

element, minimizing over the strategies. The capacity Cap(S) is the highest quorum accesses rate +L+

that S can handle, so Cap(S) = 1=L(S). +L+

The availability of a quorum system S is the probability that at least one quorum survives, +L+

assuming that each element fails independently with probability p. A tradeoff between L(S) and the +L+

availability of S is shown. +L+

We present four novel constructions of quorum system, all featuring optimal or near optimal +L+

load, and high availability. The best construction, based on paths in a grid, has a load of O(1= +L+

p +L+

and a failure probability of exp(( +L+

p +L+

n)) when the elements fail with probability p &lt; 1 +L+

2 . Moreover, +L+

even in the presence of faults, with exponentially high probability the load of this system is still +L+

O(1= +L+

n). The analysis of this scheme is based on Percolation Theory. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Key words. quorum systems, load, fault tolerance, distributed computing, percolation theory, +L+

linear programming. +L+ </keyword>

<note> AMS subject classifications. 60K35, 62N05, 68M10, 68Q22, 68R05, 90A28, 90C05. +L+ </note>

<intro> 1. Introduction. </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Practical Data Breakpoints: Design and Implementation +L+ </title>

<author> Robert Wahbe Steven Lucco Susan L. Graham  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Division, </affiliation> <address> 571 Evans Hall </address> +L+

<affiliation> UC Berkeley, </affiliation> <address> Berkeley CA, 94720 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

A data breakpoint associates debugging actions with +L+

programmer-specified conditions on the memory state +L+

of an executing program. Data breakpoints provide +L+

a means for discovering program bugs that are tedious or impossible to isolate using control breakpoints +L+

alone. In practice, programmers rarely use data break-points, because they are either unimplemented or prohibitively slow in available debugging software. In this +L+

paper, we present the design and implementation of a +L+

practical data breakpoint facility. +L+

A data breakpoint facility must monitor all memory +L+

updates performed by the program being debugged. +L+

We implemented and evaluated two complementary +L+

techniques for reducing the overhead of monitoring +L+

memory updates. First, we checked write instructions +L+

by inserting checking code directly into the program +L+

being debugged. The checks use a segmented bitmap +L+

data structure that minimizes address lookup complexity. Second, we developed data flow algorithms +L+

that eliminate checks on some classes of write instructions but may increase the complexity of the remaining +L+

checks. +L+

We evaluated these techniques on the Sparc using +L+

the spec benchmarks. Checking each write instruc +L+ </abstract>

<note> This research was sponsored in part by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency under grant MDA972-92-J-1028 and contract DABT63-92-C-0026. The content of the paper does not necessarily reflect the position or the policy of the +L+

Government and no official endorsement should be inferred. +L+ </note>

<email> Email: frwahbe, lucco, grahamg@cs.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<note> To appear in Proceedings of the ACM SIGPLAN'93 Symposium on Programming Language Design and Implementation, Albuquerque, NM, June 23-25 1993. +L+ </note>

<abstract> tion using a segmented bitmap achieved an average +L+

overhead of 42%. This overhead is independent of the +L+

number of breakpoints in use. Data flow analysis eliminated an average of 79% of the dynamic write checks. +L+

For scientific programs such the nas kernels, analysis +L+

reduced write checks by a factor of ten or more. On the +L+

Sparc these optimizations reduced the average overhead to 25%. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<web> URL: http://www.cam.sri.com/tr/crc033/paper.ps.Z </web> <note> Eurospeech, Berlin, 1993 +L+ </note>

<title> A SPEECH-BASED ROUTE ENQUIRY SYSTEM BUILT FROM +L+

GENERAL-PURPOSE COMPONENTS 1 +L+ </title>

<author> Ian Lewin , Martin Russell , David Carter , Sue Browning , Keith Ponting and Stephen Pulman  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Speech Research Unit, DRA Malvern, </affiliation> <address> St Andrews Road, Malvern, Worcs, WR14 3PS, UK +L+ </address>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

The adaptation of existing general-purpose speech recognition and language understanding systems can greatly +L+

reduce the cost of developing applications. However, the +L+

components must have appropriate characteristics for this +L+

to be possible. +L+

Work is in progress to adapt two task-independent +L+

<NEW_HEADER>

<web> URL: http://www.cam.sri.com/tr/crc044/paper.ps.ZARPA </web> <note> (HLT) Proceedings, Princeton, 1994 +L+ </note>

<title> Combining Knowledge Sources +L+

to Reorder N-Best Speech Hypothesis Lists +L+ </title>

<author> Manny Rayner 1 , David Carter 1 , Vassilios Digalakis 2 , Patti Price 2 +L+ </author>

<affiliation> (1) SRI International, </affiliation> <address> Suite 23, Millers Yard, Cambridge CB2 1RQ, UK +L+ </address>

<affiliation> (2) SRI International, </affiliation> <address> 333 Ravenswood Ave., Menlo Park, CA 94025, USA +L+ </address>

<date> November 29, 1994 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

A simple and general method is described that can combine different +L+

knowledge sources to reorder N-best lists of hypotheses produced by a +L+

speech recognizer. The method is automatically trainable, acquiring information from both positive and negative examples. Experiments are +L+

described in which it was tested on a 1000-utterance sample of unseen +L+

ATIS data. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> AAAI-98, Madison, WI, to appear +L+ </note>

<title> Needles in a Haystack : Plan Recognition in Large Spatial +L+

Domains Involving Multiple Agents +L+ </title>

<author> Mark Devaney and Ashwin Ram +L+ </author>

<affiliation> College of Computing +L+

Georgia Institute of Technology +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Atlanta, GA 30332-0280 +L+ </address>

<email> markd@cc.gatech.edu +L+

ashwin@cc.gatech.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

While plan recognition research has been applied to a +L+

wide variety of problems, it has largely made identical assumptions about the number of agents participating in the plan, the observability of the plan execution process, and the scale of the domain. We describe a method for plan recognition in a real-world +L+

domain involving large numbers of agents performing +L+

spatial maneuvers in concert under conditions of limited observability. These assumptions differ radically +L+

from those traditionally made in plan recognition and +L+

produce a problem which combines aspects of the fields +L+

of plan recognition, pattern recognition, and object +L+

tracking. We describe our initial solution which borrows and builds upon research from each of these areas, +L+

employing a pattern-directed approach to recognize individual movements and generalizing these to produce +L+

inferences of large-scale behavior. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Multistrategy Learning of Adaptive Reactive Controllers +L+ </title>

<author> Juan Carlos Santamara and Ashwin Ram +L+ </author>

<affiliation> College of Computing +L+

Georgia Institute of Technology +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Atlanta, Georgia 30332-0280 +L+ </address>

<email> E-mail: fcarlos,ashwing@cc.gatech.edu +L+ </email>

<phone> Phone: (404) 894-4995 +L+

Fax: (404) 894-9846 +L+ </phone>

<pubnum> Technical Report GIT-CC-97-05 +L+ </pubnum>

<date> January 1997 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Reactive controllers has been widely used in mobile robots since they are able to achieve successful performance in real-time. However, the configuration of a reactive controller depends +L+

highly on the operating conditions of the robot and the environment; thus, a reactive controller +L+

configured for one class of environments may not perform adequately in another. This paper +L+

presents a formulation of learning adaptive reactive controllers. Adaptive reactive controllers +L+

inherit all the advantages of traditional reactive controllers, but in addition they are able to adjust themselves to the current operating conditions of the robot and the environment in order to +L+

improve task performance. Furthermore, learning adaptive reactive controllers can learn when +L+

and how to adapt the reactive controller so as to achieve effective performance under different +L+

conditions. The paper presents an algorithm for a learning adaptive reactive controller that +L+

combines ideas from case-based reasoning and reinforcement learning to construct a mapping +L+

between the operating conditions of a controller and the appropriate controller configuration; +L+

this mapping is in turn used to adapt the controller configuration dynamically. As a case +L+

study, the algorithm is implemented in a robotic navigation system that controls a Denning +L+

MRV-III mobile robot. The system is extensively evaluated using statistical methods to verify +L+

its learning performance and to understand the relevance of different design parameters on the +L+

performance of the system. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: Reactive control, multistrategy learning, case-based reasoning, reinforcement learning, +L+

robotic navigation. +L+ </keyword>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> The State of the Art in Ontology Design: +L+

A Survey and Comparative Review +L+ </title>

<author> Natalya Fridman Noy +L+

Carole D. Hafner +L+ </author>

<affiliation> College of Computer Science +L+

Northeastern University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Boston, MA 02115 +L+ </address>

<email> -natasha, hafner-@ccs.neu.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

In this paper we develop a framework for comparing +L+

ontologies, and place a number of the more +L+

prominent ontologies into it. We have selected 10 +L+

specific projects for this study, including general +L+

ontologies, domain specific ones, and one knowledge +L+

representation system. The comparison framework +L+

includes general characteristics such as the purpose of +L+

an ontology, its coverage (general or domain-specific), its size, and the formalism used. It also +L+

includes the design process used in creating an +L+

ontology and the methods used to evaluate it. +L+

Characteristics that describe the content of an +L+

ontology include taxonomic organization, types of +L+

concepts covered, top-level divisions, internal +L+

structure of concepts, representation of part-whole +L+

relations, and the presence and nature of additional +L+

axioms. Finally we consider what experiments or +L+

applications have used the ontologies. Knowledge +L+

sharing and reuse will require a common framework +L+

to support interoperability of independently created +L+

ontologies. Our study shows there is great diversity +L+

in the way ontologies are designed and the way they +L+

represent the world. By identifying the similarities +L+

and differences among existing ontologies, we clarify +L+

the range of alternatives in creating a standard +L+

framework for ontology design. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Adaptive Markov Chain Monte Carlo through +L+

Regeneration +L+ </title>

<author> Walter R. Gilks +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Medical Research Council +L+

Biostatistics Unit +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Cambridge, CB2 2SR, UK. +L+ </address>

<author> Gareth O. Roberts +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Statistical Laboratory +L+

University of Cambridge +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Cambridge, CB2 1SB, UK. +L+ </address>

<author> Sujit K. Sahu +L+ </author>

<affiliation> School of Mathematics +L+

University of Wales, Cardiff +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Cardiff, CF2 4YH, UK. +L+ </address>

<date> January 26, 1998 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Summary +L+

Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) is used for evaluating expectations of functions of interest +L+

under a target distribution . This is done by calculating averages over the sample path of a +L+

Markov chain having as its stationary distribution. For computational efficiency, the Markov +L+

chain should be rapidly mixing. This can sometimes be achieved only by careful design of the +L+

transition kernel of the chain, on the basis of a detailed preliminary exploratory analysis of . An +L+

alternative approach might be to allow the transition kernel to adapt whenever new features of  +L+

are encountered during the MCMC run. However, if such adaptation occurs infinitely often, the +L+

stationary distribution of the chain may be disturbed. We describe a framework, based on the +L+

concept of Markov chain regeneration, which allows adaptation to occur infinitely often, but which +L+

does not disturb the stationary distribution of the chain or the consistency of sample-path averages. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Key Words: Adaptive method; Bayesian inference; Gibbs sampling; Markov chain Monte Carlo; +L+ </keyword>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> RESONANCE AND THE PERCEPTION OF +L+

MUSICAL METER +L+ </title>

<author> Edward W. Large +L+

John F. Kolen +L+ </author>

<affiliation> The Ohio State University +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Many connectionist approaches to musical expectancy and music composition let the +L+

question of What next? overshadow the equally important question of When next?. One cannot +L+

escape the latter question, one of temporal structure, when considering the perception of musical +L+

meter. We view the perception of metrical structure as a dynamic process where the temporal +L+

organization of external musical events synchronizes, or entrains, a listeners internal processing +L+

mechanisms. This article introduces a novel connectionist unit, based upon a mathematical model +L+

of entrainment, capable of phase and frequency-locking to periodic components of incoming +L+

rhythmic patterns. Networks of these units can self-organize temporally structured responses to +L+

rhythmic patterns. The resulting network behavior embodies the perception of metrical structure. +L+

The article concludes with a discussion of the implications of our approach for theories of metrical +L+

structure and musical expectancy. +L+ </abstract>

<note> Connection Science, 6 (1), 177 - 208. +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A Volumetric Approach to Virtual Simulation +L+

of Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery +L+ </title>

<author> Gregory J. Wiet 1,2 , Roni Yagel 3 , Don Stredney 2 , Petra Schmalbrock 4 , +L+ </author>

<author> Dennis J. Sessanna 2 , Yair Kurzion 3 , Louis Rosenberg 5 , Michael Levin 5 , Kenneth Martin 5 +L+ </author>

<affiliation> 1 Department of Otolaryngology, The Ohio State University Hospitals, </affiliation> <address> Columbus, OH +L+ </address>

<affiliation> 2 The Ohio Supercomputer Center, </affiliation> <address> Columbus, OH +L+ </address>

<affiliation> 3 Department of Computer and Information Science, The Ohio State University, </affiliation> <address> Columbus, OH +L+ </address>

<affiliation> 4 Department of Radiology, The Ohio State University Hospitals, </affiliation> <address> Columbus, OH +L+ </address>

<affiliation> 5 Immersion Corporation, </affiliation> <address> San Jose, CA +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Advanced display technologies have made the virtual exploration of relatively complex models feasible +L+

in many applications. Unfortunately, only a few human interfaces allow natural interaction with the +L+

environment. Moreover, in surgical applications, such realistic interaction requires real-time rendering +L+

of volumetric data - placing an overwhelming performance burden on the system. We report on a +L+

collaboration of an interdisciplinary group developing a virtual reality system that provides intuitive +L+

interaction with volume data by employing real-time volume rendering and force feedback (haptic) +L+

sensations. We describe our rendering methods and the haptic devices and explain its utility of this +L+

system in the real-world application of Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (ESS) simulation. +L+ </abstract>

<title> Refining Interactions in a Distributed System +L+ </title>

<author> Neelam Soundarajan +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer and Information Science +L+

The Ohio State University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 2015 Neil Avenue +L+

Columbus, OH 43210 +L+

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Clustering Methods for Collaborative Filtering +L+ </title>

<author> Lyle H. Ungar and Dean P. Foster +L+ </author>

<affiliation> CIS Dept. and Dept. of Statistics +L+

University of Pennsylvania +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Philadelphia, PA 19104 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Grouping people into clusters based on the items they have purchased allows accurate recommendations of new items for purchase: +L+

if you and I have liked many of the same movies, then I will probably enjoy other movies that you like. Recommending items based +L+

on similarity of interest (a.k.a. collaborative filtering) is attractive +L+

for many domains: books, CDs, movies, etc., but does not always +L+

work well. Because data are always sparse any given person has +L+

seen only a small fraction of all movies much more accurate predictions can be made by grouping people into clusters with similar +L+

movies and grouping movies into clusters which tend to be liked by +L+

the same people. Finding optimal clusters is tricky because the movie +L+

groups should be used to help determine the people groups and visa +L+

versa. We present a formal statistical model of collaborative filtering, +L+

and compare different algorithms for estimating the model parameters +L+

including variations of K-means clustering and Gibbs Sampling. This +L+

formal model is easily extended to handle clustering of objects with +L+

multiple attributes. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: collaborative filtering, clustering, EM, Gibbs sampling +L+ </keyword>

<note> Email address of contact author: </note> <email> ungar@cis.upenn.edu +L+ </email>

<note> Phone number of contact author: </note> <phone> 215 898-7449 +L+ </phone>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> AUCTION-DRIVEN COORDINATION FOR +L+

PLANTWIDE OPTIMIZATION +L+ </title>

<author> Rinaldo A. Jose and Lyle H. Ungar +L+ </author>

<affiliation> University of Pennsylvania +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Philadelphia, PA 19104 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Model predictive control strategies generally focus on controlling plant outputs to setpoints; in +L+

industry, however, a more desirable goal is maximizing a plants profitability. In principle, this can be +L+

done by creating a plant model and maximizing profit with respect to the market prices of the plants +L+

inputs and outputs, but in practice, such centralized approaches often cannot effectively be applied at +L+

the operations time scale due to the size and complexity of the problem. One solution is to use +L+

decentralized optimization at the unit operations level by tearing process streams and coordinating the +L+

resulting pieces. Such optimization, however, requires that unit inputs and outputs be priced. We show +L+

that a traditional Lagrangean-based approach to this pricing fails for simple systems. Instead, we define +L+

slack resources over the torn process streams and price them using auctions. Unlike Lagrange +L+

multipliers, slack resource prices contain useful information and can be used to make decisions +L+

regarding capital improvements, thus providing a strong tie between the operations and management +L+

layers in chemical plants. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords +L+

auctions, distributed optimization, resource prices, process decomposition, optimal coordination, +L+

penalty-based methods, Lagrangean decomposition +L+ </keyword>

<intro> Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Integrality and Separability of Input Devices +L+ </title>

<author> Robert J.K. Jacob +L+

Linda E. Sibert +L+

Daniel C. McFarlane +L+

M. Preston Mullen, Jr. +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Human-Computer Interaction Lab +L+

Naval Research Laboratory +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Washington, D.C. +L+ </address>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

Current input device taxonomies and other frameworks typically emphasize +L+

the mechanical structure of input devices. We suggest that selecting an +L+

appropriate input device for an interactive task requires looking beyond the +L+

physical structure of devices to the deeper perceptual structure of the task, the +L+

device, and the interrelationship between the perceptual structure of the task and +L+

the control properties of the device. We affirm that perception is key to +L+

understanding performance of multidimensional input devices on +L+

multidimensional tasks. We have therefore extended the theory of processing of +L+

perceptual structure to graphical interactive tasks and to the control structure of +L+

input devices. This allows us to predict task and device combinations that lead to +L+

better performance and hypothesize that performance is improved when the +L+

perceptual structure of the task matches the control structure of the device. We +L+

conducted an experiment in which subjects performed two tasks with different +L+

perceptual structures, using two input devices with correspondingly different +L+

control structures, a three-dimensional tracker and a mouse. We analyzed both +L+

speed and accuracy, as well as the trajectories generated by subjects as they used +L+

the unconstrained three-dimensional tracker to perform each task. The results +L+

support our hypothesis and confirm the importance of matching the perceptual +L+

structure of the task and the control structure of the input device. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: Input devices, interaction techniques, gesture input, Polhemus +L+

tracker, perceptual space, integrality, separability. +L+ </keyword>

<intro> INTRODUCTION </intro>

<note> To appear in Proceedings of Virtual Reality Vienna '93 +L+ </note>

<title> Constructing Cyberspace: +L+

Virtual Reality and Hypermedia +L+ </title>

<author> Keith Andrews +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Institute for Information Processing and Computer Supported New Media (IICM) +L+

Graz University of Technology, +L+ </affiliation>

<address> A-8010 Graz, Austria. +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Large-scale, distributed hypermedia information systems allow fast, structured access to very large, dynamic information bases. The highly perceptual nature of a virtual reality interface has the power to take users both inside information and inside its +L+

structure. Combining the two takes us a step towards cyberspace, William Gibson's +L+

vision of a virtual model of all the world's interconnected data. This paper reviews +L+

current work on the boundary of virtual reality and hypermedia. +L+ </abstract>
