<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Probabilistic Analysis for Combinatorial +L+

Functions of Moving Points  +L+ </title>

<author> Li Zhang Harish Devarajan Julien Basch Piotr Indyk +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department +L+

Stanford University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Stanford, CA94305 +L+ </address>

<email> flizhang,harish,jbasch,indykg@cs.stanford.edu +L+ </email>

<date> September 9, 1997 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Given a set of n points, what is the description complexity of their convex hull? In our world, this question +L+

is understood with an implicit "in the worst case", and the answer is n bd=2c where d is the dimension of +L+

the underlying space. This is not entirely satisfactory, as this description complexity can vary tremendously +L+

depending on the positions of the points. Another approach is to look at the expected description complexity +L+

when the points are drawn from a given distribution. This type of analysis, initiated by Renyi and Sulanke +L+

[RS63] and pursued by others gets its value from the fact that this expectation is in general much smaller +L+

than in the worst case, and, more importantly, in that it often allows one to design algorithms that have +L+

expected running times against which worst case aware algorithms cannot compete. For instance, the convex +L+

hull of n points drawn independently uniformly at random from a d-dimensional hypercube has expected +L+

complexity O(log d1 n), and can be computed in expected linear time. +L+

In parallel, in the past decade, a number of papers have considered a setting where points are allowed +L+

to move along low degree algebraic trajectories. Different questions have been asked in this context. In +L+

particular, Atallah [Ata85], studied the number of times the combinatorial description of the convex hull +L+

or closest pair can change, in the worst case ("dynamic computational geometry"). More recently, Basch, +L+

Guibas, and Hershberger [BGH97] have designed kinetic data structures to maintain these attributes in an +L+

online setting, measuring the quality of a kinetic data structure by the ratio of the worst case number of +L+

changes to the configuration of interest, to the worst case number of changes to the data structure itself, for +L+

low degree algebraic motions. However, an experimental study undertaken in [BGSZ97] to assess the quality +L+

of these data structures in practice shows that the worst case analysis can hide vastly different results in +L+

terms of expectation when the point positions and speeds are drawn at random from some distributions. It +L+

is this study that motivated the present paper. +L+

In this communication, we report several results on the expected number of changes to various combinatorial structures for the case when points are drawn from the uniform distribution on the unit square. These +L+

results can be generalized for any dimension d &gt; 2. +L+ </abstract>

<note> This paper appeared in the proceedings of the 13th Symposium of Computational Geometry (1997) as a communication +L+

Supported in part by National Science Foundation grant CCR-9623851 and by US Army MURI grant DAAH04-96-1-0007. +L+

Supported in part by the Okawa Foundation. +L+

x Supported in part by ARO MURI Grant DAAH04-96-1-0007 and by NSF Award CCR-9357849, with matching funds +L+

from IBM, Mitsubishi, Schlumberger Foundation, Shell Foundation, and Xerox Corporation. +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Geometric Matching under Noise: Combinatorial Bounds and +L+

Algorithms  +L+ </title>

<author> Piotr Indyk Rajeev Motwani Suresh Venkatasubramanian +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

Stanford University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Stanford, CA 94305 +L+ </address>

<email> findyk,rajeev,sureshg@cs.stanford.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The geometric point set matching problem in 2 and 3 dimensions is a well-studied problem with application to areas such as computer vision and pattern recognition, computational chemistry and other fields +L+

such as cartography and computer animation. The basic problems can be formulated as follows. Given +L+

some choice of a space of transformations and a similarity measure d(P; Q) for two point sets P and Q in +L+

Euclidean space. +L+

Problem 1 (Pattern Matching (PM)) Given point sets P and Q, where jP j = k and jQj = n with +L+

k n, and an * &gt; 0, find a transformation T for which d(T (P ); Q) * or return none if no such T exists. +L+

Problem 2 (Largest Common Point-set (LCP)) Given point sets P and Q, where jP j = m and jQj = +L+

n, K &gt; 0 and * &gt; 0, find a transformation T and a set P 0 P of size jP 0 j K such that jd(T (P 0 ); Q)j * +L+

or return none if no such T and P 0 exist. +L+

We restrict T to the space of rigid Euclidean translations and rotations. The similarity measures of interest +L+

to us are: the exact metric 1 d E (P; Q) (binary-valued, requiring each point in P to be mapped to a point in +L+

Q); the Hausdorff metric d H (P; Q) (maximum over all points in P of the distance to the nearest point in +L+

Q); and, the matching metric d M (bottleneck matching distance). +L+

A detailed study of this set of problems was initiated by Alt, Mehlhorn, Wagener, and Welzl [AMWW88]. +L+

In this seminal work, they propose a suite of algorithms for the exact and matching metrics. More recent work +L+

led to improved bounds for pattern matching and LCP under the exact metric. The problem of estimating +L+

the minimum Hausdorff distance between two point sets in 2 and 3 dimensions has been studied extensively. +L+

Clearly, any real application of such algorithms has to deal with the presence of noise in data, requiring +L+

the algorithms to perform matching within the limits of some reasonable noise model. In fact, our interest +L+

in these problems arose during an attempt to implement such algorithms for applications in computer vision +L+

and in computational biology and chemistry, particularly rational drug design [FKL + 97]. We discovered that +L+

noise present in real data rendered most known algorithms inoperative. In hindsight, this is not surprising +L+

for, as noted in the survey by Alt and Guibas [AG96], these algorithms are likely to be "difficult to implement +L+

and numerically unstable due to the necessary computation of intersections of complex algebraic surfaces." +L+

Worse still, they have unacceptably high running times: for example, even in R 2 , LCP under the matching +L+

metric requires O(n 8 ) time, although under additional restrictions on noise regions the running times can be +L+ </abstract>

<note> This research is supported in part by a grant from Pfizer Central Research. +L+

Supported by NSF Award CCR-9357849, with matching funds from IBM, Mitsubishi, Schlumberger Foundation, Shell +L+

Foundation, and Xerox Corporation. +L+

Supported by an Alfred P. Sloan Research Fellowship, an IBM Faculty Partnership Award, an ARO MURI Grant DAAH04-96-1-0007, and NSF Young Investigator Award CCR-9357849, with matching funds from IBM, Mitsubishi, Schlumberger Foun +L+

dation, Shell Foundation, and Xerox Corporation. +L+ </note>

<note> 1 We use the term "metric" only for convenience; formally, none of the above measures satisfy all the properties of a metric. </note>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Lexicographic Bit Allocation for MPEG Video +L+ </title>

<author> Dzung T. Hoang +L </author>+

<affiliation> Sony Semiconductor of America +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 3300 Zanker Road, MS SJ3C3 +L+

San Jose, CA 95134 +L+ </address>

<email> dth@ricochet.net +L+ </email>

<author> Elliot L. Linzer +L+ </author>

<affiliation> C-Cube Microsystems +L+ </affiliation>

<address> One Water Street, 2nd Floor +L+

White Plains, NY 10601 +L+ </address>

<email> elliot.linzer@c-cube.com +L+ </email>

<author> Jeffrey Scott Vitter +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Duke University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Box 90129 +L+

Durham, NC 27708-0129 +L+ </address>

<email> jsv@cs.duke.edu +L+ </email>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Scalable Mining for Classification Rules +L+

in Relational Databases +L+ </title>

<author> Min Wang Bala Iyer Jeffrey Scott Vitter +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Computer Science Database Technology Institute Dept. of Computer Science +L+

Duke University IBM Santa Teresa Lab Duke University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Durham, NC 27708 San Jose, CA 95161 Durham, NC 27708 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Classification is a key function of many "business +L+

intelligence" toolkits and a fundamental building block +L+

in data mining. Immense data may be needed to train +L+

a classifier for good accuracy. The state-of-art classifiers [21, 25] need an in-memory data structure of +L+

size O(N ), where N is the size of the training data, +L+

to achieve efficiency. For large data sets, such a data +L+

structure will not fit in the internal memory. The best +L+

previously known classifier does a quadratic number of +L+

I/Os for large N . +L+

In this paper, we propose a novel classification algorithm (classifier) called MIND (MINing in +L+

Databases). MIND can be phrased in such a way that +L+

its implementation is very easy using the extended relational calculus SQL, and this in turn allows the classifier to be built into a relational database system directly. MIND is truly scalable with respect to I/O efficiency, which is important since scalability is a key +L+

requirement for any data mining algorithm. +L+

We built a prototype of MIND in the relational +L+

database manager DB2 and benchmarked its performance. We describe the working prototype and report +L+

the measured performance with respect to the previous +L+

method of choice. MIND scales not only with the size +L+

of the datasets but also with the number of processors +L+

on an IBM SP2 computer system. Even on uniproces-sors, MIND scales well beyond the dataset sizes previously published for classifiers. We also give some +L+

insights that may have an impact on the evolution of +L+

the extended relational calculus SQL. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A Unified Analysis of Value-Function-Based +L+

Reinforcement-Learning Algorithms +L+ </title>

<author> Csaba Szepesvari +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Research Group on Artificial Intelligence +L+

"Jozsef Attila" University +L+ </affiliation>

<affiliation> Szeged 6720, Aradi vrt tere 1. +L+

Hungary +L+ </affiliation>

<email> szepes@sol.cc.u-szeged.hu +L+ </email>

<author> Michael L. Littman +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

Duke University +L+ </affiliation>

<affiliation> Durham, NC 27708-0129 +L+ </affiliation>

<email> mlittman@cs.duke.edu +L+ </email>

<date> December 3, 1997 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Reinforcement learning is the problem of generating optimal behavior in a sequential decision-making environment given the opportunity of +L+

interacting with it. Many algorithms for solving reinforcement-learning +L+

problems work by computing improved estimates of the optimal value +L+

function. We extend prior analyses of reinforcement-learning algorithms +L+

and present a powerful new theorem that can provide a unified analysis of +L+

value-function-based reinforcement-learning algorithms. The usefulness +L+

of the theorem lies in how it allows the asynchronous convergence of a +L+

complex reinforcement-learning algorithm to be proven by verifying that +L+

a simpler synchronous algorithm converges. We illustrate the application +L+

of the theorem by analyzing the convergence of Q-learning, model-based +L+

reinforcement learning, Q-learning with multi-state updates, Q-learning +L+

for Markov games, and risk-sensitive reinforcement learning. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<pubnum> M.I.T Media Laboratory Perceptual Computing Section Technical Report No. 279 </pubnum> <note> (Replaces TR-228) +L+ </note>

<note> Appears in the IEEE Transactions on Image Processing Special Issue: Image Sequence Compression, +L+

vol 3, no. 5, p. 625-638, September 1994. Revised: May, 1994 +L+ </note>

<title> Representing Moving Images with Layers +L+ </title>

<author> John Y. A. Wang AND Edward H. Adelson +L+ </author>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We describe a system for representing moving +L+

images with sets of overlapping layers. Each +L+

layer contains an intensity map that defines the +L+

additive values of each pixel, along with an alpha +L+

map that serves as a mask indicating the transparency. The layers are ordered in depth and +L+

they occlude each other in accord with the rules +L+

of compositing. Velocity maps define how the +L+

layers are to be warped over time. The layered +L+

representation is more flexible than standard image transforms and can capture many important +L+

properties of natural image sequences. We describe some methods for decomposing image sequences into layers using motion analysis, and we +L+

discuss how the representation may be used for +L+

image coding and other applications. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords| Image coding, motion analysis, image +L+

segmentation, image representation, robust estimation. +L+ </keyword>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> An Extensible End-to-End Protocol and Framework +L+ </title>

<author> K. L. Calvert +L+

R. H. Kravets +L+

R. D. Krupczak +L+ </author>

<affiliation> College of Computing +L+

Georgia Institute of Technology +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Atlanta, Georgia, USA +L+ </address>

<email> fcalvert,robink,rdkg@cc.gatech.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We describe a framework for composing end-to-end protocol functions. The framework comprises: +L+

a generic model of protocol processing; a metaheader protocol supporting per-packet configuration +L+

of protocol function and efficient demultiplexing of incoming data units; and an extensible set of +L+

modular protocol functions. This paper describes the pieces of the framework and motivates some +L+

of the design decisions. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction and Motivations </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A Protocol for Efficient Transfer of Data over Fiber/Cable Systems +L+ </title>

<author> Dolors Sala John O. Limb +L+ </author>

<affiliation> School of Electrical College of Computing +L+

and Computer Engineering +L+

Georgia Institute of Technology +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Atlanta, GA 30332-0280 +L+ </address>

<email> E-mail: (dolors,limb)@cc.gatech.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

A revolution is occurring in the scope and range +L+

of information, communication and education services +L+

that will be made available to schools, libraries, town-halls, clinics and, most importantly, residences. These +L+

services will be provided initially, primarily over hybrid fiber-cable systems, either by telephone companies +L+

or cable companies. The old cable plant is being upgraded and used in totally new ways. +L+

The topology and physical characteristics of the upstream channel present new challenges for efficient +L+

channel access. We present a media access protocol +L+

that efficiently transfers data on this channel. A primary goal in the design was to keep the portion of the +L+

protocol resident in the station as simple as possible. +L+

Thus we use centralized control located in the cable +L+

head-end and minimize intelligence in the station. We +L+

refer to this protocol as Centralized Priority Reservation or CPR. A station wishing to transmit sends a request to the head-end using a contention channel. The +L+

head-end acknowledges the request and then schedules +L+

the request, informing the station by means of a grant +L+

message when to transmit. +L+

The protocol performs well under heavy load. Performance is affected little by the number of stations, +L+

the speed of the system and the physical length of the +L+

system. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> PARALLEL AND DISTRIBUTED SIMULATION +L+ </title>

<author> Richard M. Fujimoto +L+ </author>

<affiliation> College of Computing +L+

Georgia Institute of Technology +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Atlanta, Georgia 30332-0280, U.S.A. +L+ </address>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

Research and development efforts in the parallel and +L+

distributed simulation field over the last 15 years +L+

has progressed, largely independently, in two separate camps: the largely academic high performance +L+

Parallel And Distributed (discrete event) Simulation (PADS) community, and the DoD-centered Distributed Interactive Simulation (DIS) community. +L+

This tutorial gives an overview and comparison of +L+

work in these two areas, emphasizing issues related to +L+

distributed execution where these fields have the most +L+

overlap. Differences in the fundamental assumptions +L+

routinely used within each community are contrasted, +L+

followed by overviews of work in each community. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 INTRODUCTION </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Storage Systems for Movies-on-Demand Video Servers +L+ </title>

<author> Ann L. Chervenak +L+ </author>

<date> April 7, 1995 +L+ </date>

<abstract> 1 Abstract +L+

In this paper, we evaluate storage system alternatives for movies-on-demand video servers. We begin by +L+

characterizing the movies-on-demand workload. Then we study disk farms in which one movie is stored per +L+

disk. This is a simple scheme, but it wastes substantial disk bandwidth, since disks holding less popular +L+

movies are under-utilized; also, good performance requires that movies be replicated to reflect the user +L+

request pattern. Next, we examine disk farms in which movies are striped across disks, and find that +L+

striped video servers offer close to full utilization of the disks by achieving better load balancing. Finally, we +L+

evaluate the use of storage hierarchies for video service that include a tertiary library along with a disk farm. +L+

Unfortunately, we show that the performance of neither magnetic tape libraries nor optical disk jukeboxes +L+

as part of a storage hierarchy is adequate to service the predicted distribution of movie accesses. We suggest +L+

changes to tertiary libraries that would make them better-suited to these applications. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 2 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Evaluating Blocking Probability in Generalized +L+

Connectors +L+ </title>

<author> Ellen Witte Zegura +L+ </author>

<abstract> Abstract| Generalized connectors provide the capability to connect a single input to one or more outputs. Such networks play an important role in supporting any application that involves the distribution of information from one source to many destinations or many sources to many destinations. We present the first analytic model for evaluating blocking probability in generalized connectors. The model allows flexibility in specifying traffic fanout characteristics and network routing algorithms. Equations are derived for computing blocking probability for the important class of series-parallel networks. We investigate the accuracy of the equations by comparing the blocking probability computed using the equations to results from simulation. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

<title> Reverse Engineering with a CASE Tool +L+ </title>

<author> Bret Johnson +L+ </author>

<note> Research advisors: Spencer Rugaber and Rich LeBlanc +L+ </note>

<date> October 6, 1994 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We examine using a CASE tool, Interactive Development Environment's Software through Pictures (StP), to support reverse engineering. We generate structure charts in StP from the automated analysis +L+

of C source code. The advantages of this approach are that one can use +L+

the CASE tool's support for drawing, linking, and modifying pictorial +L+

notations for program design in order to make it easier to construct a +L+

reverse engineering tool. Additionally, one can then use the design rep +L+

resentations with the CASE tool to do reengineering for maintenance. +L+ </abstract>

<title> Finding Interesting Rules from Large Sets of Discovered Association Rules +L+ </title>

<author> Mika Klemettinen Heikki Mannila Pirjo Ronkainen Hannu Toivonen A. Inkeri Verkamo +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Helsinki +L+ </affiliation>

<address> P.O. Box 26, FIN-00014 University of Helsinki, Finland +L+ </address>

<email> mannila@cs.helsinki.fi +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Association rules, introduced by Agrawal, Imielinski, and +L+

Swami, are rules of the form "for 90 % of the rows of the +L+

relation, if the row has value 1 in the columns in set W , +L+

then it has 1 also in column B". Efficient methods exist for +L+

discovering association rules from large collections of data. +L+

The number of discovered rules can, however, be so large +L+

that browsing the rule set and finding interesting rules from +L+

it can be quite difficult for the user. We show how a simple +L+

formalism of rule templates makes it possible to easily describe the structure of interesting rules. We also give examples of visualization of rules, and show how a visualization +L+

tool interfaces with rule templates. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A structured document database system +L+ </title>

<author> Pekka Kilpelainen Greger Linden Heikki Mannila +L+
Erja Nikunen +L+ </author>

<affiliation> University of Helsinki +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We describe a database system for writing, editing, and querying structured documents. The structure of text is described using a context-free +L+

grammar. The operations are implemented using a powerful query language. The system supports the use of user-defined multiple views of the +L+

documents: one view can contain all the structure explicitly, while another +L+

can contain only part of the document and have only part of the structure visible. This makes the system flexible for different editing tasks. +L+

The system is implemented in C using a relational database system. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

<title> Lempel-Ziv Index for q-Grams +L+ </title>

<author> Juha Karkkainen and Erkki Sutinen +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science, </affiliation><address>  P.O. Box 26 (Teollisuuskatu 23), +L+ </address>

<address> FIN-00014 </address> <affiliation> University of Helsinki, </affiliation> <address> Finland +L+ </address>

<email> fJuha.Karkkainen,Erkki.Sutineng@cs.Helsinki.FI +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract. We present a new sublinear-size index structure for q-grams. +L+

A q-gram index of the text is used in many approximate pattern matching +L+

algorithms. All earlier q-gram indexes have at least linear size. The new +L+

method takes advantage of repetitions in the text found by Lempel-Ziv +L+

parsing. +L+ </abstract>

<note> ??, ??, 1-10 (??) +L+

<title> Unifying Two-View and Three-View Geometry +L+ </title>

<author> SHAI AVIDAN, AMNON SHASHUA +L+ </author>

<email> favidan,shashuag@cs.huji.ac.il +L+ </email>

<affiliation> Institute of Computer Science, The Hebrew University, </affiliation> <address> Jerusalem 91904, Israel +L+ </address>

<note> Received ??. Revised ??. +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract. The core of multiple-view geometry is governed by the fundamental matrix and the trilinear +L+

tensor. In this paper we unify both representations by first re-deriving the fundamental matrix as a rank +L+

deficient tensor, and secondly by deriving a unified set of operators that are transparent to the number of +L+

views. As a result, we show that the basic building block of the geometry of multiple views is the trilinear +L+

tensor of three views and that this tensor specializes to the fundamental matrix (in it's tensor form) in +L+

the case of two views. The properties of the tensor (geometric interpretation, contraction properties, +L+

etc.) are independent of the number of views (two or three). As a byproduct, every two-view algorithm +L+

can be considered as a degenerate three-view algorithm and three-view algorithms can work with either +L+

two or three images, all using one standard set of tensor operations. To highlight the usefulness of this +L+

paradigm we provide two practical applications. First we present a novel view synthesis algorithm that +L+

starts with the fundamental matrix (in its tensor form) and seamlessly move to the general trilinear +L+

tensor, all using one set of tensor operations. The second application is a camera stabilization algorithm, +L+

originally introduced for three views, now working with two views without modification. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1. Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Using Queue Time Predictions for Processor Allocation +L+ </title>

<author> Allen B. Downey  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> University of California at Berkeley +L+

San Diego Supercomputer Center +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

When a moldable job is submitted to a space-sharing +L+

parallel computer, it must choose whether to begin execution on a small, available cluster or wait in queue for +L+

more processors to become available. To make this decision, it must predict how long it will have to wait for +L+

the larger cluster. We propose statistical techniques for +L+

predicting these queue times, and develop an allocation +L+

strategy that uses these predictions. We present a workload model based on observed workloads at the San Diego +L+

Supercomputer Center and the Cornell Theory Center, +L+

and use this model to drive simulations of various allocation strategies. We find that prediction-based allocation +L+

not only improves the turnaround time of individual jobs; +L+

it also improves the utilization of the system as a whole. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Coordination and Control Structures and Processes: +L+

Possibilities for Connectionist Networks (CN) +L+ </title>

<author> Vasant Honavar & Leonard Uhr +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Sciences Department +L+

University of Wisconsin-Madison +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The absence of powerful control structures and processes that synchronize, coordinate, switch between, choose among, regulate, direct, modulate interactions between, and +L+

combine distinct yet interdependent modules of large connectionist networks (CN) is +L+

probably one of the most important reasons why such networks have not yet succeeded at +L+

handling difficult tasks (e.g. complex object recognition and description, complex +L+

problem-solving, planning). +L+

In this paper we examine how CN built from large numbers of relatively simple +L+

neuron-like units can be given the ability to handle problems that in typical multi-computer networks and artificial intelligence programs along with all other types of +L+

programs are always handled using extremely elaborate and precisely worked out central control (coordination, synchronization, switching, etc.). We point out the several +L+

mechanisms for central control of this un-brain-like sort that CN already have built into +L+

them albeit in hidden, often overlooked, ways. +L+

We examine the kinds of control mechanisms found in computers, programs, fetal +L+

development, cellular function and the immune system, evolution, social organizations, +L+

and especially brains, that might be of use in CN. Particularly intriguing suggestions are +L+

found in the pacemakers, oscillators, and other local sources of the brain's complex partial synchronies; the diffuse, global effects of slow electrical waves and neurohormones; +L+

the developmental program that guides fetal development; communication and coordination within and among living cells; the working of the immune system; the evolutionary +L+

processes that operate on large populations of organisms; and the great variety of partially competing partially cooperating controls found in small groups, organizations, and +L+

larger societies. All these systems are rich in control but typically control that emerges +L+

from complex interactions of many local and diffuse sources. We explore how several +L+

different kinds of plausible control mechanisms might be incorporated into CN, and +L+

assess their potential benefits with respect to their cost. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> 1 FEATURE SUBSET SELECTION USING A +L+

GENETIC ALGORITHM +L+ </title>

<author> Jihoon Yang and Vasant Honavar +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Artificial Intelligence Research Group +L+

Department of Computer Science +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 226 Atanasoff Hall +L+ </address>

<affiliation> Iowa State University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Ames, IA 50011 +L+

U.S.A. +L+ </address>

<email> yangjhonavar-@cs.iastate.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract: Practical pattern classification and knowledge discovery problems require selection of a +L+

subset of attributes or features (from a much larger set) to represent the patterns to be classified. +L+

This is due to the fact that the performance of the classifier (usually induced by some learning +L+

algorithm) and the cost of classification are sensitive to the choice of the features used to construct +L+

the classifier. Exhaustive evaluation of possible feature subsets is usually infeasible in practice because +L+

of the large amount of computational effort required. Genetic algorithms, which belong to a class of +L+

randomized heuristic search techniques, offer an attractive approach to find near-optimal solutions +L+

to such optimization problems. This paper presents an approach to feature subset selection using a +L+

genetic algorithm. Some advantages of this approach include the ability to accommodate multiple +L+

criteria such as accuracy and cost of classification into the feature selection process and to find feature +L+

subsets that perform well for particular choices of the inductive learning algorithm used to construct +L+

the pattern classifier. Our experiments with several benchmark real-world pattern classification +L+

problems demonstrate the feasibility of this approach to feature subset selection in the automated +L+

design of neural networks for pattern classification and knowledge discovery. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1.1 INTRODUCTION </intro>

<title> Compiler Construction Using Scheme +L+ </title>

This paper describes a course in compiler design that focuses on the +L+

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Using Goals and Experience to Guide Abduction +L+ </title>

<author> David B. Leake +L+ </author>

<email> leake@cs.indiana.edu +L+ </email>

<pubnum> Technical Report #359 +L+ </pubnum>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science, Indiana University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Lindley Hall 215, Bloomington, IN 47405 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Standard methods for abductive understanding are neutral to prior experience and current goals. +L+

Candidate explanations are built from scratch by backwards chaining, without considering how +L+

similar situations were previously explained, and selection of the candidate to accept is based on its +L+

likelihood, without considering the information needs beyond routine understanding. Problems arise +L+

when applying these methods to everyday understanding: The vast range of possible explanations +L+

makes it difficult to control the cost of explanation construction and to assure that the explanations +L+

generated will actually be useful. +L+

We argue that these problems can be overcome by using goals and experience to guide both +L+

explanation generation and evaluation. Our work is within the framework of case-based explanation, which builds explanations by retrieving and adapting prior explanations stored in memory. +L+

We substantiate our model by describing mechanisms that enable it to effectively generate good +L+

explanations. First, we demonstrate that there exists a theory of anomaly and explanation that can +L+

guide retrieval of relevant explanations. Second, we present a plausibility evaluation process that +L+

efficiently detects conflicts and confirmations of an explanation's assumptions by prior patterns, +L+

making it possible to focus explanation adaptation when retrieved explanations are implausible. +L+

Third, we present methods for judging whether explanations provide the information needed to satisfy explainer goals beyond routine understanding. By reflecting experience and goals in the search +L+

for explanations, case-based explanation provides a practical mechanism for guiding search towards +L+

explanations that are both plausible and useful. +L+ </abstract>

<note> 1 The work described here was supported in part by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, </note>

<title> Toward the Rigorous Use of +L+

Diagrams in Reasoning about +L+

Hardware +L+ </title>

<author> Steven D. Johnson </author> <email> sjohnson@indiana.edu </email> <affiliation> Department of Computer Science Indiana University +L+ </affiliation>

<note> Proceedings of the Fifteenth International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Morgan Kaufmann, San Francisco, 1997. +L+ </note>

<title> Learning to Integrate Multiple Knowledge Sources +L+

for Case-Based Reasoning +L+ </title>

<author> David B. Leake, Andrew Kinley, and David Wilson +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Lindley Hall 215, </address> <affiliation> Indiana University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Bloomington, IN 47405, U.S.A. +L+ </address>

<email> fleake, akinley, davwilsg@cs.indiana.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The case-based reasoning process depends on +L+

multiple overlapping knowledge sources, each +L+

of which provides an opportunity for learning. Exploiting these opportunities requires +L+

not only determining the learning mechanisms +L+

to use for each individual knowledge source, +L+

but also how the different learning mechanisms interact and their combined utility. This +L+

paper presents a case study examining the +L+

relative contributions and costs involved in +L+

learning processes for three different knowledge sources|cases, case adaptation knowledge, and similarity information|in a case-based planner. It demonstrates the importance +L+

of interactions between different learning processes and identifies a promising method for integrating multiple learning methods to improve +L+

case-based reasoning. +L+ </abstract>

<title> A Ray Tracing Method for Illumination Calculation in +L+

Diffuse-Specular Scenes +L+ </title>

<author> Peter Shirley +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Illinois +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 1304 West Springfield Avenue +L+

Urbana, Illinois 61801 +L+
USA +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Several ways of improving the realism of the results +L+

of traditional ray tracing are presented. The essential physical quantities of spectral radiant power and +L+

spectral radiance and their use in lighting calculations +L+

are discussed. Global illumination terms are derived +L+

by employing illumination ray tracing for calculation of +L+

quickly changing indirect lighting components, and ra-diosity ray tracing for slowly changing indirect lighting +L+

components. Direct lighting is calculated during the +L+

viewing phase allowing the use of bump maps. Finally, +L+

a method is introduced that reduces the total number +L+

of shadow rays to no more than the total number of +L+

viewing rays for a given picture. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: Bump Mapping, Illumination, Radiosity, +L+

Radiance, Ray Tracing, Realism, Stratified Sampling, +L+

Texture Mapping. +L+ </keyword>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> 3-D Stereo Using Photometric Ratios +L+ </title>

<author> Lawrence B. Wolff +L+

Elli Angelopoulou +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Vision Laboratory +L+

Department of Computer Science +L+

The Johns Hopkins University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Baltimore, MD 21218 +L+ </address>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

We present a novel robust methodology for corresponding a dense set of points on an +L+

object surface from photometric values, for 3-D stereo computation of depth. The methodology utilizes multiple stereo pairs of images, each stereo pair taken of exactly the same +L+

scene but under different illumination. With just 2 stereo pairs of images taken respectively for 2 different illumination conditions, a stereo pair of ratio images can be produced; one for the ratio of left images, and one for the ratio of right images. We +L+

demonstrate how the photometric ratios composing these images can be used for accurate +L+

correspondence of object points. Object points having the same photometric ratio with +L+

respect to 2 different illumination conditions comprise a well-defined equivalence class of +L+

physical constraints defined by local surface orientation relative to illumination conditions. We formally show that for diffuse reection the photometric ratio is invariant to +L+

varying camera characteristics, surface albedo, and viewpoint and that therefore the same +L+

photometric ratio in both images of a stereo pair implies the same equivalence class of +L+

physical constraints. Corresponding photometric ratios along epipolar lines in a stereo pair +L+

of images under different illumination conditions is therefore a robust correspondence of +L+

equivalent physical constraints, and determination of depth from stereo can be performed +L+

without explicitly knowing what these physical constraints being corresponded actually +L+

are. This implies a very practical shape-from-stereo methodology applicable to perspective views and not requiring any knowledge whatsoever of illumination conditions. This is +L+

particularly practical for determination of 3-D shape on smooth featureless surfaces which +L+

has previously been hard to perform using stereo. We demonstrate experimental 3-D shape +L+

determination from a dense set of points using our stereo technique on smooth objects of +L+

known ground truth shape that are accurate to well within 1% depth accuracy. +L+ </abstract>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON PATTERN ANALYSIS AND MACHINE INTELLIGENCE, VOL. 17, NO. 6, JUNE 1995 599 +L+ </note>

<title> Best-Case Results for Nearest Neighbor +L+

Learning +L+ </title>

<author> Steven Salzberg, Arthur Delcher, David Heath, and Simon Kasif +L+ </author>

<abstract> Abstract| In this paper we propose a theoretical model +L+

for analysis of classification methods, in which the teacher +L+

knows the classification algorithm and chooses examples in +L+

the best way possible. We apply this model using the nearest-neighbor learning algorithm, and develop upper and lower +L+

bounds on sample complexity for several different concept +L+

classes. For some concept classes, the sample complexity +L+

turns out to be exponential even using this best-case model, +L+

which implies that the concept class is inherently difficult +L+

for the nearest-neighbor algorithm. We identify several geometric properties that make learning certain concepts relatively easy. Finally we discuss the relation of our work +L+

to helpful teacher models, its application to decision-tree +L+

learning algorithms, and some of its implications for current experimental work. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords| machine learning, nearest-neighbor, geometric +L+

concepts. +L+ </keyword>

<intro> I. Introduction </intro>

<title> Deterministic Sorting +L+

in Nearly Logarithmic Time +L+

on the Hypercube +L+

and Related Computers +L+ </title>

<author> Robert Cypher +L+ </author>

<affiliation> IBM Almaden Research Center +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 650 Harry Rd. +L+

San Jose, CA 95120 +L+ </address>

<author> C. Greg Plaxton  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> MIT Laboratory for Computer Science +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 545 Technology Square +L+

Cambridge, MA 02139 +L+ </address>

<date> November 29, 1995 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper presents a deterministic sorting algorithm, called Sharesort, that sorts n +L+

records on an n-processor hypercube, shu*e-exchange, or cube-connected cycles in +L+

O(log n (log log n) 2 ) time in the worst case. The algorithm requires only a constant +L+

amount of storage at each processor. The fastest previous deterministic algorithm for +L+

this problem was Batcher's bitonic sort, which runs in O(log 2 n) time. +L+ </abstract>

89-J-1988. +L+ </note>

<NEW_HEADER>

<note> Appears in Machine Learning: Proceedings of the Tenth International Conference, +L+

P. E. Utgoff (editor), Morgan Kaufmann, San Mateo, CA, 1993 +L+ </note>

<title> Learning Symbolic Rules Using Artificial Neural Networks +L+ </title>

<author> Mark W. Craven and Jude W. Shavlik +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Sciences Department +L+

University of Wisconsin +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 1210 West Dayton St. +L+

Madison, WI 53706 +L+ </address>

<email> email: fcraven, shavlikg@cs.wisc.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

A distinct advantage of symbolic learning +L+

algorithms over artificial neural networks is +L+

that typically the concept representations +L+

they form are more easily understood by humans. One approach to understanding the +L+

representations formed by neural networks is +L+

to extract symbolic rules from trained networks. In this paper we describe and investigate an approach for extracting rules from +L+

networks that uses (1) the NofM extraction algorithm, and (2) the network training +L+

method of soft weight-sharing. Previously, +L+

the NofM algorithm had been successfully +L+

applied only to knowledge-based neural networks. Our experiments demonstrate that +L+

our extracted rules generalize better than +L+

rules learned using the C4.5 system. In addition to being accurate, our extracted rules +L+

are also reasonably comprehensible. +L+ </abstract>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> The Royal Tree Problem, a Benchmark for Single and +L+

Multi-population Genetic Programming +L+ </title>

<note> appears in "Advances in Genetic Programming II", MIT Press, Pete Angeline and +L+

Kim Kinnear, editors +L+ </note>

<author> Bill Punch, Doug Zongker, and Erik Goodman +L+ </author>

<abstract> We report on work done to develop a benchmark problem for genetic programming, both +L+

as a difficult problem to test GP abilities and as a platform for tuning GP parameters. +L+

This benchmark, the royal tree, is a function that accounts for tree shape as part of its +L+

evaluation function, thus it controls for a parameter not often found in the GP literature. +L+

It also is a progressive function, allowing the user to set the difficulty of the problem +L+

attempted. We not only describe the function, but also report on results of using island +L+

parallelism for solving GP problems. The results obtained are somewhat surprising, as it +L+

appears that a single large population outperforms a group of smaller populations under +L+

all the conditions tested. +L+ </abstract>

<title> A Perspective on Word Sense Disambiguation Methods +L+

and Their Evaluation +L+ </title>

University of Maryland +L+ </affiliation>

<address> College Park, MD 20742 +L+ </address>

<email> resnik@umiacs.umd.edu +L+ </email>

<author> David Yarowsky +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Computer Science/CLSP +L+

Johns Hopkins University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Baltimore, MD 21218 +L+ </address>

<email> yarowsky@cs.jhu.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

In this position paper, we make several +L+

observations about the state of the art in +L+

automatic word sense disambiguation. Motivated by these observations, we offer several specific proposals to the community regarding improved evaluation criteria, common training and testing resources, and the +L+

definition of sense inventories. +L+ </abstract>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Inductive Constraint Logic +L+

and the Mutagenesis Problem +L+ </title>

<author> Wim Van Laer Hendrik Blockeel +L+

Luc De Raedt +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Celestijnenlaan 200A, B-3001 Heverlee, Belgium +L+ </address>

<email> Email:fWimV,Hendrik,LucDRg@cs.kuleuven.ac.be +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

A novel approach to learning first order logic formulae from positive and negative examples is incorporated in a system named ICL (Inductive Constraint +L+

Logic). In ICL, examples are viewed as interpretations which are true or false +L+

for the target theory, whereas in present inductive logic programming systems, +L+

examples are true and false ground facts (or clauses). Furthermore, ICL uses a +L+

clausal representation, which corresponds to a conjunctive normal form where +L+

each conjunct forms a constraint on positive examples, whereas classical learning +L+

techniques have concentrated on concept representations in disjunctive normal +L+

form. +L+

We present some experiments with this new system on the mutagenesis problem. These experiments illustrate some of the differences with other systems, +L+

and indicate that our approach should work at least as well as the more classical +L+

approaches. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Model-guided Segmentation of Corpus Callosum in MR Images +L+ </title>

<author> Arvid Lundervold 1 , Nicolae Duta 2 , Torfinn Taxt 1 & Anil K. Jain 2 +L+ </author>

<affiliation> 1 Section for Medical Image Analysis and Informatics, Department of Physiology +L+ </affiliation>

<affiliation> University of Bergen, </affiliation> <address> Arstadveien 19, N-5009 Bergen, Norway +L+ </address>

<affiliation> 2 Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Michigan State University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> East Lansing, MI 48824-1226, USA +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain, followed by automated segmentation of the corpus callosum +L+

(CC) in midsagittal sections have important applications +L+

in both clinical neurology and neurocognitive research +L+

since the size and shape of the CC are shown to be correlated to sex, age, neurodegenerative diseases and various lateralized behavior in man. Moreover, whole head, +L+

multispectral 3D MRI recordings enable voxel-based tissue classification and estimation of total brain volumes, +L+

in addition to CC morphometric parameters. We propose +L+

a new algorithm that uses both multispectral MRI measurements (intensity values) and prior information about +L+

shape (CC template) to segment CC in midsagittal slices +L+

with very little user interaction. The algorithm has been +L+

tested on a sample of 10 subjects scanned with multispec-tral 3D MRI, collected for a study of dyslexia, with very +L+

good agreement between the manually traced (true) CC +L+

outline and the detected CC outline. We conclude that +L+

the proposed method for CC segmentation is promising for +L+

clinical use when multispectral MR images are recorded. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Statistical Characteristics and Multiplexing of MPEG Streams +L+ </title>

<author> Marwan Krunz , Ron Sass , and Herman Hughes  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Electrical Engineering +L+

Department of Computer Science +L+

Michigan State University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> East Lansing, MI 48824 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper presents a study of the statistical characteristics and multiplexing of Variable-Bit-Rate (VBR) +L+

MPEG-coded video streams. Our results are based on +L+

23 minutes of video obtained from the entertainment +L+

movie, The Wizard of Oz. The experimental setup +L+

which was used to capture, digitize, and compress the +L+

video stream is described. Although the study is conducted at the frame level (as opposed to the slice level), +L+

it is observed that the inter-frame correlation structure for the frame-size sequence involves complicated +L+

forms of pseudo-periodicity that are mainly affected +L+

by the compression pattern of the sequence. A simple model for an MPEG traffic source is developed in +L+

which frames are generated according to the compression pattern of the original captured video stream. The +L+

number of cells per frame is fitted by a lognormal distribution. Simulations are used to study the performance of an ATM multiplexer for MPEG streams. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

Aditi is a deductive database system under development at the Collaborative Information +L+

Technology Research Institute by researchers from the University of Melbourne. The main +L+

language in which users interact with Aditi is Aditi-Prolog. This document is a reference +L+

manual for Aditi-Prolog. +L+ </abstract>

for Robot Vision System +L+ </title>

<title> Agents for Citation Finding +L+

on the World Wide Web +L+ </title>

<author> Yi Han, Seng Wai Loke, Leon Sterling +L+ </author>

<pubnum> Technical Report 96/40 +L+ </pubnum>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

The University of Melbourne +L+ </affiliation>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Termination Analysis for Mercury +L+ </title>

<author> Chris Speirs, Zoltan Somogyi and Harald Stndergaard +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

The University of Melbourne +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Parkville, Victoria 3052, Australia +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Since the late eighties, much progress has been made in the theory of termination analysis for +L+

logic programs. However, from a practical point of view, the significance of much of the work +L+

on termination is hard to judge, since experimental evaluations rarely get published. Here we +L+

describe and evaluate a termination analyzer for Mercury, a strongly typed and moded logic- +L+

functional programming language. Mercury's high degree of referential transparency and the +L+

guaranteed availability of reliable mode information simplify the termination analysis of Mer- +L+

cury compared with that of other logic programming languages. We describe our termination +L+

analyzer, which uses a variant of a method developed by Plumer. It deals with full Mercury, +L+

including modules, declarative input/output, the foreign language interface, and higher-order +L+

features. In spite of these obstacles, it produces high-quality termination information, comparable to the results recently obtained by Lindenstrauss and Sagiv. Most important, in stark +L+

contrast with Lindenstrauss and Sagiv's experimental results, our analyzer has a negligible +L+

impact on the running time of the compiler of which it is part, even for large programs. This +L+

means that the Mercury compiler can produce valuable termination information at no real +L+

cost to the programmer. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Mixed Semidefinite-Quadratic-Linear Programs +L+ </title>

<author> Jean-Pierre Haeberly Madhu V. Nayakkankuppam  +L+

Michael L. Overton  +L+ </author>

<date> September 23, 1998 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We consider mixed semidefinite-quadratic-linear programs. These are +L+

linear optimization problems with three kinds of cone constraints, namely: +L+

the semidefinite cone, the quadratic cone and the nonnegative orthant. We +L+

outline a primal-dual path following method to solve these problems and +L+

highlight the main features of SDPpack, a Matlab package which solves +L+

such programs. We give some examples where such mixed programs arise, +L+

and provide numerical results on benchmark problems. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

<title> Methods for Handling Faults and Asynchrony +L+

in Parallel Computation  +L+ </title>

<author> Z. M. Kedem  +L+ </author>

<intro> 1. Introduction and Motivation </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Toward the Automation of the Card-Playing +L+

Component of Bridge +L+ </title>

<author> Ming-Sheng Chang +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences +L+

New York University +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

In comparision with other games, particularly chess, the research in computer bridge is +L+

immature, and the best bridge-playing programs are mediocre. We propose to study the +L+

automation of the card-playing segment of bridge (omitting bidding), using a number of +L+

different techniques. In this paper we first give an introduction to the state of computer +L+

bridge. Next, we propose two possible architectures for solving double-dummy bridge +L+

(i.e., a simplified bridge game with perfect information): The first is based on the +L+

combination of And-OR search and heuristic evaluation. The second forms a global plan +L+

by merging subplans for each individual suit. Next, to deal with uncertain information in +L+

real bridge, we present a new mechanism that combines the concepts of both minimax +L+

search and possible worlds. Finally we give a brief description of further work toward +L+

automating card-playing in real bridge. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> The Development of the C Language +L+ </title>

<author> Dennis M. Ritchie +L+ </author>

<affiliation> AT&T Bell Laboratories +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Murray Hill, NJ 07974 USA +L+ </address>

<email> dmr@research.att.com +L+ </email>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

The C programming language was devised in the early 1970s as a system +L+

implementation language for the nascent Unix operating system. Derived from +L+

the typeless language BCPL, it evolved a type structure; created on a tiny +L+

machine as a tool to improve a meager programming environment, it has become +L+

one of the dominant languages of today. This paper studies its evolution. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> Introduction
 </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Hierarchical Explanation-Based Reinforcement Learning +L+ </title>

<author> Prasad Tadepalli and Thomas G. Dietterich +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department +L+

Oregon State University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Corvallis,Oregon 97331-3202 +L+ </address>

<email> ftadepalli,tgdg@research.cs.orst.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Explanation-Based Reinforcement Learning +L+

(EBRL) was introduced by Dietterich and +L+

Flann as a way of combining the ability of +L+

Reinforcement Learning (RL) to learn optimal plans with the generalization ability +L+

of Explanation-Based Learning (EBL) (Di-etterich & Flann, 1995). We extend this +L+

work to domains where the agent must order and achieve a sequence of subgoals in +L+

an optimal fashion. Hierarchical EBRL can +L+

effectively learn optimal policies in some of +L+

these sequential task domains even when the +L+

subgoals weakly interact with each other. +L+

We also show that when a planner that can +L+

achieve the individual subgoals is available, +L+

our method converges even faster. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> DISTRIBUTED CONTROL IN OPTICAL WDM NETWORKS +L+ </title>

<author> X. Yuan R. Gupta R. Melhem +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Pittsburgh +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Pittsburgh, PA 15260 +L+ </address>

<abstract> ABSTRACT +L+

This paper describes and evaluates distributed +L+

wavelength reservation protocols for all-optical WDM +L+

networks. These protocols are essential for applying +L+

WDM techniques to large scale all-optical networks. +L+

The protocols ensure that the wavelengths on the links +L+

along a path are reserved before communication takes +L+

place. A message is transmitted using the reserved +L+

wavelengths and remains in the optical domain utill +L+

it reaches the destination. Based upon the timing at +L+

which the reservation is performed, the protocols are +L+

classified into two categories: forward reservation protocols and backward reservation protocols. Although +L+

forward reservation protocols are simpler, our performance study shows that backward reservation protocols provide better performance. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> INTRODUCTION </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Contingency Selection in Plan Generation +L+ </title>

<author> Nilufer Onder +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Pittsburgh +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Pittsburgh, PA 15260 +L+ </address>

<note> nilufer@cs.pitt.edu +L+ </note>

<author> Martha E. Pollack +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

and Intelligent Systems Program +L+

University of Pittsburgh +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Pittsburgh, PA 15260 +L+ </address>

<note> pollack@cs.pitt.edu +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

A key question in conditional planning is: how many, +L+

and which of the possible execution failures should be +L+

planned for? One cannot, in general, plan for all the +L+

possible failures because the search space is too large. +L+

One cannot ignore all the possible failures, or one will +L+

fail to produce sufficiently flexible plans. In this paper, +L+

we describe an approach to conditional planning that +L+

attempts to identify the contingencies that contribute +L+

the most to a plan's overall utility. Plan generation +L+

proceeds by handling the most important contingencies first, extending the plan to include actions that +L+

will be taken in case the contingency fails. We discuss +L+

the representational issues that must be addressed in +L+

order to implement such an algorithm, and present an +L+

example which illustrates our approach. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Working Sets, Cache Sizes, and Node Granularity Issues +L+

for Large-Scale Multiprocessors +L+ </title>

<author> Edward Rothberg Jaswinder Pal Singh and Anoop Gupta +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Intel Supercomputer Systems Division Computer Systems Laboratory +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 14924 N.W. Greenbrier Parkway </address> <affiliation> Stanford University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Beaverton, OR 97006 Stanford, CA 94305 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The distribution of resources among processors, memory and +L+

caches is a crucial question faced by designers of large-scale +L+

parallel machines. If a machine is to solve problems with a +L+

certain data set size, should it be built with a large number of +L+

processors each with a small amount of memory, or a smaller +L+

number of processors each with a large amount of memory? +L+

How much cache memory should be provided per processor for +L+

cost-effectiveness? And how do these decisions change as larger +L+

problems are run on larger machines? +L+

In this paper, we explore the above questions based on the +L+

characteristics of five important classes of large-scale parallel scientific applications. We first show that all the applications have a hierarchy of well-defined per-processor working +L+

sets, whose size, performance impact and scaling characteristics +L+

can help determine how large different levels of a multiprocessor's cache hierarchy should be. Then, we use these working sets together with certain other important characteristics of +L+

the applications|such as communication to computation ratios, +L+

concurrency, and load balancing behavior|to reflect upon the +L+

broader question of the granularity of processing nodes in high-performance multiprocessors. +L+

We find that very small caches whose sizes do not increase +L+

with the problem or machine size are adequate for all but two of +L+

the application classes. Even in the two exceptions, the working +L+

sets scale quite slowly with problem size, and the cache sizes +L+

needed for problems that will be run in the foreseeable future +L+

are small. We also find that relatively fine-grained machines, +L+

with large numbers of processors and quite small amounts of +L+

memory per processor, are appropriate for all the applications. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Modeling Communication in Parallel Algorithms: +L+

A Fruitful Interaction between Theory and Systems? +L+ </title>

<author> Jaswinder Pal Singh * , Edward Rothberg , and Anoop Gupta * +L+ </author>

<affiliation> * Computer Systems Laboratory Intel Supercomputer Systems +L+

Stanford University </affiliation> <address> 14924 NW Greenbrier Pkwy, CO6-09 +L+

Stanford, CA 94305 Beaverton, OR 97006 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Recently, several theoretical models of parallel architectures have been proposed to replace the PRAM as the model +L+

that is presented to an algorithm designer. A primary focus of +L+

the new models is to include the cost of interprocessor communication, which is increasingly important in modern parallel +L+

architectures. We argue that modeling the communication costs +L+

in the architecture or system is only one part of the problem. +L+

The other, and usually much more difficult, part is modeling +L+

the communication properties of the algorithm itself, which +L+

provides necessary inputs into the architectural model to determine overall complexity. In this context, we make three main +L+

points in this paper: (i) It is incomplete to describe communication without regard to its relationship with replication. We +L+

propose a description of the communication-replication relationship in terms of the working set hierarchy of an algorithm. +L+

(ii) Both inherent communication and the communication-replication relationship can be very difficult to model in irregular, dynamic computations that are crucial in many real-world +L+

applications. We present some examples that demonstrate this +L+

difficulty. (iii) We believe that substantial leverage can be +L+

obtained in this effort from the computer systems community, +L+

which can provide a hierarchy of simulation and profiling +L+

toolsfrom abstract to detailedtailored to the needs of the +L+

algorithm designers. We propose an initial set of simulation +L+

tools, and we discuss possible future refinements to this set. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<pubnum> Technical Report TR-514-96. +L+ </pubnum>

<title> Irregular Applications under Software Shared Memory +L+ </title>

<author> Liviu Iftode, Jaswinder Pal Singh and Kai Li +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

Princeton University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Princeton, NJ 08544 +L+ </address>

<email> liv,jps,li@cs.princeton.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Shared Virtual Memory (SVM) provides an inexpensive way to support the popular shared address +L+

space programming model on networks of workstations or personal computers. Despite recent advances +L+

in SVM systems, their performance for all but coarse-grained or regular applications is not well understood. +L+

Nor is there an understanding of whether and how +L+

fine-grained, irregular programs should be written differently for SVM, with its large granularities of communication and coherence, than for the more familiar +L+

hardware coherent at cache line granularity. In this +L+

paper we try to understand the performance and programming issues for emerging, irregular applications +L+

on SVM systems. We examine performance on both +L+

an aggressive all-software system as well as one with a +L+

little hardware support in the network interface. We +L+

also present approaches to improve the performance +L+

of irregular applications at both the programming and +L+

the system level. As a result of our experiences, we +L+

identify a set of guidelines and techniques that pertain +L+

specifically to programming SVM systems, beyond the +L+

guidelines commonly used for programming hardware-coherent systems as well. We also present a further +L+

relaxation of the memory consistency model, called +L+

scope consistency, which is particularly effective for +L+

such applications. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Network Services for +L+

Multi-User Virtual Environments +L+ </title>

<author> Thomas A. Funkhouser +L+ </author>

<affiliation> AT&T Bell Laboratories +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Murray Hill, NJ +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper describes network services to support +L+

large multi-user virtual environments. A client-server design is proposed in which multiple servers +L+

coordinate execution, manage communication, offload processing, and provide persistent storage for +L+

their clients. Using this design, it is possible to support real-time features, such as collision detection, +L+

voice bridging, persistent updates, physical simulation, and autonomous agents, that would be difficult to implement for large virtual environments +L+

with a peer-to-peer design. The paper includes a +L+

description of services being implemented in RING, +L+

a client-server system for interaction between many +L+

users in large virtual environments. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

<title> Database and Display Algorithms for +L+

<author> by +L+

<degree> B.S. (Stanford University) 1983 +L+

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Simulating the Madness of Crowds: +L+

Price Bubbles in an Auction-Mediated Robot Market +L+ </title>

<author> Ken Steiglitz and Daniel Shapiro +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Computer Science, Princeton University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Princeton, NJ 08544 +L+ </address>

<date> May 5, 1997 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We simulate a multiagent market with production, consumption, and exchange +L+

mediated by a sealed-bid double auction. Marked price bubbles and subsequent +L+

crashes occur when value-based (fundamentals-driven) and trend-based traders are +L+

both present, and the market equilibrium price is ramped up exogenously. Similarly, +L+

negative price bubbles and recoveries occur when the equilibrium price is ramped +L+

down. Because the simulated market is auction-mediated, we can observe the operations of traders during these events, and study the interactions that produce and +L+

resolve bubbles. Some preliminary circuit-breaker experiments are described, in which +L+

bubbles are interrupted during their formation. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction
 </intro>

<title> An Evolutionary Approach to +L+

Combinatorial Optimization Problems +L+ </title>

<author> Sami Khuri +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Mathematics & Computer Science +L+

San Jose State University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> One Washington Square +L+

San Jose, CA 95192-0103, U.S.A. +L+ </address>

<email> khuri@sjsumcs.sjsu.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Thomas Back and Jorg Heitkotter +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Dortmund +L+ 

Systems Analysis Research Group, LSXI +L+ </affiliation>

<address> D-44221 Dortmund, Germany +L+ </address>

<email> fbaeck,jokeg@ls11.informatik.uni-dortmund.de +L+ </email>

<note> Copyright c 1993 ACM Press. All rights reserved. +L+

To appear in the proceedings of CSC'94 +L+

Phoenix Arizona, March 8-10, 1994. +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract: The paper reports on the application of genetic +L+

algorithms, probabilistic search algorithms based on the +L+

model of organic evolution, to NP-complete combinatorial +L+

optimization problems. In particular, the subset sum, maximum cut, and minimum tardy task problems are considered. +L+

Except for the fitness function, no problem-specific changes +L+

of the genetic algorithm are required in order to achieve results of high quality even for the problem instances of size +L+

100 used in the paper. For constrained problems, such as the +L+

subset sum and the minimum tardy task, the constraints are +L+

taken into account by incorporating a graded penalty term +L+

into the fitness function. Even for large instances of these +L+

highly multimodal optimization problems, an iterated application of the genetic algorithm is observed to find the global +L+

optimum within a number of runs. As the genetic algorithm +L+

samples only a tiny fraction of the search space, these results +L+

are quite encouraging. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

for Scheduling +L+ </title>
