<NEW_HEADER>

<title> The Relative Complexity of NP Search Problems +L+ </title>

<author> Paul Beame  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science and Engineering +L+

University of Washington +L+ </affiliation>

<email> beame@cs.washington.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Stephen Cook  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Dept. +L+

University of Toronto +L+ </affiliation>

<email> sacook@cs.toronto.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Jeff Edmonds  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> I.C.S.I. +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Berkeley, CA 94704-1198 +L+ </address>

<email> edmonds@icsi.berkeley.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Russell Impagliazzo x +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science and Engineering +L+

UC, San Diego +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 9500 Gilman Drive +L+

La Jolla, CA 92093-0114 +L+ </address>

<email> russell@cs.ucsd.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Toniann Pitassi - +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Mathematics and Computer Science +L+

University of Pittsburgh +L+ </affiliation>

<email> toni@cs.pitt.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Papadimitriou introduced several classes of NP search problems based on combinatorial principles which guarantee the +L+

existence of solutions to the problems. Many interesting +L+

search problems not known to be solvable in polynomial +L+

time are contained in these classes, and a number of them +L+

are complete problems. We consider the question of the relative complexity of these search problem classes. We prove +L+

several separations which show that in a generic relativized +L+

world, the search classes are distinct and there is a standard +L+

search problem in each of them that is not computation-ally equivalent to any decision problem. (Naturally, absolute separations would imply that P 6= NP.) Our separation +L+

proofs have interesting combinatorial content and go to the +L+

heart of the combinatorial principles on which the classes are +L+

based. We derive one result via new lower bounds on the +L+

degrees of polynomials asserted to exist by Hilbert's Null-stellensatz over finite fields. +L+ </abstract>

<note> Research supported by NSF grants CCR-8858799 and CCR-9303017 +L+

Research supported by an NSERC operating grant and the Information Technology Research Centre +L+

Supported by an NSF postdoctoral fellowship and by a Canadian +L+

NSERC postdoctoral fellowship +L+

x Research Supported by NSF YI Award CCR-92-570979, Sloan +L+

Research Fellowship BR-3311, grant #93025 of the joint US-Czechoslovak Science and Technology Program, and USA-Israel BSF +L+

Grant 92-00043 +L+

Research supported by an NSF postdoctoral fellowship and by +L+

NSF Grant CCR-9457782 +L+ </note>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<pubnum> TR - UCSD - CS96-484 +L+ </pubnum>

<title> Mapping Parallel Applications to +L+

Distributed Heterogeneous Systems +L+ </title>

<author> Silvia M. Figueira 1 and Francine Berman 2 +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science and Engineering +L+

University of California, San Diego +L+ </affiliation>

<email> -silvia,berman-@cs.ucsd.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Fast networks have made it possible to coordinate distributed heterogeneous CPU, +L+

memory and storage resources to provide a powerful platform for executing high-performance applications. However, the performance of parallel applications on such +L+

systems is highly dependent on the mapping of application tasks to machines. In this +L+

paper, we propose a mapping strategy for applications formed by multiple tasks targeted +L+

to heterogeneous platforms. We first define a mapping model, the match-tree, which +L+

reects the data movement and conversion costs of distributed algorithms and allows for +L+

alternative implementations of individual tasks on different machines. We then define the +L+

find-mapping and split-partition algorithms, based on the match-tree model, to +L+

determine the best allocation of tasks to resources in heterogeneous systems. We +L+

illustrate the use of these algorithms with a sample distributed application. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Almost All Regular Graphs are +L+

Hamiltonian +L+ </title>

<author> R. W. Robinson +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department +L+

University of Georgia +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Athens, GA 30602, U.S.A. +L+ </address>

<author> N. C. Wormald  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Mathematics +L+

University of Melbourne +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Parkville, VIC 3052, Australia +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

In a previous paper the authors showed that almost all labelled +L+

cubic graphs are hamiltonian. In the present paper, this result is +L+

used to show that almost all r-regular graphs are hamiltonian for any +L+

fixed r 3, by an analysis of the distribution of 1-factors in random +L+

regular graphs. Moreover, almost all such graphs are r-edge-colourable +L+

if they have an even number of vertices. Similarly, almost all r-regular +L+

bipartite graphs are hamiltonian and r-edge-colourable for fixed r 3. +L+ </abstract>

<note> Research supported by the Australian Research Council +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Learning to Schedule Straight-Line Code +L+ </title>

<author> J. Eliot B. Moss +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Comp. Sci. +L+

Univ. of Mass. +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Amherst, MA 01003 +L+ </address>

<author> Paul E. Utgoff +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Comp. Sci. +L+

Univ. of Mass. +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Amherst, MA 01003 +L+ </address>

<author> John Cavazos +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Comp. Sci. +L+

Univ. of Mass. +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Amherst, MA 01003 +L+ </address>

<author> Doina Precup +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Comp. Sci. +L+

Univ. of Mass. +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Amherst, MA 01003 +L+ </address>

<author> Darko Stefanovi c +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Comp. Sci. +L+

Univ. of Mass. +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Amherst, MA 01003 +L+ </address>

<author> Carla Brodley +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Sch. of Elec. and Comp. Eng. +L+

Purdue University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> W. Lafayette, IN 47907 +L+ </address>

<author> David Scheeff +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Sch. of Elec. and Comp. Eng. +L+

Purdue University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> W. Lafayette, IN 47907 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Execution speed of programs on modern computer architectures is sensitive, by a factor of two or more, to the order in which instructions +L+

are presented to the processor. To realize potential execution efficiency, +L+

it is now customary for an optimizing compiler to employ a heuristic +L+

algorithm for instruction scheduling. These algorithms are painstakingly +L+

hand-crafted, which is expenseive and time-consuming. We show how +L+

to cast the instruction scheduling problem as a learning task, so that one +L+

obtains the heuristic scheduling algorithm automatically. Our focus is the +L+

narrower problem of scheduling straight-line code, also known as a basic +L+

block of instructions. Our empirical results show that just a few features +L+

are adequate for quite good performance at this task for a real modern +L+

processor, and that any of several supervised learning methods perform +L+

nearly optimally with respect to the features used. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Category: Applications (compiler optimization) +L+ </keyword>

<note> Original: This work has not been submitted elsewhere. +L+

Presentation: We prefer oral presentation. +L+

Contact author: Eliot Moss +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Multi-time Models for Temporally Abstract +L+

Planning +L+ </title>

<author> Doina Precup, Richard S. Sutton +L+ </author>

<affiliation> University of Massachusetts +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Amherst, MA 01003 +L+ </address>

<email> fdprecupjrichg@cs.umass.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Planning and learning at multiple levels of temporal abstraction is a key +L+

problem for artificial intelligence. In this paper we summarize an approach to this problem based on the mathematical framework of Markov +L+

decision processes and reinforcement learning. Current model-based reinforcement learning is based on one-step models that cannot represent +L+

common-sense higher-level actions, such as going to lunch, grasping an +L+

object, or flying to Denver. This paper generalizes prior work on temporally abstract models [Sutton, 1995] and extends it from the prediction +L+

setting to include actions, control, and planning. We introduce a more +L+

general form of temporally abstract model, the multi-time model, and establish its suitability for planning and learning by virtue of its relationship +L+

to the Bellman equations. This paper summarizes the theoretical framework of multi-time models and illustrates their potential advantages in a +L+

gridworld planning task. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> The need for hierarchical </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Intra-Option Learning about Temporally Abstract Actions +L+ </title>

<author> Richard S. Sutton +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Massachusetts +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Amherst, MA 01003-4610 +L+ </address>

<email> rich@cs.umass.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Doina Precup +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Massachusetts +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Amherst, MA 01003-4610 +L+ </address>

<email> dprecup@cs.umass.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Satinder Singh +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Colorado +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Boulder, CO 80309-0430 +L+ </address>

<email> baveja@cs.colorado.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Several researchers have proposed modeling +L+

temporally abstract actions in reinforcement +L+

learning by the combination of a policy and a termination condition, which we refer to as an option. Value functions over options and models of +L+

options can be learned using methods designed +L+

for semi-Markov decision processes (SMDPs). +L+

However, all these methods require an option to +L+

be executed to termination. In this paper we explore methods that learn about an option from +L+

small fragments of experience consistent with +L+

that option, even if the option itself is not executed. We call these methods intra-option learning methods because they learn from experience +L+

within an option. Intra-option methods are sometimes much more efficient than SMDP methods because they can use off-policy temporal-difference mechanisms to learn simultaneously +L+

about all the options consistent with an experience, not just the few that were actually executed. In this paper we present intra-option learning methods for learning value functions over options and for learning multi-time models of the +L+

consequences of options. We present computational examples in which these new methods +L+

learn much faster than SMDP methods and learn +L+

effectively when SMDP methods cannot learn at +L+

all. We also sketch a convergence proof for intra +L+

option value learning. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A Method Providing Identity Privacy to Mobile Users during +L+

Authentication +L+ </title>

<author> Didier Samfat, Refik Molva +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Institut Eurecom +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 2229 Route des Cr^etes +L+

BP 193 - Sophia Antipolis FRANCE +L+ </address>

<email> fsamfat, molvag@eurecom.fr +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The increasing development of mobile networks +L+

raises new security requirements and concerns. In addition to the basic need of authentication, confidentiality and key distribution services, a new problem involving privacy is the unauthorized tracking of users' +L+

migration. In other words, accessing any information +L+

related to the mobile user's location data without his +L+

consent, is a serious violation of his privacy. Moreover, if no care is taken, the disclosure of the mobile +L+

user real identity may appear during the authentication process. The basic solution to this problem is the +L+

use of aliases which insure non-traceability by hiding +L+

the user's real identity and also his relationship with +L+

domain authorities. In this paper we provide a classification of the different degrees of non-traceability and +L+

present a new efficient method for the computation of +L+

aliases. This technique can be used during authentication of mobile users and thus avoids the drawbacks of +L+

existing solutions such as GSM and CDPD. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Composite Model Checking with Type Specific +L+

Symbolic Encodings  +L+ </title>

<author> Tevfik Bultan Richard Gerber +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Maryland, </affiliation> <address> College Park, MD 20742, USA +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We present a new symbolic model checking technique, which analyzes temporal properties in multi-typed transition systems. Specifically, the method uses multiple type-specific data encodings to represent +L+

system states, and it carries out fixpoint computations via the corresponding type-specific symbolic +L+

operations. In essence, different symbolic encodings are unified into one composite model checker. Any +L+

type-specific language can be included in this framework provided that the language is closed under +L+

Boolean connectives, propositions can be checked for satisfiability, and relational images can be computed. +L+

Our technique relies on conjunctive partitioning of transition relations of atomic events based on variable +L+

types involved, which allows independent computation of one-step pre- and post-conditions for each +L+

variable type. +L+

In this paper we demonstrate the effectiveness of our method on a nontrivial data-transfer protocol, +L+

which contains a mixture of integer and Boolean-valued variables. The protocol operates over an unreliable channel that can lose, duplicate or reorder messages. Moreover, the protocol's send and receive +L+

window sizes are not specified in advance; rather, they are represented as symbolic constants. The resulting system was automatically verified using our composite model checking approach, in concert with +L+

a conservative approximation technique. +L+ </abstract>

<note> This research is supported in part by ONR grant N00014-94-10228 and NSF CCR-9619808. +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Mobile-End Transport Protocol: +L+

An Alternative to TCP/IP Over Wireless Links  +L+ </title>

<author> Kuang-Yeh Wang +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Maryland +L+ </affiliation>

<address> College Park, MD 20742 +L+ </address>

<email> kwang@cs.umd.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Satish K. Tripathi +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Bourns College of Engineering +L+

University of California +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Riverside, CA 92521-0425 +L+ </address>

<email> tripathi@engr.ucr.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Unlike wired links, wireless network bandwidth is highly limited +L+

and the channel usually suffers from frequent and bursty loss due +L+

to its vulnerability to various kinds of interference. At the same +L+

time, the traditional TCP with its congestion control is well known +L+

for its poor performance over wireless links. This paper proposes +L+

a new protocol that (1) replaces TCP/IP over the wireless link by +L+

a simpler protocol with smaller headers, if the link is the last hop +L+

along a data path, (2) shifts functions needed to communicate with +L+

an Internet host using TCP/IP from the mobile host to the base +L+

station, so that the distinct wireless link is hidden from the outside Internet, and (3) exploits link-layer acknowledgments and re-transmissions to quickly recover losses over the wireless link. Our +L+

simulation results show a substantial performance improvement +L+

achieved by the new protocol. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Ratio Rules: +L+

A New Paradigm for Fast, Quantifiable Data Mining +L+ </title>

<author> Flip Korn, Alexandros Labrinidis, Yannis Kotidis +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Maryland +L+ </affiliation>

<address> College Park, MD 20742 +L+ </address>

<email> fflip,labrinid,kotidisg@cs.umd.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Christos Faloutsos  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department +L+

Carnegie Mellon University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Pittsburgh, PA 15213 +L+ </address>

<email> christos@cs.cmu.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Association Rule Mining algorithms operate +L+

on a data matrix (e.g., customers fi products) +L+

to derive association rules [2, 23]. We propose a new paradigm, namely, Ratio Rules, +L+

which are quantifiable in that we can measure +L+

the "goodness" of a set of discovered rules. +L+

We propose to use the "guessing error" as a +L+

measure of the "goodness", that is, the root-mean-square error of the reconstructed values +L+

of the cells of the given matrix, when we pretend that they are unknown. Another contribution is a novel method to guess missing/hidden values from the Ratio Rules that +L+

our method derives. For example, if somebody bought $10 of milk and $3 of bread, our +L+

rules can "guess" the amount spent on, say, +L+

butter. Thus, we can perform a variety of important tasks such as forecasting, answering +L+

"what-if" scenarios, detecting outliers, and visualizing the data. Moreover, we show how to +L+

compute Ratio Rules in a single pass over the +L+

dataset with small memory requirements (a +L+

few small matrices), in contrast to traditional +L+

association rule mining methods that require +L+

multiple passes and/or large memory. Experiments +L+ </abstract>

<note> Work performed while at the University of Maryland. This +L+

research was partially funded by the Institute for Systems Research (ISR), and by the National Science Foundation under +L+

Grants No. EEC-94-02384, IRI-9205273 and IRI-9625428. +L+

Permission to copy without fee all or part of this material is +L+

granted provided that the copies are not made or distributed for +L+

direct commercial advantage, the VLDB copyright notice and +L+

the title of the publication and its date appear, and notice is +L+

given that copying is by permission of the Very Large Data Base +L+

Endowment. To copy otherwise, or to republish, requires a fee +L+

and/or special permission from the Endowment. +L+

Proceedings of the 24th VLDB Conference +L+

New York, USA, 1998 +L+ </note>

<abstract> on several real datasets (e.g., basketball and baseball statistics, biological data) +L+

demonstrate that the proposed method consistently achieves a "guessing error" of up to +L+

5 times less than the straightforward competi +L+

tor. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> To appear in Proc. AAAI'97 +L+ </note>

<title> Dynamic Abstraction Planning +L+ </title>

<author> Robert P. Goldman, David J. Musliner, Kurt D. Krebsbach, Mark S. Boddy +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Automated Reasoning Group +L+

Honeywell Technology Center +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 3660 Technology Drive +L+

Minneapolis, MN 55418 +L+ </address>

<email> fgoldman,musliner,krebsbac,boddyg@htc.honeywell.com +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper describes Dynamic Abstraction Planning +L+

(DAP), an abstraction planning technique that improves the efficiency of state-enumeration planners for +L+

real-time embedded systems such as CIRCA. Abstraction is used to remove detail from the state representation, reducing both the size of the state space that +L+

must be explored to produce a plan and the size of the +L+

resulting plan. The intuition behind this approach is +L+

simple: in some situations, certain world features are +L+

important, while in other situations those same features are not important. +L+

By automatically selecting the appropriate level of abstraction at each step during the planning process, +L+

DAP can significantly reduce the size of the search +L+

space. Furthermore, the planning process can supply +L+

initial plans that preserve safety but might, on further +L+

refinement, do a better job of goal achievement. DAP +L+

can also terminate with an executable abstract plan, +L+

which may be much smaller than the corresponding +L+

plan expanded to precisely-defined states. Preliminary +L+

results show dramatic improvements in planning speed +L+

and scalability. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> Appears in Working Notes of the NASA Workshop on Planning and Scheduling for Space +L+

Oxnard, CA, October 1997 +L+ </note>

<title> CIRCA and the Cassini Saturn Orbit Insertion: +L+

Solving a Prepositioning Problem +L+ </title>

<author> David J. Musliner and Robert P. Goldman +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Automated Reasoning Group +L+

Honeywell Technology Center +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 3660 Technology Drive +L+

Minneapolis, MN 55418 +L+ </address>

<email> fmusliner,goldmang@htc.honeywell.com +L+ </email>

<intro> Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Quantum Computing | A treatise +L+ </title>

<author> Prabhat Kumar +L+ </author>

<date> October 24, 1996 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Quantum computing has witnessed a surge of activity recently owing +L+

to some very exciting discoveries on both the theoretical and practical +L+

fronts. In this overview, we sketch an account of the developments in +L+

this scientifically intriguing field, starting in the early 80's when the first +L+

questions about the computability of quantum processes were raised, +L+

and which led to the formal definitions of a Quantum Computer and a +L+

Quantum Complexity Theory. Peter Shor's recent remarkable discovery of quantum algorithms to solve the problems of integer factoring +L+

and discrete log computing, which are believed to be extremely hard to +L+

solve efficiently on classical computers, is a compelling demonstration +L+

of the suspected superiority of quantum computing over the classical +L+

model that is in use today. We discuss one of his algorithms and the +L+

implications it has for classical cryptography. We discuss some of the +L+

latest work in this field which has brought us yet closer to achieving a +L+

physical realization of a quantum computer. Whenever it happens, if it +L+

happens, it would be yet another revolution in the field of computing, +L+

and maybe the biggest one to date. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Birth of Quantum Computing </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Within the Letter of the Law: open-textured planning +L+ </title>

<author> Kathryn E. Sanders  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Maryland +L+ </affiliation>

<address> College Park, MD 20742 +L+ </address>

<email> sanders@cs.umd.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Most case-based reasoning systems have used a +L+

single "best" or "most similar" case as the basis +L+

for a solution. For many problems, however, +L+

there is no single exact solution. Rather, there +L+

is a range of acceptable answers. We use cases +L+

not only as a basis for a solution, but also to +L+

indicate the boundaries within which a solution +L+

can be found. We solve problems by choosing +L+

some point within those boundaries. +L+

In this paper, I discuss this use of cases with +L+

illustrations from chiron, a system I have implemented in the domain of personal income +L+

tax planning. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A Comparison of Content-Based Image/Video Retrieval +L+

Systems +L+ </title>

<author> Fatma Ozcan +L+ </author>

<date> December 15, 1997 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Recently, content-based retrieval of images and video has become a hot research area. The reason for this +L+

is the need for effective and efficient techniques, that meet user requirements, to access large volumes of digital +L+

images and video data. In [GR 95], previous approaches to content-based retrieval is said to have taken two +L+

directions. In the first approach, image contents are modeled as a set of attributes extracted manually and +L+

managed within the framework of conventional database-management systems. The second approach depends +L+

on an integrated feature-extraction/object-recognition subsystem to overcome the limitations of attribute-based retrieval. However, it has been also stated that [GR 95] recent content-based image retrieval systems +L+

recognized the need for synergy between these two approaches. +L+

There has been numerous efforts to build content-based image retrieval systems. These include, Chabot +L+

[OS 95], SCORE [ATY 95, ATY 96], CONIVAS [AD 96], Photobook [PPS 93], CANDID [KCH 95], JACOB +L+

[ALDV 96, LA 96], VisualSEEk [SC 96] and QBIC [FSN+ 95]. In the first place, these systems differ in their +L+

querying capabilities. Images could be retrieved through the use of color, texture, sketch, shape, volume, +L+

spatial constraints, browsing, motion, text and domain concepts. Current approaches to content-based image +L+

retrieval also differ in terms of image features extracted, their level of abstraction and the degree of domain +L+

independence. In this paper, a comparative survey on these systems is conducted to figure out design tradeoffs +L+

and different approaches to content-based image retrieval. Furthermore, a taxonomy of content-based retrieval +L+

systems, as well as a generic architecture, is provided. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Efficiently Supporting Ad Hoc Queries in Large Datasets of Time +L+

Sequences +L+ </title>

<author> Flip Korn  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Computer Science +L+

University of Maryland +L+ </affiliation>

<address> College Park, MD 20742 +L+ </address>

<email> flip@cs.umd.edu +L+ </email>

<author> H. V. Jagadish +L+ </author>

<affiliation> AT&T Laboratories +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Florham Park, NJ 07932 +L+ </address>

<email> jag@research.att.com +L+ </email>

<author> Christos Faloutsos  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Computer Science and +L+

Inst. for Systems Research +L+

University of Maryland +L+ </affiliation>

<address> College Park, MD 20742 +L+ </address>

<email> christos@cs.umd.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Ad hoc querying is difficult on very large datasets, since it +L+

is usually not possible to have the entire dataset on disk. +L+

While compression can be used to decrease the size of the +L+

dataset, compressed data is notoriously difficult to index +L+

or access. +L+

In this paper we consider a very large dataset comprising multiple distinct time sequences. Each point in the +L+

sequence is a numerical value. We show how to compress +L+

such a dataset into a format that supports ad hoc querying, provided that a small error can be tolerated when the +L+

data is uncompressed. Experiments on large, real world +L+

datasets (AT&T customer calling patterns) show that the +L+

proposed method achieves an average of less than 5% error +L+

in any data value after compressing to a mere 2.5% of the +L+

original space (i.e., a 40:1 compression ratio), with these +L+

numbers not very sensitive to dataset size. Experiments +L+

on aggregate queries achieved a 0.5% reconstruction error +L+

with a space requirement under 2%. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> How to Be a Good +L+

Graduate Student +L+

Advisor +L+ </title>

<author> Marie desJardins +L+ </author>

<email> marie@erg.sri.com +L+ </email>

<date> March 1994 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper attempts to raise some issues that +L+

are important for graduate students to be successful and to get as much out of the process +L+

as possible, and for advisors who wish to help +L+

their students be successful. The intent is not +L+

to provide prescriptive advice no formulas for +L+

finishing a thesis or twelve-step programs for becoming a better advisor are given but to raise +L+

awareness on both sides of the advisor-student +L+

relationship as to what the expectations are and +L+

should be for this relationship, what a graduate +L+

student should expect to accomplish, common +L+

problems, and where to go if the advisor is not +L+

forthcoming. +L+ </abstract>

<NEW_HEADER>

<note> To appear, Computer Aided Design, 1995 or 1996 +L+ </note>

<title> GENERATING REDESIGN SUGGESTIONS TO REDUCE SETUP COST: +L+

A STEP TOWARDS AUTOMATED REDESIGN +L+ </title>

<author> Diganta Das +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Mechanical Engr. Dept. and +L+

Institute for Systems Research, +L+

University of Maryland +L+ </affiliation>

<address> College Park, MD 20742 +L+ </address>

<email> diganta@cs.umd.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Satyandra K. Gupta +L+ </author>

<affiliation> The Robotics Institute +L+

Carnegie Mellon University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Pittsburgh, PA 15213 +L+ </address>

<email> skgupta@isl1.ri.cmu.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Dana S. Nau +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Computer Science and +L+

Institute for Systems Research, +L+

University of Maryland +L+ </affiliation>

<address> College Park, MD 20742 +L+ </address>

<email> nau@cs.umd.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

All mechanical designs pass through a series of formal and informal redesign steps, involving the analysis of functionality, manufacturability, cost and other life-cycle factors. The +L+

speed and efficacy of these steps has a major influence on the lead time of the product from +L+

conceptualization to launching. In this paper we propose a methodology for automatically +L+

generating redesign suggestions for reducing setup costs for machined parts. +L+

Given an interpretation of the design as a collection of machinable features, our approach +L+

is to generate alternate machining features by making geometric changes to the original +L+

features, and add them to the feature set of the original part to create an extended feature +L+

set. The designer may provide restrictions on the design indicating the type and extent of +L+

modifications allowed on certain faces and volumes, in which case all redesign suggestions +L+

generated by our approach honor those restrictions. +L+

By taking combinations of features from the extended feature set generated above, we can +L+

generate modified versions of the original design that still satisfy the designer's intent. By +L+

considering precedence constraints and approach directions for the machining operations as +L+

well as simple fixturability constraints, we can estimate the setup time that will be required +L+

for each design. Any modified design whose setup time is less than that of the original +L+

design can be presented to the designer as a possible way to modify the original design. +L+ </abstract>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Transport and Display Mechanisms For Multimedia +L+

Conferencing Across Packet-Switched Networks * +L+ </title>

<author> K. Jeffay, D.L. Stone, F.D. Smith +L+ </author>

<affiliation> University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill +L+

Department of Computer Science +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Chapel Hill, NC 27599-3175 USA +L+ </address>

<email> -jeffay,stone,smithfd-@cs.unc.edu +L+ </email>

<date> September, 1993 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract: A transport protocol that supports real-time communication of +L+

audio/video frames across campus-area packet switched networks is presented. +L+

It is a best effort protocol that attempts to ameliorate the effect of jitter, load +L+

variation, and packet loss, to provide low latency, synchronized audio and video +L+

communications. This goal is realized through four transport and display +L+

mechanisms, and a real-time implementation of these mechanisms that +L+

integrates operating system services ( e.g., scheduling and resource allocation, +L+

and device management) with network communication services ( e.g., transport +L+

protocols), and with application code ( e.g., display routines). The four +L+

mechanisms are: a facility for varying the synchronization between audio and +L+

video to achieve continuous audio in the face of jitter, a network congestion +L+

monitoring mechanism that is used to control audio/video latency, a queueing +L+

mechanism at the sender that is used to maximize frame throughput without +L+

unnecessarily increasing latency, and a forward error correction mechanism for +L+

transmitting audio frames multiple times to ameliorate the effects of packet loss +L+

in the network. The effectiveness of these techniques is demonstrated by +L+

measuring the performance of the protocol when transmitting audio and video +L+

across congested networks. +L+ </abstract>

<note> Published in: Computer Networks and ISDN Systems, +L+

Vol. 26, No. 10, (July 1994) pp. 1281-1304. +L+

* This work supported in parts by grants from the National Science Foundation (numbers CCR-9110938 and ICI +L+

9015443), and by the Digital Equipment Corporation and the IBM Corporation. +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> To appear in 1996 ACM SIGMETRICS (Extended Version: UMass TR 95-98, Nov. 1995) +L+ </note>

<title> Supporting Stored Video: Reducing Rate Variability and End-to-End Resource +L+

Requirements through Optimal Smoothing  +L+ </title>

<author> James D. Salehi, Zhi-Li Zhang, James F. Kurose, and Don Towsley +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science, University of Massachusetts, </affiliation> <address> Amherst MA 01003, USA +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

VBR compressed video is known to exhibit significant, multiple- +L+

time-scale bit rate variability. In this paper, we consider the transmission of stored video from a server to a client across a high speed +L+

network, and explore how the client buffer space can be used most +L+

effectively toward reducing the variability of the transmitted bit +L+

rate. +L+

We present two basic results. First, we present an optimal +L+

smoothing algorithm for achieving the greatest possible reduction +L+

in rate variability when transmitting stored video to a client with +L+

given buffer size. We provide a formal proof of optimality, and +L+

demonstrate the performance of the algorithm on a set of long +L+

MPEG-1 encoded video traces. Second, we evaluate the impact +L+

of optimal smoothing on the network resources needed for video +L+

transport, under two network service models: Deterministic Guar- +L+

anteed service [1, 11] and Renegotiated CBR (RCBR) service [9, 8]. +L+

Under both models, we find the impact of optimal smoothing to be +L+

dramatic. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

<title> Alleviating Priority Inversion and Non-determinism +L+

in Real-time CORBA ORB Core Architectures +L+ </title>

<author> Douglas C. Schmidt, Sumedh Mungee, and Aniruddha Gokhale +L+ </author>

<email> fschmidt,sumedh,gokhaleg@cs.wustl.edu +L+ </email>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science, Washington University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> St. Louis, MO 63130, USA  +L+ </address>

<note> This paper has been submitted to the 4 th IEEE Real-time +L+

Technology and Applications Symposium (RTAS), Denver, +L+

Colorado, June 3-5, 1998. +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

There is increasing demand to extend CORBA to support +L+

applications with stringent real-time requirements. However, conventional CORBA Object Request Brokers (ORBs) +L+

exhibit substantial priority inversion and non-determinism, +L+

which makes them unsuitable for applications with deterministic real-time requirements. This paper focuses on software +L+

architectures that help to alleviate priority inversion and non-determinism in real-time CORBA ORBs. It also illustrates empirically why conventional ORBs do not yet support real-time +L+

quality of service. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: Real-time CORBA Object Request Broker, QoS-enabled OO Middleware, Performance Measurements +L+ </keyword>

<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Reducing False Sharing on Shared Memory Multiprocessors +L+

through Compile Time Data Transformations +L+ </title>

<author> Tor E. Jeremiassen +L+ </author>

<affiliation> AT&T Bell Laboratories  +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 600 Mountain Ave. +L+

Murray Hill, New Jersey 07974 +L+ </address>

<email> tor@research.att.com +L+ </email>

<author> Susan J. Eggers +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science and Engineering +L+

University of Washington +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Seattle, Washington 98195 +L+ </address>

<email> eggers@cs.washington.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We have developed compiler algorithms that analyze explicitly parallel programs and restructure their shared data to +L+

reduce the number of false sharing misses. The algorithms +L+

analyze per-process shared data accesses, pinpoint the data +L+

structures that are susceptible to false sharing and choose +L+

an appropriate transformation to reduce it. The transformations either group data that is accessed by the same processor or separate individual data items that are shared. +L+

This paper evaluates that technique. We show through +L+

simulation that our analysis successfully identifies the data +L+

structures that are responsible for most false sharing misses, +L+

and then transforms them without unduly decreasing spatial +L+

locality. The reduction in false sharing positively impacts +L+

both execution time and program scalability when executed +L+

on a KSR2. Both factors combine to increase the maximum +L+

achievable speedup for all programs, more than doubling +L+

it for several. Despite being able to only approximate actual inter-processor memory accesses, the compiler-directed +L+

transformations always outperform programmer efforts to +L+

eliminate false sharing. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

<note> To appear in Proceedings of the Twenty Third ACM SIGPLAN-SIGACT +L+

Symposium on Principles of Programming Languages, St. Petersburg +L+

Beach, Florida, January 21-24, 1996. c fl1996 ACM (see notice below). +L+ </note>

<title> Is it a Tree, a DAG, or a Cyclic Graph? +L+

A Shape Analysis for Heap-Directed Pointers in C +L+ </title>

<author> Rakesh Ghiya and Laurie J. Hendren +L+ </author>

<affiliation> School of Computer Science, McGill University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Montreal, Quebec, CANADA H3A 2A7 +L+ </address>

<email> fghiya,hendreng@cs.mcgill.ca +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

This paper reports on the design and implementation of a practical shape analysis for C. The purpose of the analysis is to aid in the disambiguation of +L+

heap-allocated data structures by estimating the shape +L+

(Tree, DAG, or Cyclic Graph) of the data structure accessible from each heap-directed pointer. This shape +L+

information can be used to improve dependence testing and in parallelization, and to guide the choice of +L+

more complex heap analyses. +L+

The method has been implemented as a context-sensitive interprocedural analysis in the McCAT compiler. Experimental results and observations are given +L+

for 16 benchmark programs. These results show that +L+

the analysis gives accurate and useful results for an +L+

important group of applications. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction and Related </intro>

<title> Constraint-Based Animations +L+ </title>

<title> Dynamic Resource Management for Continuous +L+

Media Traffic over ATM Networks +L+ </title>

<author> Rose P. Tsang 1 , Paisal Keattithananant +L+

Taisheng Chang 3 , Jenwei Hsieh 3 , David H.C. Du 2 +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Distributed Multimedia Center 3 +L+

Computer Science Department +L+

University of Minnesota +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Minneapolis, MN 55455 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Real-time continuous media traffic, such as digital video and audio, is expected +L+

to comprise a large percentage of the network load on future high speed packet +L+

switch networks such as ATM. A major feature which distinguishes high speed +L+

networks from traditional slower speed networks is the large amount of data the +L+

network must manage. For efficient network usage, traffic control mechanisms are +L+

essential. Currently, most mechanisms for traffic control (such as flow control) +L+

have centered on the support of Available Bit Rate (ABR), i.e., non real-time, +L+

traffic. With regard to ATM, for ABR traffic, two major types of schemes which +L+

have been proposed are rate-control and credit-control schemes. Neither of these +L+

schemes are directly applicable to Real-time Variable Bit Rate (VBR) traffic such +L+

as continuous media traffic. Traffic control for continuous media traffic is an inherently difficult problem due to the time-sensitive nature of the traffic and its +L+

unpredictable burstiness. In this study, we present a scheme which controls traffic by dynamically allocating/de-allocating resources among competing VCs based +L+

upon their real-time requirements. This scheme incorporates a form of rate-control, +L+

real-time burst-level scheduling and link-link flow control. We show analytically potential performance improvements of our rate-control scheme and present a scheme +L+

for buffer dimensioning. We also present simulation results of our schemes and discuss the tradeoffs inherent in maintaining high network utilization and statistically +L+

guaranteeing many users' Quality of Service. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: Asynchronous Transfer Mode (ATM), dynamic traffic control, resource man +L+

agement, rate control, Real-time Variable Bit Rate traffic, continuous media traffic. +L+ </keyword>

<note> 1 This work is supported in part by U S WEST Communications. </note>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> A short version of this paper appears in Supercomputing 1996  +L+

The serial algorithms described in this paper are implemented by the +L+

`METIS: Unstructured Graph Partitioning and Sparse Matrix Ordering System'. +L+

METIS is available on WWW at URL: </note> <web> http://www.cs.umn.edu/karypis/metis/metis.html +L+ </web>

<title> Parallel Multilevel k -way Partitioning Scheme for +L+

Irregular Graphs +L+ </title>

<author> George Karypis and Vipin Kumar +L+ </author>

<affiliation> University of Minnesota, Department of Computer Science +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Minneapolis, MN 55455, </address> <pubnum> Technical Report: 96-036 +L+ </pubnum>

<email> fkarypis, kumarg@cs.umn.edu +L+ </email>

<note> Last updated on October 24, 1996 at 9:02am +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

In this paper we present a parallel formulation of a multilevel k-way graph partitioning algorithm. The multilevel +L+

k-way partitioning algorithm reduces the size of the graph by collapsing vertices and edges (coarsening phase), finds +L+

a k-way partitioning of the smaller graph, and then it constructs a k-way partitioning for the original graph by projecting and refining the partition to successively finer graphs (uncoarsening phase). A key innovative feature of our +L+

parallel formulation is that it utilizes graph coloring to effectively parallelize both the coarsening and the refinement +L+

during the uncoarsening phase. Our algorithm is able to achieve a high degree of concurrency, while maintaining the +L+

high quality partitions produced by the serial algorithm. We test our scheme on a large number of graphs from finite +L+

element methods, and transportation domains. For graphs with a million vertices, our parallel formulation produces +L+

high quality 128-way partitions on 128 processors in a little over two seconds, on Cray T3D. Thus our parallel algorithm makes it feasible to perform frequent dynamic graph partition in adaptive computations without compromising +L+

quality. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Keywords: Parallel Graph Partitioning, Multilevel Partitioning Methods, Spectral Partitioning Methods, +L+

Kernighan-Lin Heuristic, Parallel Sparse Matrix Algorithms. +L+ </keyword>

<note> This work was supported by NSF CCR-9423082 and by Army Research Office contract DA/DAAH04-95-1-0538, and by Army High Performance Computing Research Center under the auspices of the Department of the Army, Army Research Laboratory cooperative agreement +L+

number DAAH04-95-2-0003/contract number DAAH04-95-C-0008, the content of which does not necessarily reflect the position or the policy of the government, and no official endorsement should be inferred. Access to computing facilities was provided by AHPCRC, Minnesota +L+

Supercomputer Institute, Cray Research Inc, and by the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center. Related papers are available via WWW at URL: +L+

http://www.cs.umn.edu/karypis +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Optimizing Multi-Join Queries in Parallel Relational Databases +L+ </title>

<author> Jaideep Srivastava +L+

Gary Elsesser +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Computer Science Department +L+

University of Minnesota +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Minneapolis, MN 55455 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Query optimization for parallel machines needs to +L+

consider machine architecture, processor and memory +L+

resources available, and different types of parallelism, +L+

making the search space much larger than the sequential case. In this paper our aim is to determine a plan +L+

that makes the execution of an individual query very +L+

fast, making minimizing parallel execution time the +L+

right objective. This creates the following circular dependence: a plan tree is needed for effective resource +L+

assignment, which is needed to estimate the parallel +L+

execution time, and this is needed for the cost-based +L+

search for a good plan tree. In this paper we propose +L+

a new search heuristic that breaks the cycle by constructing the plan tree layer by layer in a bottom-up +L+

manner. To select nodes at the next level, the lower +L+

and upper bounds on the execution time for plans consistent with the decisions made so far are estimated +L+

and are used to guide the search. A query plan representation for intra- and inter-operator parallelism, +L+

pipelining, and processor and memory assignment is +L+

proposed. Also proposed is a new approach to estimating the parallel execution time of a plan that considers +L+

sum and max of operators working sequentially and +L+

in parallel, respectively. The results obtained from a +L+

prototype optimizer are presented. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<pubnum> CS/TR-92-80 +L+ </pubnum>

<title> The COOL architecture and abstractions for object-oriented +L+

distributed operating systems +L+ </title>

<author> Rodger Lea, Christian Jacquemot +L+ </author>

<note> approved by: +L+

distribution: COOL +L+ </note>

<abstract> abstract: Building distributed operating systems benefits from the micro-kernel approach by allowing better support for modularization. However, we believe +L+

that we need to take this support a step further. A more modular, or object +L+

oriented approach is needed if we wish to cross the barrier of complexity that +L+

is holding back distributed operating system development. The Chorus Ob +L+

ject Oriented Layer (COOL) is a layer built above the Chorus micro-kernel +L+

designed to extend the micro-kernel abstractions with support for object oriented systems. COOL v2, the second iteration of this layer provides generic +L+

support for clusters of objects, in a distributed virtual memory model. It is +L+

built as a layered system where the lowest layer support only clusters and the +L+

upper layers support objects. +L+ </abstract>

<note> c Chorus systemes, 1992 +L+

c Chorus systemes, 1992 September 21, 1992 +L+ </note>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>

<title> Using PVS to Analyze Hierarchical State-Based Requirements for +L+

<author> Mats P.E. Heimdahl +L+ </author>

<title> AN ALGORITHM FOR GENERATING EXECUTABLE +L+

ASSERTIONS FOR FAULT TOLERANCE  +L+ </title>

<author> Martina Schollmeyer, Hanan Lutfiyya and Bruce McMillin +L+ </author>

<pubnum> CSC-92-01 +L+ </pubnum>

<date> March 21, 1992 +L+ </date>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Missouri at Rolla +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Rolla, Missouri 65401 +L+ </address>

<note> This work was supported in part by the National Science Foundation under Grant Numbers MIP-8909749 and CDA-8820714, and in part by the AMOCO Faculty Development +L+

Program. +L+ </note>

<NEW_HEADER>

<note> To be presented at the 17th IEEE Real-Time Systems Symposium, December 1996. +L+ </note>

<title> A Framework for Implementing Objects and Scheduling Tasks in Lock-Free +L+

Real-Time Systems  +L+ </title>

<author> James H. Anderson and Srikanth Ramamurthy +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We present an integrated framework for developing real-time systems in which lock-free algorithms are employed to +L+

implement shared objects. There are two key objectives of +L+

our work. The first is to enable functionality for object sharing in lock-free real-time systems that is comparable to that +L+

in lock-based systems. Our main contribution toward this +L+

objective is an efficient approach for implementing multi-object lock-free operations and transactions. A second key +L+

objective of our work is to improve upon previously proposed +L+

scheduling conditions for tasks that share lock-free objects. +L+

When developing such conditions, the key issue is to bound +L+

the cost of operation interferences. We present a general +L+

approach for doing this, based on linear programming. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1. Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Universal Constructions for Large Objects +L+ </title>

<author> James H. Anderson and Mark Moir +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Computer Science, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We present lock-free and wait-free universal constructions for implementing large +L+

shared objects. Most previous universal constructions require processes to copy the +L+

entire object state, which is impractical for large objects. Previous attempts to +L+

address this problem require programmers to explicitly fragment large objects into +L+

smaller, more manageable pieces, paying particular attention to how such pieces are +L+

copied. In contrast, our constructions are designed to largely shield programmers +L+

from this fragmentation. Furthermore, for many objects, our constructions result +L+

in lower copying overhead than previous ones. +L+

Fragmentation is achieved in our constructions through the use of load-linked, +L+

store-conditional, and validate operations on a "large" multi-word shared variable. +L+

Before presenting our constructions, we show that these operations can be efficiently +L+

implemented from similar one-word primitives. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> View-Dependent Simplification Of Arbitrary Polygonal Environments +L+ </title>

<author> David Luebke, Carl Erikson +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill +L+ </affiliation>

<abstract> 1. ABSTRACT +L+

Hierarchical dynamic simplification (HDS) is a new approach to +L+

the problem of simplifying arbitrary polygonal environments. +L+

HDS operates dynamically, retessellating the scene continuously +L+

as the users viewing position shifts, and adaptively, processing +L+

the entire database without first decomposing the environment +L+

into individual objects. The resulting system allows real-time +L+

display of very complex polygonal CAD models consisting of +L+

thousands of parts and hundreds of thousands of polygons. HDS +L+

supports various preprocessing algorithms and various runtime +L+

criteria, providing a general framework for dynamic view-dependent simplification. +L+

Briefly, HDS works by clustering vertices together in a +L+

hierarchical fashion. The simplification process continuously +L+

queries this hierarchy to generate a scene containing only those +L+

polygons that are important from the current viewpoint. When +L+

the volume of space associated with a vertex cluster occupies less +L+

than a userspecified amount of the screen, all vertices within +L+

that cluster are collapsed together and degenerate polygons +L+

filtered out. HDS maintains an active list of visible polygons for +L+

rendering. Since frame-to-frame movements typically involve +L+

small changes in viewpoint, and therefore modify the active list +L+

by only a few polygons, the method takes advantage of temporal +L+

coherence for greater speed. +L+

CR Categories: I.3.5 [Computer Graphics]: Computational Geometry and +L+

Object Modeling - surfaces and object representations. +L+

Additional Keywords: polygonal simplification, level of detail, view +L+

dependent rendering. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 2. INTRODUCTION </intro> 


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Modeling and Parameter Estimation of the Human Index Finger +L+ </title>

<author> Robert N. Rohling and John M. Hollerbach +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Biorobotics Laboratory, McGill University +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 3775 University St., Montreal, Quebec H3A 2B4 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Precise teleoperation of dextrous robotic hands by +L+

hand masters requires an accurate human hand model. +L+

A kinematic model of a human index finger is developed as an example for human hand modeling. The +L+

parameters of the model are determined by open-loop +L+

kinematic calibration. Singular value decomposition is +L+

used as a tool for analyzing the kinematic model and +L+

the identification process. Accurate and reliable results are obtained only when the numerical condition +L+

is minimized through parameter scaling, model reduction and pose set selection. The identified kinematic +L+

parameters show the kinematic model and calibration +L+

procedure have an accuracy on the order of a few millimeters. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> A Dossier Driven Persistent Objects Facility +L+ </title>

<author> Robert Mecklenburg, Charles Clark, Gary Lindstrom and Benny Yih +L+ </author>

<affiliation> University of Utah Center for Software Science +L+

Department of Computer Science +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Salt Lake City, UT 84112 +L+ </address>

<email> E-mail: fmecklen,clark,gary,yihg@cs.utah.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We describe the design and implementation of a persistent object storage facility +L+

based on a dossier driven approach. Objects are characterized by dossiers which describe both their language defined and "extra-linguistic" properties. These dossiers are +L+

generated by a C++ preprocessor in concert with an augmented, but completely C++ +L+

compatible, class description language. The design places very few burdens on the application programmer and can be used without altering the data member layout of application objects or inheriting from special classes. The storage format is kept simple to allow +L+

the use of a variety of data storage backends. In addition, these dossiers can be used to +L+

implement (or augment) a run-time typing facility compatible with the proposed ANSI +L+

C++ standard. Finally, by providing a generic object to byte stream conversion the persistent object facility can also be used in conjunction with an interprocess communication +L+

facility to provide object-level communication between processes. 1 +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Motivation </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> The Next Frontier: Interactive and Closed Loop Performance +L+

Steering  +L+ </title>

<author> Daniel A. Reed Christopher L. Elford +L+

Tara M. Madhyastha Evgenia Smirni +L+

Stephen E. Lamm +L+ </author>

<email> freed,elford,tara,esmirni,slammg@cs.uiuc.edu +L+ </email>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Illinois +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Urbana, Illinois 61801 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Software for a growing number of problem domains +L+

has complex, time varying behavior and unpredictable +L+

resource demands (e.g., WWW servers and parallel input/output systems). While current performance analysis tools provide insights into application dynamics +L+

and the causes of poor performance, with a posteriori analysis one cannot adapt to temporally varying +L+

application resource demands and system responses. +L+

We believe that the solution to this performance optimization conundrum is integration of dynamic performance instrumentation and on-the-fly performance +L+

data reduction with real-time adaptive control mechanisms that select and configure resource management +L+

algorithms automatically, based on observed application behavior, or interactively, through high-modality +L+

virtual environments. We motivate this belief by first +L+

describing our experiences with performance analysis tools, input/output characterization, and WWW +L+

server analysis, and then sketching the design of interactive and closed loop adaptive control systems. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Compilation of Constraint Systems to +L+

Procedural Parallel Programs +L+ </title>

<author> Ajita John and J. C. Browne +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Dept. of Computer Sciences +L+

University of Texas, </affiliation><address>  Austin, TX 78712 +L+ </address>

<email> fajohn,browneg@cs.utexas.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract. This paper describes the first results from research 1 on the +L+

compilation of constraint systems into task level parallel programs in a +L+

procedural language. This is the only research, of which we are aware, +L+

which attempts to generate efficient parallel programs for numerical +L+

computations from constraint systems. Computations are expressed as +L+

constraint systems. A dependence graph is derived from the constraint +L+

system and a set of input variables. The dependence graph, which exploits the parallelism in the constraints, is mapped to the target language CODE, which represents parallel computation structures as generalized dependence graphs. Finally, parallel C programs are generated. +L+

The granularity of the derived dependence graphs depends upon the +L+

complexity of the operations represented in the type system of the constraint specification language. To extract parallel programs of appropriate granularity, the following features have been included: (i) modularity, (ii) operations over structured types as primitives, (iii) definition +L+

of sequential C functions. A prototype of the compiler has been implemented. The execution environment or software architecture is specified +L+

separately from the constraint system. The domain of matrix computations has been targeted for applications. Some examples have been +L+

programmed. Initial results are very encouraging. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Optimal Wire-Sizing Formula Under the Elmore Delay Model +L+ </title>

<author> Chung-Ping Chen, Yao-Ping Chen, and D. F. Wong +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Sciences, University of Texas, </affiliation> <address> Austin, Texas 78712 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

In this paper, we consider non-uniform wire-sizing. Given a +L+

wire segment of length L, let f(x) be the width of the wire +L+

at position x, 0 x L. We show that the optimal wire-sizing function that minimizes the Elmore delay through the +L+

wire is f(x) = ae bx , where a &gt; 0 and b &gt; 0 are constants +L+

that can be computed in O(1) time. In the case where lower +L+

bound (L &gt; 0) and upper bound (U &gt; 0) on the wire widths +L+

are given, we show that the optimal wire-sizing function f(x) +L+

is a truncated version of ae bx that can also be determined in +L+

O(1) time. Our wire-sizing formula can be iteratively applied +L+

to optimally size the wire segments in a routing tree. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<note> In Proceedings of the Eighth International Workshop +L+

on Qualitative Physics about Physical Systems (QR-94) +L+

Nara, Japan, 1994.  +L+ </note>

<title> Model Decomposition and Simulation +L+ </title>

<author> Daniel J. Clancy and Benjamin Kuipers +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Sciences +L+

University of Texas at Austin +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Austin, Texas 78712 +L+ </address>

<email> clancy@cs.utexas.edu and kuipers@cs.utexas.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Qualitative reasoning uses incomplete knowledge to compute a description of the possible behaviors for dynamic +L+

systems. For complex systems containing a large number +L+

of variables and constraints, the simulation frequently is +L+

intractable or results in a large, incomprehensible behavioral description. Abstraction and aggregation techniques are required during the simulation to eliminate +L+

irrelevant details and highlight the important characteristics of the behavior. The total temporal ordering of +L+

unrelated events provided by a traditional state-based +L+

qualitative representation is one such irrelevant distinction. Model decomposition and simulation addresses this +L+

problem. +L+

Model decomposition uses a causal analysis of the model +L+

to partition the variables into tightly connected components. The components are simulated separately in +L+

the order dictated by the causal analysis beginning with +L+

causally upstream components. Information from the +L+

simulation of causally upstream components is used to +L+

constrain the behavior of downstream components. If a +L+

feedback loop exists between components or a set of components are acausally related, then a concurrent simulation is performed for these components. A truth maintenance system is used to record and retract assumptions +L+

made during this concurrent simulation. +L+

Model decomposition provides a general architecture +L+

which separates the method of simulation from the model +L+

decomposition algorithm. This architecture can be used +L+

to introduce alternative abstraction techniques to eliminate other irrelevant distinctions. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Programming the Web: +L+

An Application-oriented Language for Hypermedia Services +L+ </title>

<author> David A. Ladd J. Christopher Ramming +L+ </author>

<email> ladd@research.att.com jcr@research.att.com +L+ </email>

<affiliation> AT&T Bell Laboratories +L+ </affiliation>

<date> October 9, 1995 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

MAWL is an application language for programming interactive services in the context of the Worldwide +L+

Web. The language is small, because no construct was introduced without compelling justification; as with +L+

yacc [8], general-purpose computation is done in a host language. MAWL offers conveniences such as control +L+

abstraction, persistent state management, synchronization, and shared memory. In addition, the MAWL +L+

compiler performs static checking designed to prevent common Web programming errors. In this paper we +L+

discuss the design and engineering of MAWL. +L+

We describe the problems MAWL is intended to solve, and then discuss our design choices in the context +L+

of our general language design philosophy, We also include an appendix of commentary on several short +L+

MAWL programs. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Stability and Chaos in an Inertial Two +L+

Neuron System +L+ </title>

<author> Diek W. Wheeler 1 and W. C. Schieve +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Ilya Prigogine Center for Studies in Statistical Mechanics and +L+

Complex Systems +L+

and +L+

Physics Department, The University of Texas, +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Austin, TX 78712 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract. +L+

Inertia is added to a continuous-time, Hopfield [1] effective-neuron system. +L+

We explore the effects on the stability of the fixed points of the system. A two +L+

neuron system with one or two inertial terms added is shown to exhibit chaos. +L+

The chaos is confirmed by Lyapunov exponents, power spectra, and phase space +L+

plots. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> INTRODUCTION </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> ON UNAPPROXIMABLE VERSIONS OF NP-COMPLETE +L+

PROBLEMS  +L+ </title>

<author> DAVID ZUCKERMAN  +L+ </author>

<abstract> Abstract. +L+

We prove that all of Karp's 21 original NP -complete problems have a version that's hard to +L+

approximate. These versions are obtained from the original problems by adding essentially the same, +L+

simple constraint. We further show that these problems are absurdly hard to approximate. In fact, no +L+

polynomial-time algorithm can even approximate log (k) of the magnitude of these problems to within +L+

any constant factor, where log (k) denotes the logarithm iterated k times, unless N P is recognized by +L+

slightly superpolynomial randomized machines. We use the same technique to improve the constant +L+

* such that MAX CLIQUE is hard to approximate to within a factor of n * . Finally, we show that it +L+

is even harder to approximate two counting problems: counting the number of satisfying assignments +L+

to a monotone 2-SAT formula and computing the permanent of -1,0,1 matrices. +L+ </abstract>

<keyword> Key words. NP-complete, unapproximable, randomized reduction, clique, counting problems, +L+

permanent, 2SAT +L+ </keyword>

<note> AMS subject classifications. 68Q15, 68Q25, 68Q99 +L+ </note>

<intro> 1. Introduction. </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Recursive Functions of Symbolic +L+

Expressions and Their Computation by +L+

Machine, Part I +L+ </title>

<author> John McCarthy, </author> <affiliation> Massachusetts Institute of Technology, </affiliation> <address> Cambridge, Mass.  +L+ </address>

<date> April 1960 +L+ </date>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Frangipani: A Scalable Distributed File System +L+ </title>

<author> Chandramohan A. Thekkath +L+

Timothy Mann +L+

Edward K. Lee +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Systems Research Center +L+

Digital Equipment Corporation +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 130 Lytton Ave, Palo Alto, CA 94301 +L+ </address>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

The ideal distributed file system would provide all its users with coherent, shared access to the same set of files,yet would be arbitrarily +L+

scalable to provide more storage space and higher performance to +L+

a growing user community. It would be highly available in spite of +L+

component failures. It would require minimal human administration, and administration would not become more complex as more +L+

components were added. +L+

Frangipani is a new file system that approximates this ideal, yet +L+

was relatively easy to build because of its two-layer structure. The +L+

lower layer is Petal (described in an earlier paper), a distributed +L+

storage service that provides incrementally scalable, highly available, automatically managed virtual disks. In the upper layer, +L+

multiple machines run the same Frangipani file system code on top +L+

of a shared Petal virtual disk, using a distributed lock service to +L+

ensure coherence. +L+

Frangipani is meant to run in a cluster of machines that are under +L+

a common administration and can communicate securely. Thus the +L+

machines trust one another and the shared virtual disk approach is +L+

practical. Of course, a Frangipani file system can be exported to +L+

untrusted machines using ordinary network file access protocols. +L+

We have implemented Frangipani on a collection of Alphas +L+

running DIGITAL Unix 4.0. Initial measurements indicate that +L+

Frangipani has excellent single-server performance and scales well +L+

as servers are added. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> The Cost of Recovery in Message Logging Protocols +L+ </title>

<author> Sriram Rao, Lorenzo Alvisi, and Harrick M. Vin +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Sciences +L+

The University of Texas at Austin +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Taylor Hall 2.124, Austin, Texas 78712-1188, USA +L+ </address>

<email> E-mail: fsriram,lorenzo,ving@cs.utexas.edu, </email> <phone> Telephone: (512) 471-9792, Fax: (512) 471-8885 +L+ </phone>

<web> URL: http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/fsriram,lorenzo,ving +L+ </web>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

Message logging is a popular technique for building low-overhead protocols that tolerate +L+

process crash failures. Past research in message logging has focused on studying the relative +L+

overhead imposed by pessimistic, optimistic, and causal protocols during failure-free executions. In this paper, we give the first experimental evaluation of the performance of these +L+

protocols during recovery. We discover that, if a single failure is to be tolerated, pessimistic +L+

and causal protocols perform best, because they avoid rollbacks of correct processes. For +L+

multiple failures, however, the dominant factor in determining performance becomes where +L+

the recovery information is logged (i.e. at the sender, at the receiver, or replicated at a +L+

subset of the processes in the system) rather than when this information is logged (i.e. if +L+

logging is synchronous or asynchronous). From our results, we distil a few lessons that can +L+

guide the design of message-logging protocols that combine low-overhead during failure-free +L+

executions with fast recovery. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>

<title> Design Goals for ACL2 +L+ </title>

<author> Matt Kaufmann and J Strother Moore +L+ </author>

<title> Broadcasting on Meshes with Worm-Hole Routing +L+ </title>

<author> Michael Barnett +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Science +L+

University of Idaho +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Moscow, Idaho 83844-1010 +L+ </address>

<email> mbarnett@cs.uidaho.edu +L+ </email>

<author> David G. Payne +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Supercomputer Systems Division +L+

Intel Corporation +L+ </affiliation>

<address> 15201 N.W. Greenbrier Pkwy +L+

Beaverton, Oregon 97006 +L+ </address>

<email> payne@ssd.intel.com +L+ </email>

<author> Robert A. van de Geijn +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Sciences +L+

The University of Texas at Austin +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Austin, Texas 78712-1188 +L+ </address>

<email> rvdg@cs.utexas.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Jerrell Watts +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Scalable Concurrent Programming Laboratory +L+

California Institute of Technology +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Pasadena, California 91125 +L+ </address>

<email> jwatts@scp.caltech.edu +L+ </email>

<note> Original Version: November 2, 1993 +L+

Revised Version: September 21, 1994 +L+ </note>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

We address the problem of broadcasting on mesh architectures with arbitrary (non-power-two) dimensions. It is assumed that such mesh architectures employ cut-through or worm-hole routing. The +L+

primary focus is on avoiding network conflicts in the various proposed algorithms. We give algorithms +L+

for performing a conflict-free minimum-spanning tree broadcast, a pipelined algorithm that is similar to +L+

Ho and Johnsson's EDST algorithm for hypercubes, and a novel scatter-collect approach that is a natural +L+

choice for communication libraries due to its simplicity. Results obtained on the Intel Paragon system +L+

are included. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> 1 Introduction </intro>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Towards Usable and Lean +L+

Parallel Linear Algebra Libraries  +L+ </title>

<author> Almadena Chtchelkanova Carter Edwards +L+

John Gunnels Greg Morrow +L+

James Overfelt Robert van de Geijn  +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Sciences +L+

and +L+

Texas Institute for Computational and Applied Mathematics +L+

The University of Texas at Austin +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Austin, Texas 78712 +L+ </address>

<date> May 1, 1996 +L+ </date>

<abstract> Abstract +L+

In this paper, we introduce a new parallel library effort, as part of the PLAPACK +L+

project, that attempts to address discrepencies between the needs of applications and +L+

parallel libraries. A number of contributions are made, including a new approach +L+

to matrix distribution, new insights into layering parallel linear algebra libraries, and +L+

the application of "object based" programming techniques which have recently become +L+

popular for (parallel) scientific libraries. We present an overview of a prototype library, +L+

the SL Library, which incorporates these ideas. Preliminary performance data shows +L+

this more application-centric approach to libraries does not necessarily adversely impact +L+

performance, compared to more traditional approaches. +L+ </abstract>

<note> This project is sponsored in part by the Office of Naval Research under Contract N00014-95-1-0401, +L+

the NASA High Performance Computing and Communications Program's Earth and Space Sciences Project +L+

under NRA Grant NAG5-2497, the PRISM project under ARPA grant P-95006. +L+

Corresponding and presenting author. </note> <affiliation> Dept. of Computer Sciences, The University of Texas at Austin, +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Austin, TX 78712, </address> (<phone> 512) 471-9720 (Office), (512) 471-8885 (Fax), </phone> <email> rvdg@cs.utexas.edu. +L+ </email>

<page> +PAGE+ </page>


<NEW_HEADER>

<title> Anatomy of a Parallel Out-of-Core Dense Linear Solver +L+ </title>

<author> Kenneth Klimkowski +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Texas Institute for Computational +L+

and Applied Mathematics +L+

The University of Texas at Austin +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Austin, Texas 78712 +L+ </address>

<email> ken@ticam.utexas.edu +L+ </email>

<author> Robert A. van de Geijn +L+ </author>

<affiliation> Department of Computer Sciences +L+

The University of Texas at Austin +L+ </affiliation>

<address> Austin, Texas 78712 +L+ </address>

<email> rvdg@cs.utexas.edu +L+ </email>

<abstract> Abstract In this paper, we describe the design +L+

and implementation of the Platform Independent +L+

Parallel Solver (PIPSolver) package for the out-of-core (OOC) solution of complex dense linear systems. Our approach is unique in that it allows essentially all of RAM to be filled with the current +L+

portion of the matrix (slab) to be updated and factored, thereby greatly improving the computation to +L+

I/O ratio over previous approaches. Experiences +L+

and performance are reported for the Cray T3D +L+

system. +L+ </abstract>

<intro> INTRODUCTION </intro>

<title> Automated Proof Support for +L+
